data.name: Blog_FEFBI_Summary
data.value: Today, the financial sector operates in a highly digital and data-centric environment. More people are using smartphones and computers for payments, investments, and financial management, shifting away from traditional methods like cash and physical banking. Internet banking has largely replaced in-person transactions, leading to a significant increase in the generation of financial data.

data.name: Blog_FEFBI_Text1
data.value: Today, the financial sector operates in a highly digital and data-centric environment. More people are using smartphones and computers for payments, investments, and financial management, shifting away from traditional methods like cash and physical banking. Internet banking has largely replaced in-person transactions, leading to a significant increase in the generation of financial data.

data.name: Blog_FEFBI_Text2
data.value: However, this digital transformation also heightens vulnerabilities to cyberattacks and data breaches. In fact, data breaches in financial services rank as the second most expensive in terms of costs for each breach, averaging $5.72 million in damages. Small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) are particularly impacted, accounting for 42% of all breaches, with 60% going out of business within six months of an attack.

data.name: Blog_FEFBI_Text3
data.value: As cyber threats evolve, ensuring robust cybersecurity measures in the financial sector becomes critical. With increasingly sophisticated attack methods targeting sensitive financial data — such as phishing, ransomware, and insider threats — financial institutions must continuously enhance their defenses.

data.name: Blog_FEFBI_Text4
data.value: Safeguarding customer information and financial transactions is crucial for maintaining trust and meeting regulatory requirements in today's dynamic digital environment. Proactive strategies like implementing encryption, multi-factor authentication, and conducting regular security audits are essential to mitigate risks and prevent potential breaches that could result in significant financial and reputational harm.

data.name: Blog_FEFBI_Text5
data.value: File encryption is a data security solution that converts sensitive data into an unreadable format, ensuring protection even if unauthorized access occurs. This enhances data security and helps meet regulatory requirements. AxCrypt offers advanced encryption solutions, providing banking and finance organizations with the tools needed to secure their data against breaches and cyber attacks.

data.name: Blog_FEFBI_Text6
data.value: In this post, we will examine the importance of file encryption within the banking and finance industry, explore the various types of encryption methods, and discuss how AxCrypt's advanced encryption solutions can help financial institutions protect their sensitive files at all times.

data.name: Blog_FOKM_Conclusion_Text2

data.name: Blog_FOKM_Conclusion_Text3
data.value: AxCrypt offers strong encryption with 256-bit encryption to secure your data in the three stages of data; data at rest, at transit and in use. Moreover, AxCrypt also provides its users a password management generator that ensures your passwords are as secure as possible. data.name: Blog_FOKM_H1_Text1
data.value: Effective data security is built on the foundation of key management also known as KMS. It is the process of administering or managing cryptographic keys. A critical feature of any KMS is its capacity to handle keys systematically throughout its lifecycle: key generation, key import/export, key distribution, key usage, key update, key backup, key revocation, and key deletion. Data is encrypted and decrypted using encryption keys, therefore the loss or compromise of any encryption key renders the data protection. It also ensures the safe transmission of data across an internet connection and not just includes access control but also monitoring and logging of each key's access, use, and context.

data.name: Blog_FOKM_H2_Text1
data.value: Key management deals with numerous types of security risks beyond encryption, such as people and incorrect policies, cyber attacks and data theft on networks. It is one of the most difficult components of cryptography. It also entails developing a system policy, user training, interdepartmental collaboration, and effective coordination.

data.name: Blog_FOKM_H2_Text2
data.value: In large corporations all members have access to the company data, therefore security is a major concern. The solution is a multicast group key management system that securely distributes individual keys to each member. In this way, material encrypted with a single group member's key can only be accessed and read by that group member.

data.name: Blog_FOKM_H2_Text3
data.value: Key Management also includes controls to guarantee that keys are only accessible to authorised personnel and systems, that they are only used for their intended purposes, and that all key activities are logged for audit and compliance purposes.

data.name: Blog_FOKM_H3_SH3_Text1
data.value: Key sharing is a feature that allows you to keep your data secure while also sharing it with your colleagues. It enables you to collaborate and connect with other members without jeopardising the confidentiality of your data. Using AxCrypt's key sharing function you can give anyone data access and withdraw it whenever you want; you don't even have to disclose your own password. With their own password, the other user can access the shared files. For more info on AxCrypt key sharing check our key sharing tutorial on You Tube for a better understanding of AxCrypt's key sharing capability.

data.name: Blog_FOKM_H3_SH4_Text1
data.value: Master Key is highly secure, it can be viewed as an automatic sharing of files with the administrators of the business. It allows business managers to recover files from other members of the company. This avoids the possibility of losing vital files. No documents will ever be lost owing to employees quitting or forgetting the passwords as long as the company administrators keep track of the credentials. Master key feature is only available for business users. Click here to check more business subscription features. Read more about AxCrypt's master key feature here.

data.name: Blog_GAES256BEWA_H1_SubHeading1
data.value: Is AES 256 secure?

data.name: Blog_GAES256BEWA_H1_SubHeading2
data.value: AES 256 bit Encryption with AxCrypt

data.name: Blog_GAES256BEWA_H1_Text1
data.value: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) recognized the need for an alternative to the Data Encryption Standard (DES), which was becoming vulnerable to brute-force attacks, and thus Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) was created. The US National Security Agency (NSA) authorized AES as the first publicly available cipher for protecting top-secret material.Learn More

data.name: Blog_GAES256BEWA_H1_Text2
data.value: Cybercriminals are constantly on the lookout for weak points to exploit. How can users have complete confidence that their data is safe, no matter where it is stored, especially in this increasingly connected world? Encryption is one of the most prevalent methods for safeguarding sensitive information. Encryption works by turning ordinary text to ciphertext, which consists of seemingly random characters. It can only be decrypted by those who hold the unique key.

data.name: Blog_GAES256BEWA_Heading1
data.value: Why is AES 256-bit encryption required?

data.name: Blog_GAES256BEWA_Summary
data.value: AES is a symmetric algorithm, meaning it uses the same key for encryption and decryption. The technique has been built to accommodate key sizes of 128, 192, and 256 bits.

data.name: Blog_GAES256BEWA_Text1
data.value: AES is a symmetric algorithm, meaning it uses the same key for encryption and decryption. The technique has been built to accommodate key sizes of 128, 192, and 256 bits. It is known as the strongest and most robust encryption standard commercially available today.

data.name: Blog_GAES256BEWA_Text2
data.value: AES-256 bit encryption has a key length of 256 bits and supports the greatest bit size and is practically unbreakable by brute force based on existing computing capability. A brute-force attack is when a hacker checks all possible key combinations until the correct key is found.Learn More

data.name: Blog_GAES256BEWA_Title
data.value: Get AES 256-bit encryption with AxCrypt

Whether on desktop or mobile, AxCrypt ensures your files remain private, giving you complete control over your data security.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_Conclusion_Text2

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text1
data.value: AxCrypt integrates local file encryption with secure cloud storage, ensuring that your files are protected before they even reach the cloud. Here’s how it works:

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text10
data.value: • Real-Time Protection: Files modified in the secured folder are automatically re-encrypted when you sign out or use the Cleanup feature.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text11
data.value: • Temporary Decryption: Files can be opened in their native applications (e.g., Word, Excel), and AxCrypt will re-encrypt them upon saving.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text12
data.value: • Visibility: Encrypted files display the AxCrypt padlock icon instead of the standard file icon, making it easy to identify protected files.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text2
data.value: Encryption Process

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text3
data.value: • AxCrypt uses AES-256 encryption, one of the strongest encryption standards, to secure files locally before syncing them to cloud services like Google Drive, OneDrive, or Dropbox.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text4
data.value: • When you designate a folder as ❝secured❞, any file added to this folder is automatically encrypted and assigned a .axx extension.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text5
data.value: • The file retains its original name but becomes inaccessible without the correct AxCrypt credentials.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text6
data.value: Cloud Integration

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text7
data.value: • Dedicated Folders: AxCrypt creates an ❝AxCrypt❞ folder within your file encryption for cloud services. Any file placed inside is encrypted before syncing to the cloud.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H1_Text8
data.value: • Cross-Platform Access: Encrypted files remain secure and can be accessed on any device running AxCrypt using your master password.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text16
data.value: 1. Install AxCrypt Mobile: Download AxCrypt from the Google Play Store or Apple App Store and sign in.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text17
data.value: 2. Link Your Cloud Storage:

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text18
data.value: • Tap the Secure button.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text19
data.value: • Select a cloud storage provider (Google Drive, OneDrive, or Dropbox).

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text2
data.value: 1. Install AxCrypt: Download and install AxCrypt, then create an account and set a strong master password.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text20
data.value: • Authenticate with your cloud account credentials.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text21

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text22
data.value: • Navigate to the linked cloud storage folder within AxCrypt.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text23
data.value: • Select files and tap Secure to encrypt them.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text25

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text26

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text27
data.value: 5. Stop Securing Files: Use the ❝Stop Securing❞ option to permanently decrypt files if needed.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text28
data.value: Additional Mobile Features

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text3
data.value: 2. Set Up Cloud Storage: Ensure you have a cloud storage service (e.g., Google Drive, OneDrive) installed.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text4

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text5

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text6

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text7

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text8
data.value: 7. Stop Securing Files: To remove encryption, right-click and select Stop Securing.

data.name: Blog_HACEESCSDP_H2_Text9
data.value: 8. Backup Your Master Password: Since AxCrypt does not store your password, losing it means losing access to your files.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H1_Text1
data.value: Robust data security measures in your healthcare organizations can be a game changer. The security measures will not only prevent sensitive healthcare data from unauthorized access, but they would also ensure continued and streamlined operations, making critical healthcare services readily available without interruptions.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H1_Text2
data.value: Protecting patient data is not just a legal obligation; it is an ethical imperative. Healthcare providers have a duty to safeguard the sensitive information entrusted to them. HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) and other regulations outline strict guidelines for handling and protecting PHI.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H2_Text1
data.value: A breach containing healthcare data can have detrimental consequences for both the healthcare organizations and the patients. Healthcare has the highest cost of a data breach among all industries, standing at

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H2_Text2
data.value: Identity Theft: Stolen medical records can be used for fraudulent activities, including obtaining medical services, prescription drugs, or loans under a patient's name. This can lead to significant financial losses and emotional distress for patients.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H2_Text3
data.value: Disruption of Services: Cyberattacks can disrupt healthcare operations, leading to delays in diagnosis, treatments, and appointments. This can have serious consequences for patient care and potentially endanger lives.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H2_Text4
data.value: Financial Loss: Healthcare organizations can face significant financial losses due to data breaches. This includes fines and penalties for non-compliance with regulations, legal fees, costs associated with notifying patients, and potential reputational damage.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H2_Text5
data.value: Reputational Damage:Data breaches can erode patient trust and damage the reputation of healthcare providers. This can lead to loss of business, legal repercussions, and difficulty attracting and retaining qualified healthcare professionals.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H2_Text6
data.value: Discrimination: Sensitive medical information can be used for discrimination in employment, insurance, or other areas of life. This can have a profound impact on a patient's livelihood and well-being.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H2_Text7
data.value: These devastating consequences highlight the critical need for robust data security measures in the healthcare industry. A proactive data security measure such as file encryption can not only protect sensitive healthcare data from attacks but it will also give healthcare organizations and patients a peace of mind for their data.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H3_Text1
data.value: File encryption is a process where contents of a file are transformed into an unreadable and undecipherable format. The process involves using an encryption algorithm, such as AES, along with encryption keys. The encryption keys contain the precise pattern for the algorithm to transform the file’s contents, so that the same keys can be used to reverse the encryption process (decryption) to restore the file’s contents to its original state.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H3_Text2
data.value: File encryption ensures that even if unauthorized individuals gain access to the encrypted healthcare data, they cannot understand or utilize the information, rendering it useless in the hands of cyber attackers.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H3_Text3
data.value: File encryption is inherently different from other file security measures such as password protection, where files are locked with a layer of password and can easily be broken to gain access to the files.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text1
data.value: Watch the Video Tutorial:

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text10
data.value: To permanently decrypt a file, click on the ‘Stop Securing’ icon from the main menu strip on top and select the files that you’d like to decrypt.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text11
data.value: P.S. When you open a file to view or edit, it only creates a temporary decryption process, and any changes made to the file will automatically be re-encrypted.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text12
data.value: AxCrypt can also automatically encrypt and sync files from your Windows to your Google Drive and OneDrive accounts, allowing you to access and edit them on the go on your phone.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text2
data.value: STEP 1: Download and install AxCrypt: https://axcrypt.net/download/

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text3
data.value: STEP 2: Launch AxCrypt and sign in or sign up with your credentials.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text4
data.value: STEP 3: From the menu, go to File > Options and check the ‘Include Subfolders’ option.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text5
data.value: STEP 4: On the main screen, click on the ‘Secured Folders’ tab and right-click to add the desired folder that you would like to automatically encrypt files within.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text6
data.value: STEP 5: Create, modify, add, or drag files to the secured folder and AxCrypt will automatically encrypt them once you click the ‘Cleanup’ button on the top-right or sign out of the application.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text7
data.value: STEP 6: You can open the encrypted files by either double-clicking a file or by clicking on ‘Open Secured’ in the main menu and selecting the file.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text8
data.value: Additionally, set AxCrypt to automatically sign out and encrypt any opened files by going to File > Options > Inactivity Sign Out and selecting the desired duration.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_H4_SH1_Text9
data.value: Your most recent encrypted files will appear on the main screen on the ‘Recent Files’ tab, and will have a file extension of .axx. You can add new folders and subfolders and AxCrypt will automatically encrypt them as well.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_Summary
data.value: Healthcare is one of the top three targeted industries in terms of cyber attacks. The industry also generates around 30% of the world's data volume, with a significant portion containing sensitive patient information. This vast amount of data, often referred to as Protected Health Information (PHI), requires robust security measures to ensure patient privacy and compliance with regulations.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_Text1
data.value: Healthcare is one of the top three targeted industries in terms of cyber attacks. The industry also generates around 30% of the world's data volume, with a significant portion containing sensitive patient information. This vast amount of data, often referred to as Protected Health Information (PHI), requires robust security measures to ensure patient privacy and compliance with regulations.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_Text2
data.value: The exponential increase in the healthcare data also makes it highly vulnerable to malicious cyber attacks and data breaches, which can lead to devastating consequences.

data.name: Blog_HDSHTPMDWE_Title
data.value: Healthcare Data Security 101: How to Protect Medical Data with Encryption

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H1_Text1
data.value: Exploitation of an individual’s interest by a scammer in order to access restricted information. Phishing is by far the most entrenched form of data security breach in this sphere. Due to its nature, the victims of this form of data breach at times have no idea that they are leaving themselves open to exploitation. The way phishing works is that the entity with the intention to access unauthorized information lures the potential victim into thinking that they are engaging with a legitimate online entity; usually via email to access the desired information. The victim, unaware that they are being scammed, end up giving the desired information themselves. To the mind of the victim, they are only giving out desired information to a legitimate online platform. The end result is that the person ends up aiding in the data breach, albeit unknowingly, through accessing malicious links or email attachments.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H10_Text1
data.value: Outsourcing or dealing with contractors whose perspective of data security might be different from that of the organization that is contacting outside vendors. Outsourcing has been known to contribute to cases of data breaches. When vendors have access to information that is deemed sensitive and they themselves do not appreciate its importance, which could lead to serious data leakages.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H2_Text1
data.value: Mail misdelivery is another form of human error that impacts on data security. Misdelivery occurs when those entrusted with the delivery of sensitive information either intentionally or unknowingly end up delivering such information to unauthorized users. In this age of email mass marketing and other forms of massive data transfer, persons handling such transfers are mandated to guarantee the safety of data being sent. The use of encryption in such transfers helps minimize the accessibility of such information should it find its way to unintended recipients.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H3_Text1
data.value: Unauthorized access to information outlets such as company devices. Those entrusted with such devices should treat them with the importance they deserve. It’s not uncommon to find employees with access to such devices allowing unrestricted access to their friends or family members. It’s during those interactions that information can be accessed without the person’s knowledge, leading to a serious breach in data security. The owners of such devices should be trained on the importance of the gadgets in their possession as they are literally the gatekeepers of such sensitive information.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H4_Text1
data.value: Poor password usage can seriously undermine a person’s or corporate data. The accessibility to such information should be password protected. In fact, it’s no longer just about having a password. More is expected, the routine changing of these passwords guarantees that access to such information is restricted. Another way would be to avoid using obvious words for passwords. Individuals entrusted with password requesting devices should avoid sharing such passwords. Corporations should emphasise to their employees the importance of employing proper password management practices to avoid data security breaches.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H5_Text1
data.value: Inadequate or in some cases absence of relevant training on people entrusted with such data. The frequent incorporation of information management systems to members of staff that handle sensitive information minimizes the risk of human error, as members can refer to their training on best practices employed in the handling of such information. The absence of such laid out guidelines and expectations would most definitely expose employees to violations in data security.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H6_Text1
data.value: Little awareness of matters relating to data security. Security has to be emphasized to all members handling company data. Issues on software upgrade that bring about improved security measures are not a management issue alone. Best internet and data handling software should be put to use and the relevant persons educated on their importance and use. Things like data security upgrades should be at the forefront of staff members in conjunction with the relevant Information technology personnel. Data security should be a primary responsibility of all staff members; it’s the absence of such awareness that could lead to data being compromised.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H7_Text1
data.value: Careless or outright incompetence when it comes to data handling. In the daily execution of one’s duties, set out procedures might be overlooked. The need to meet targets and deadlines will most often make people overlook procedures that they consider cumbersome. These shortcuts are sometimes the root course of known data breaches. It’s the responsibility of those charged with management to ensure laid out data handling procedures adhere to irrespective of the workload. In the rush to finish assignments employees who are not keen to details might be responsible for coursing data breaches.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H8_Text1
data.value: Unrestricted data usage is yet another factor that results in data being compromised. The ease with which persons access any or all information should be a subject of scrutiny. By leaving an institution’s data access points manned and the need to apply multiple layers, authentication when accessing or requesting certain data that is considered sensitive is critical in limiting data leakages. The absence of such measures means that anybody with access can retrieve any information they so wish for their personal use. Restriction brings about accountability and traceability, especially when dealing with sensitive information.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_H9_Text1
data.value: The human aspect associated with budget allocation in matters relating to data security is sometimes to blame for data breaches. With management always on the lookout for cost-cutting measures, the need to invest and come up with a sustained approach to a data breach scenario might not be appreciated. This is especially so when the said company has never experienced any data breaches. The failure to allocate funds and invest in data security measures leaves the company vulnerable to data attacks, more so when they are ill prepared when these attacks occur.

data.value: With reported cases on data security violation on the increase, the human aspect in these breaches should be acknowledged and taken into consideration when addressing this issue.

data.value: With reported cases on data security violation on the increase, the human aspect in these breaches should be acknowledged and taken into consideration when addressing this issue.

data.name: Blog_HEIDS_Text2
data.value: It’s a common misconception that the infusion of cyber technology is by itself the main and possibly the only aspect of data protection, thereby ignoring the human element in data management or mismanagement in the event of a data breach.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H1_Text1
data.value: It’s common sense that stronger encryption leads to more protected information. Most of the time, 128-bit encryption is already enough to secure your files. It keeps away brute force attacks and renders most hackers ineffective when trying to access your information.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H1_Text2
data.value: However, some providers offer 256-bit encryption for file encryption, which is the most premium protection available. 256-bit encryption is being utilized to protect confidential and top secret data across the world, and as technology continuously evolves, most sectors would need to consider shifting to stronger encryption methods.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H1_Text3
data.value: Enterprises need to at least acquire an enterprise encryption software with 128-bit encryption so that their documents will not be vulnerable to cyberattacks, but as these threats become more complex and as hackers continue to look for loopholes to breach data, establishments can afford to gain extra peace of mind and security with 256-bit encryption.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H3_Text1
data.value: Smartphones and other mobile devices have been gaining ground during the most recent years. Latest data tallies 3.5 billion smartphone users and 4.8 billion smart and feature phone users across the globe, and while offices remain a preferable environment for employees, some staff members are more comfortable with working on tablets or mobile phones as they live on the go. As such, businesses have gone beyond only using the computer for file management.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H3_Text2
data.value: However, a lot of them still struggle in searching for a solution for safekeeping the data stored and gone across these devices. Threats continue to lurk despite the convenience and with that, potential risks and losses for any organization.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H3_Text3
data.value: Luckily, enterprise encryption software is now readily available in the market, providing organizations guaranteed safety with all their files across any device.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H3_Text4
data.value: The system supplies businesses with features of encryption that can be found in documents housed on a desktop, turning an unwarranted and stressful scenario into a manageable situation and giving you peace of mind during your entire file management process.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H3_Text5
data.value: If this still isn’t enough, your enterprise encryption software can also authenticate the devices being used in your establishment, so you can minimize the risk of infiltration from unwanted users.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H4_Text1
data.value: When discussing file encryption, most companies are led to believe that protection needs to be at its best during distribution and delivery. However, these are just two points in the entire file journey, and any company that wishes to keep up with the times must look at the bigger picture and consider all the stops when it comes to file management. That’s what encryption really is about.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H4_Text2
data.value: Wherever your file is on the pipeline, it won’t be a problem if you use encryption methods available upon purchasing an encryption software. Whether at rest or in motion, you can breathe easy knowing that your organization’s data is protected from possible virtual threats.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H5_Text1
data.value: Since cloud computing revolutionized document management, an increasing number of organizations search for enterprise encryption software that offers cloud encryption solutions to encode information in transit.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H5_Text2
data.value: As data moves from cloud-based platforms and storage to users with access to that information, a strong encryption code is deployed to protect the files from external users that can intercept information as they travel to and from the cloud or when documents are being saved to your cloud’s storage.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H5_Text3
data.value: As an added convenience to their robust features of encryption, some providers oversee encryption for their clients. They’re also open to empowering customers with the option to manage their own encryption keys. If you’re looking for a solution that is focused on cloud encryption, it would be good to check out this list of file sharing and document management software that offers security.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H5_Text4
data.value: Regardless of who facilitates these encryption methods in file management, the best file encryption software in the market ensures solid protection through multi-factor identification and secure backup in case of any encountered failures.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H6_Text1
data.value: When managing documents, it’s obvious that file encryption has begun to play a major role in enterprises regardless of industry or size. On a final note, you should consider concentrating on this aspect so that your files are not only organized and easily accessible but also safe from threats that lurk in the virtual realm

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_H6_Text2
data.value: You can start by looking for an encryption software that possesses solid encryption methods that align with your business demands.

data.value: You’re on a battlefield against online threats that can affect your organization. The enemy you’re fighting is good old computer virus.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_Text1
data.value: File encryption software is on the frontlines protecting your establishment’s sensitive information should a data breach occur. Your platform serves as the only and final line of defense that stops cybercriminals from using data that could crush your company to smithereens and ruin everything that you’ve built.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_Text2
data.value: On a surface level, an enterprise encryption software protects information transferred between parties by transforming the data into code that can only be deciphered by authorized users. With a reliable platform, users can rest easy knowing that their information is safe regardless of how sensitive it is and regardless of where it’s housed.

data.name: Blog_HFMICTETP_Text3
data.value: This capability of file encryption software is changing the file management game, since it enhances document security by protecting data from prying eyes, eavesdropping users, cybercriminals and stealthy organizations.

data.name: Blog_HOA_H1_Text1
data.value: ZV: File encryption! Our vision: security, reliability, and simplicity. Everything we make is done with these as the highest priority. Our file encryption software is available for free, and we add another layer of features in AxCrypt Premium and Business. This includes a password manager and key sharing.

data.name: Blog_HOA_H2_Text2
data.value: ZV: We have many private individuals that use AxCrypt. As for businesses, we see mainly financial services, governmental institutions (administration, education, health care), and IT companies.

data.name: Blog_HOA_H3_Text3
data.value: ZV: Ransomware has seen a huge increase over the last few years, probably in part due to companies getting better at securing their data. The problem is that in ransomware attacks, keeping your data encrypted is not enough. It’s more important than ever to make sure you have recent backups of all of your important data, and that these backups are stored in separate locations, so an attacker can never get to both your live data and backups.

data.name: Blog_HOA_H4_Text1
data.value: ZV: More and more of our society is connected, but it will be even more so in the future. The Internet of Things (IoT) has been a topic for the last decade, but it has yet to really make an impact. When this impact comes, it means every household will have numerous connected devices, some of which you might not even realize is connected and hence very poorly protected. More poorly protected devices mean more attack vectors which can be used for a whole multitude of malicious intents.

data.name: Blog_HPDYMP_Conclusion_Text1
data.value: Phone encryption is not a new concept in the mobile business, and it has become an unavoidable element of the design process for all smartphone makers. Mobile encryption can accomplish everything for you, from preventing your data from being stolen to keeping your personal information safe. Now that you understand the need for encrypted data, encrypt all of your mobile devices to protect your data from unauthorized access.

data.name: Blog_HPDYMP_H1_Text1
data.value: Mobile phones have become an integral part of our daily lives. They have become the main target for hackers as a result of the global pandemic and the rise in remote work. There are many undiscovered risks out there attempting to get private data on your mobile device. When it comes to the information stored on a phone, many people underestimate its true worth. Your phone contains all of your personal information while acting as a data bank and a social media hub.

data.name: Blog_HPDYMP_H1_Text2
data.value: Mobile security is a precautionary measure used to safeguard data against a variety of threats aimed to invade privacy and steal any other information kept on the phone. These data assaults are aimed towards stealing personal information, such as bank account numbers, login credentials, and other information. Make no mistake about a hacker's abilities. Hackers have a simple way of manipulating or stealing your phone's data. Hacking isn't necessarily limited to collecting usernames and passwords or sending out phishing emails.

data.name: Blog_HPDYMP_H2_Text1
data.value: Identity theft, fraud, and the theft of financial resources from employees and consumers are all possible outcomes of unprotected data. Every year, 4.3% of company-issued smartphones are lost or stolen. On average, roughly 10,573 mobile breaches occur per day. Large, small, public, and private enterprises all experience data breaches. In fact, hackers are increasingly targeting small and mid-sized organizations since their networks are less secure.

data.name: Blog_HPDYMP_H2_Text2
data.value: Hackers now have the ability to listen in on chats and hack into any data on your phone. Without your permission, your social media accounts, bank accounts, sensitive images, private text messages, and more could be accessed.

data.name: Blog_HPDYMP_H3_Text1
data.value: Perhaps the simplest approach to keep your phone safe from unauthorized is using a passcode. But that isn't enough; cracking someone's passcode is no longer rocket science. Mobile data encryption is one of the best ways to protect your sensitive information on a phone, even while you are on the go. AxCrypt Mobile encryption is beyond a regular lock screen password. It is a one-stop for safeguarding all of your personal information and data on your mobile phones from prying eyes. It does so by storing your phone's information in an unreadable, jumbled format that can only be read with the correct credentials. With mobile encryption, you can be certain that your data is protected even if your device is lost or stolen. AxCrypt protects your phone's data using 256-bit AES encryption and other advanced features. You can secure your data on Google Drive Files and Dropbox on your iOS and Android devices with the AxCrypt mobile encryption.

data.name: Blog_HPDYMP_H3_Text2
data.value: Try a one-month free trial on Android or iOS.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H1_Text1
data.value: 'Scientia potentia est' originating from Latin, meaning knowledge is power, is a relevant aphorism that can be associated with today's world. This dictum is now truer than ever, as a result of rapid advances in information technology.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H1_Text2
data.value: Furthermore, we want to continue ensuring and raising awareness around encryption and cyber security, and therefore we are glad to share some information on how to protect yourself and your business from cyber threats.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H2_Text1
data.value: In simple terms, a cyber attack is an assault launched by cybercriminals using one or more computers against a single or multiple computers or networks. A cyber attack can maliciously disable computers, steal data, or use a breached computer as a launch point for other attacks in order to expose, alter, disable, destroy, steal or gain information through unauthorized access to or make unauthorized use of an asset. A cyberattack may steal, alter, or destroy a specified target by hacking into a susceptible system. Cybercriminals use a variety of methods to launch a cyber attack, including malware, phishing, ransomware, denial of service, among other methods.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H3_Text1
data.value: • Malware

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H3_Text2
data.value: • Phishing

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H3_Text3
data.value: • Ransomware

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H3_Text4
data.value: • Denial of service

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H3_Text5
data.value: • Man in the middle

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H3_Text6
data.value: • Cryptojacking

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H3_Text7
data.value: • SQL injection

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H3_Text8
data.value: • Zero-day exploits

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H4_Text1
data.value: A cyberattack occurs when cybercriminals try to gain illegal access to electronic data stored on a computer or a network. The intent might be to inflict reputational damage or harm to a business or person, or theft of valuable data. Cyberattacks can target individuals, groups, organizations, or governments.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H4_Text2
data.value: A data breach is a type of security incident. It occurs when information is accessed without authorization. The information accessed could include personal information such as Social Security numbers, passwords, and financial account numbers.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H5_SH1_Text1
data.value: Using strong passwords is one way to protect your information online, so avoid using the same, easy-to-crack passwords, no matter how much you love your pet. Adopt symbols, numbers and different figures so no one can guess it by knowing personal information about you. You can also use the AxCrypt Password Generator that produces strong passwords that are not nonsensical and actually possible to remember and type. You'll get three suggestions of decreasing strength and complexity.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H5_SH2_Text1
data.value: Encryption is a way to make communications that are intended to be private actually remain private. It will help protect customers' data and anticipate threats. By encrypting your data and making it unreadable you guarantee security and productivity. Even if intercepted, the message will be unreadable for any actor that doesn't possess the right key to decrypt it.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H5_SH3_Text1
data.value: Backing up your business's data and website will help you recover any information you lose if you experience a cyber incident or have computer issues. It's essential that you backup your most important data and information regularly.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H5_SH3_Text2
data.value: Ensure you use multi-factor authentication (MFA). MFA is a verification security process that requires you to provide two or more proofs of your identity before you can access your account. For example, a system will require a password and a code sent to your mobile device before access is granted. Multi-factor authentication adds an additional layer of security to make it harder for attackers to gain access to your device or online accounts.

data.name: Blog_HPYBFC_H5_SH4_Text1
data.value: Train every new employee to protect valuable data and have them sign your information policy. Use newsletters and/or ongoing training to reinforce your culture of cybersecurity. Raise cyber security awareness among the staff and teach them how to access data in the best, secure way on every device. They should know the risks of using data with an unsecure network. That can save the company from a massive loss in the years to come. Your business is only as secure as its weakest link.

data.value: Secure your hardware

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text1
data.value: Before we dive deeper into details of password authentication and password cracking methods, let’s first look at some stats and understand how they impact the way you generate, use, and save new passwords.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text10
data.value: 9.Over 80% of users admit to reusing passwords across multiple accounts.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text11
data.value: 10.In 2022, there were over 2.29 billion global records exposed in data breaches.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text12
data.value: 11.Phishing is the most common tactic used by hackers to obtain passwords.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text13
data.value: 12.Brute force attacks are responsible for approximately 5% of successful data breaches. Brute force attack is a trial-and-error method used by hackers to guess a password by systematically checking all possible combinations of characters until the correct one is found. The checking is done using automated tools or a coding script written by hackers.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text2
data.value: 1.In 2022,“123456” was the most commonly used password, followed by “123456789” and “password”.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text3
data.value: 2.A recent survey showed that only 53% of people use different passwords for different accounts, leaving the rest vulnerable to potential hacks.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text4
data.value: 3.The average user has 26 password protected accounts.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text5
data.value: 4.Approximately 10% of internet users have used “123456” as their password.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text6
data.value: 5.A six-character password containing only lowercase letters can be cracked in less than 10 minutes.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text7
data.value: 6.A 12-character password containing uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols can take over 1,000 years to crack.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text8
data.value: 7.The most common password length is 8 characters.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H1_Text9
data.value: 8.Approximately 81% of data breaches are due to weak or stolen passwords.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H2_Text1
data.value: When you log in to a website or application, the password authentication process begins. You enter your username or email address and password, and the website or app checks this information against a database of user credentials.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H2_Text2
data.value: The password you enter is usually encrypted using a mathematical algorithm, such as SHA-256 or AES-256, which scrambles your password into a unique string of characters that cannot be easily reversed or deciphered. This encrypted version of your password is stored in the website or app's database, along with your username or email address.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H2_Text3
data.value: During the account creation process, the password is first hashed (converted) using a one-way function that transforms the password into a unique string of characters. The resulting hash is then stored in the system's database. The next time the user tries to log in, the password they provide is hashed again and compared to the stored hash. If the two hashes match, the user is authenticated and granted access to the system.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H2_Text4
data.value: To ensure the security of the password, it is essential to hash the password before storing it in the system's database. Hashing ensures that the password is not saved in plain text, making it difficult for attackers to read and use the password if they gain access to the system's database.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H2_Text5
data.value: Moreover, many systems incorporate additional security measures like salting, which adds a random string of characters to the password before hashing. Salting ensures that attackers cannot use precomputed hashes of commonly used passwords to easily crack the password, adding another layer of security.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H2_Text6
data.value: When you try to log in again, the website or app will re-encrypt the password you enter and compare it to the encrypted version stored in the database. If the two versions match, you are granted access to the site or app. This process ensures that only authorized users with the correct password can access their accounts.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H2_Text7
data.value: Password authentication is not always fool proof. Passwords can be stolen or guessed by attackers using various methods, such as brute-force attacks or social engineering. As a result, it is essential to follow password best practices, such as using a long and complex password, using unique passwords for each account, and changing passwords frequently.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H3_Text1
data.value: Hackers use various methods and algorithms to crack passwords, including brute force attacks and social engineering techniques like phishing. Let’s explore some of the most commonly used techniques for password cracking.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H3_Text2
data.value: Brute Force Attack: The most basic algorithm of cracking a password is known as a brute force attack. This method involves using a program to guess every possible combination of characters until the correct password is found. While this may seem like a time-consuming and tedious process, modern computers are incredibly fast and can guess millions of password combinations per second.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H3_Text3
data.value: Dictionary Attack: Another method used to crack passwords is the dictionary attack. In this method, the attacker uses a program that has a pre-existing list of commonly used passwords and tries them one by one until the correct password is found. This list of passwords is known as a password dictionary and can be created by the attacker or downloaded from the internet.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H3_Text4
data.value: Phishing: Phishing is a social engineering attack that involves tricking a user into revealing their password. Attackers create fake login pages that look identical to the real ones and send the user a link to the fake page. When the user enters their password, the attacker captures it and can use it to gain access to the user's account.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H3_Text5
data.value: Keystroke Logging: Keystroke logging involves installing a program on a victim's computer that records every keystroke made by the user, including their password. Attackers can then retrieve the recorded keystrokes and use them to gain access to the victim's account.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H3_Text6
data.value: Shoulder Surfing: Shoulder surfing involves physically watching a user enter their password. Attackers can do this by standing close to the victim or using a hidden camera to record the user's keystrokes. Once the password is captured, the attacker can use it to gain access to the user's account.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H3_Text7
data.value: Each technique has its own strengths and weaknesses, and hackers very cleverly utilize each of it to prepare and execute the attack. As a result, it is crucial to have a comprehensive approach to password protection to ensure that your credentials are secure from hacking attempt

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H4_Text1
data.value: To ensure the security of your passwords and protect them from malicious attacks by hackers, there are several methods, tips, and best practices that can be employed. By implementing the appropriate methods and techniques, you can ensure that your passwords remain safe and secure at all times. Some of the best methods you can use are:

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H4_Text2
data.value: Complex Passwords: One of the simplest ways to protect your passwords is to use strong and complex passwords. Passwords should be at least eight characters long and should include a combination of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols. A strong password makes it more difficult for hackers to crack your password using brute-force attacks.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H4_Text3
data.value: For example, a password like “X@xg0n$&p1E” would take billions of years to be cracked using brute force even with the fastest computers available today. You can use a password generator like AxCrypt’s Password Manager to automatically generate and save complex passwords.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H4_Text4
data.value: Password Managers: A password manager is a tool that generates and stores complex passwords for all your online accounts. It stores your passwords in an encrypted database, and you only need to remember one master password to access all your passwords. This method of password protection helps to ensure that you don't use the same password for multiple accounts, which reduces the risk of a password breach.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H4_Text5
data.value: Two-Factor Authentication (2FA): Two-factor authentication adds an extra layer of security to your account. It requires you to enter a verification code in addition to your password to log into your account. The verification code can be sent to your phone via text message, email, or an authenticator app. This method of authentication helps to ensure that only the authorized user has access to the account.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H4_Text6
data.value: Biometric Authentication: Biometric authentication uses unique biological characteristics such as fingerprints, facial recognition, or iris scans to identify users. This method of authentication is more secure than passwords since it's difficult for hackers to fake biometric data. Biometric authentication is increasingly being used in mobile devices and laptops to improve security.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H4_Text7
data.value: Password-less Authentication: Password-less authentication is a new trend in password protection. It replaces the traditional password with other forms of authentication such as biometrics, security tokens, or one-time passwords.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H4_Text8
data.value: This method of authentication is more secure since it eliminates the risk of password theft and password reuse.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H4_Text9
data.value: Apart from these methods, one more highly effective password protection practice is to change your password frequently. This is because the longer you use a password, the higher the chances are that it may get compromised. Regularly changing your password ensures that even if a hacker gains access to it, they won't be able to use it for long before it becomes invalid.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H5_Text1
data.value: A password manager is a software application that helps users generate, store, and manage passwords securely. It’s a tool that can be used to create unique, complex passwords for each of your online accounts and store them in a secure vault. The benefits of using a password manager are numerous, but the primary advantage is that it makes it easier to create and remember strong passwords.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H5_Text2
data.value: Using a password manager can also improve the overall security of your online accounts. Since many people tend to use the same password across multiple accounts, if one password is compromised, it can lead to a domino effect of security breaches across all your other accounts. With a password manager, you can ensure that each account has a unique and complex password, which greatly reduces the risk of a data breach.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H5_Text3
data.value: Another advantage of using a password manager is that it can save you a lot of time. Remembering multiple passwords can be difficult, and having to reset them frequently can be frustrating. With a password manager, you only need to remember one master password to access all of your other passwords. This not only saves you time, but it also reduces the chances of forgetting your password and being locked out of your account.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H5_Text4
data.value: Opting for a password manager is a wise decision that can provide you with peace of mind. With its simple yet effective approach, you can secure your online accounts and steer clear of the stress and financial loss that often accompany data breaches. By taking proactive measures to safeguard your personal information, you can rest assured that your online accounts are well protected, and your sensitive data is safe from prying eyes.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H6_Conclusion_Text1
data.value: If you're looking for a password manager that offers top-notch security, AxCrypt is an excellent option to consider. With its AES 256 encryption, you can rest assured that your sensitive information is well-protected. Additionally, AxCrypt's password generator feature can help you create complex and unique passwords for each of your online accounts, making it more difficult for hackers to gain access to your personal data.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H6_Conclusion_Text2
data.value: AxCrypt's Password Manager comes with credential syncing capability. This means that you can access your saved passwords and login information across multiple devices, making it more convenient to manage your online accounts. Whether you're on your computer or your phone, you can easily retrieve your login information without having to remember all of your passwords.

data.name: Blog_HQHCYP_H6_Conclusion_Text3
data.value: AxCrypt’s password manager is a great choice for those who prioritize security and convenience. With its advanced encryption, password generator, and credential syncing features, you can feel confident that your online accounts are well-protected from potential cyber-attacks.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H1_SH1_Text1
data.value: Encryption methods essentially can be divided into two categories: symmetric and asymmetric. Symmetric encryption uses the same secret key for both encryption and decryption of the data. The same key is shared between the sender and receiver of the encrypted data.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H1_SH1_Text2
data.value: Asymmetric encryption, on the other hand, involves two keys: a public key and a private key. The public key is used to encrypt the data, while the private key is used to decrypt it. This approach ensures that only the intended recipient, who has the private key, can decrypt the data.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H1_SH1_Text3
data.value: Although asymmetric encryption is often deemed more secure than symmetric encryption, it can be slower and more resource-intensive.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H1_SH1_Text4
data.value: Different encryption algorithms have been devised based on the symmetric and asymmetric methods, and in this blog, we will discuss the three most popular ones: AES, 3DES, and RSA.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H1_SubHeading1
data.value: Types of Encryption Methods:

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H1_Text1
data.value: Encryption is a process of converting the plain text into an illegible text known as ciphertext. A computing device does this by running the text through one of the encryption algorithms, such as AES, to randomly rearrange and scramble the given text – making it impossible to read during the transmission.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H1_Text2
data.value: The rearrangement of text is backed by very intricate mathematical calculations known as a ‘key’, and the same mathematical calculations used for encryption are reversed to decrypt the text, allowing only the authorized individuals to access the original plain text.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SH1_Text1
data.value: The AES encryption algorithm, also known as Rijndael, is a popular symmetric encryption algorithm used to protect data. AES algorithm has key lengths of 128, 192, or 256 bits, which means it can convert a 128, 192, or 256 bits of text blocks at once.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SH1_Text2
data.value: AES operates on the Substitution–Permutation Network (SPN), using a combination of substitution and permutation rounds to cipher the text. Which means, the plaintext data is first broken into blocks or chunks, then substituted (replaced) and permutated (scrambled) over the course of several rounds using complex calculation, making the resulted ciphertext practically impossible to decipher.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SH1_Text3
data.value: The encryption process involves several sub-processes, including sub bytes, shift rows, mix columns, and add round keys. During the process, the text is scrabbled in multiple rounds. The number of rounds performed depends on the size of the key, which for AES is 10, 12, or 14 rounds.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SH2_Text1
data.value: The 3DES encryption algorithm is an upgrade to the DES or Data Encryption Standard algorithm, that applies the DES algorithm thrice to each data block. This process made 3DES much harder to crack than its predecessor, and it became widely used in payment systems, standards, and technology in the finance industry.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SH2_Text2
data.value: However, the Sweet32 vulnerability exposed the security holes within 3DES. In response, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) announced the deprecation of 3DES in a draft guidance published in 2019. The use of 3DES is set to be scrapped and discontinued in all new applications after 2023.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SH3_Text1
data.value: RSA is an asymmetric encryption algorithm developed by Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir, and Leonard Adleman in 1977. It is widely used in many applications, including SSL/TLS certificates, crypto-currencies, and email encryption.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SH3_Text2
data.value: RSA's potency lies in the “prime factorization” method that it relies upon, where two huge random prime numbers are multiplied to create another giant number. The puzzle is to determine the original prime numbers from this giant-sized multiplied number. The difficulty of brute-forcing the key increases with each expanding key length, and RSA offers various encryption key lengths such as 768-bit, 1024-bit, 2048-bit, 4096-bit, etc

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SubHeading1
data.value: AES or Advanced Encryption Standard

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SubHeading2
data.value: 3DES or Triple DES or Triple Data Encryption

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H2_SubHeading3
data.value: RSA

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H3_Text1
data.value: Overall, AES is considered safe, fast, and flexible, making it the most widely used encryption algorithm today. AES is used in many applications, including wireless security, processor security and file encryption, SSL/TLS protocol (website security), Wi-Fi security, mobile app encryption, and most VPNs.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H3_Text2
data.value: Many government agencies, including the National Security Agency (NSA), rely on the AES encryption algorithm to protect their sensitive information. On the other hand, 3DES has been deprecated due to security vulnerabilities, while RSA's scalability and security make it the most widely used asymmetric encryption algorithm.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H3_Text3
data.value: AxCrypt utilizes the strong AES-256-bit algorithm to encrypt and decrypt data. Our intuitive and powerful standalone encryption software can encrypt data on desktops, smartphones and tablets. It can also automatically integrate and encrypt data on several cloud services such as Google Drive, Dropbox, and iCloud.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_H3_Text4
data.value: You can easily share files with others using our unique key sharing feature, which can be used to precisely share and control who sees and uses the file. AxCrypt also comes with a built-in secure password manager and password generator, which can be used to encrypt your sensitive credentials.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_Main_Heading1
data.value: Why Encryption is Essential for Your Data?

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_Main_Text1
data.value: When it comes to cyber security, encryption is one of the most critical components of a strong data protection strategy; yet many businesses and individuals tend to overlook the significance that a robust encryption method renders. With data breaches on the rise, safeguarding your sensitive data should not only be a priority, but a systematic practice that ensures that data is protected on every step of the way.

data.name: Blog_HREAYSD_Main_Text2
data.value: According to the IBM’s ‘Cost of a data breach 2022’ report, an average data breach costs organizations a whopping $4.35M with 83% of studied organizations experiencing more than one data breach in their lifetime. Prioritising encryption for your data can not only benefit you in the long run, but it can also instil a sense of security and confidence.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_Conclusion_Text1
data.value: Cybersecurity is now more important than ever. As small to medium-sized businesses increasingly rely on the internet for everything from services to customer feedback, they become prime targets for cyberattacks. It's essential for these businesses to recognize the risks and take proactive steps to protect themselves. By raising awareness among employees and implementing strong security measures, companies can create a solid defense against cyber threats.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_Conclusion_Text2
data.value: Think of AxCrypt not just as encryption software, but as your first line of defense. Start your free trial today and explore its powerful features.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H1_Text1
data.value: It may seem like large corporations with vast amounts of data would be the main targets of cybercriminals, but small businesses are often seen as low-hanging fruit. Why? Here are a few reasons:

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H1_Text2
data.value: 1. Limited Resources: SMBs typically don’t have the same budget or dedicated cybersecurity teams as larger corporations, making it harder for them to invest in comprehensive security measures.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H1_Text3
data.value: 2. Lack of Cyber Expertise: Many small businesses don’t have in-house experts who can identify, investigate, or respond to cyber threats effectively.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H1_Text4
data.value: 3. Valuable Data: Despite their size, SMBs store sensitive information—like customer data, intellectual property, and financial records—which is valuable to hackers.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H1_Text5
data.value: 4. Supply Chain Vulnerabilities: Small businesses are often part of larger supply chains. A breach in one SMB can compromise an entire network, making them an appealing entry point for cybercriminals.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H2_Text1
data.value: Cybercriminals use a variety of tactics to breach small businesses. Here are a few of the most common methods:

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H2_Text2
data.value: • Phishing Attacks: These involve emails that look legitimate but are designed to trick employees into clicking on malicious links or providing sensitive information.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H2_Text3
data.value: • Trojans: Malware that disguises itself as a legitimate program, giving hackers access to your systems and data once it’s downloaded.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H2_Text4
data.value: • Ransomware: Hackers use ransomware to lock down your data and demand payment in exchange for its release.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H2_Text5
data.value: • Credential Theft: Cybercriminals steal usernames and passwords to gain access to accounts, often through weak password policies or data leaks.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H2_Text6
data.value: • Wi-Fi Vulnerabilities: If employees connect to insecure public Wi-Fi, hackers can easily intercept their data and gain access to business networks.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H2_Text7
data.value: With attacks happening so frequently, the question isn’t if your business will be targeted, but when.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H3_Text1
data.value: While having cybersecurity insurance can provide some peace of mind, it’s not a catch-all solution. Cyber insurance can help cover the costs associated with a breach, such as legal fees, fines, and recovery expenses, but it won’t prevent an attack from happening in the first place. In fact, if your business doesn’t have adequate security measures in place, you may face higher premiums or even be denied coverage.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H3_Text2
data.value: This is why it’s essential to pair insurance with proactive cybersecurity practices. Prevention is always better than trying to recover from a devastating attack.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H4_Text1
data.value: Employees are often the first line of defense in preventing cyberattacks. They should be educated about safe online practices, but it’s a team effort. Here’s how employees and businesses can work together:

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H4_Text2
data.value: • Employee Education: Regular training on identifying phishing attempts, creating strong passwords, and using secure communication channels is crucial. Encourage employees to report suspicious activity without fear of repercussions.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H4_Text3
data.value: • Simulated Phishing Tests: Test your employees by sending fake phishing emails to see how they respond. This can help identify gaps in awareness and provide an opportunity for additional training.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H4_Text4
data.value: • Secure Devices: Make sure employees use company-approved devices for work, and implement strong security policies like multi-factor authentication and VPNs for remote access.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H4_Text5
data.value: • Cybersecurity Newsletters: Regular updates through emails or internal newsletters keep cybersecurity top of mind for employees, helping to reinforce good practices.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H5_Text1
data.value: From a business owner or IT manager's perspective, having a robust cybersecurity plan is key. Here are a few steps you can take to ensure your business is protected:

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H5_Text2
data.value: • Develop an Incident Response Plan: In the event of an attack, having a clear incident response plan will help minimize damage and get your systems back online faster. Include procedures for communication if traditional channels are compromised.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H5_Text3
data.value: • Invest in Security Software: Use reputable security software to protect your systems from malware and unauthorized access. Update it regularly to stay ahead of emerging threats.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H5_Text4
data.value: • Regular Backups: Back up your data regularly and store it securely. This will help you recover your data without paying a ransom if you fall victim to ransomware.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H5_Text5
data.value: • Use Strong Password Policies: Implement company-wide password policies that encourage the use of complex passwords and frequent updates. Consider using a password manager to store passwords securely.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H5_Text6
data.value: • Monitor for Suspicious Activity: Regularly monitor your network for unusual behavior that could indicate a cyberattack. Having real-time alerts in place can help you respond quickly.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text1
data.value: Now that you understand the risks and how to prepare for them, let’s talk about how AxCrypt, an encryption software, can enhance your cybersecurity strategy.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text10
data.value: 8. Priority Support: As a business user, you’ll receive priority support from AxCrypt, ensuring that any issues are resolved quickly to minimize downtime.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text2
data.value: Encryption is one of the best ways to protect sensitive business data, and AxCrypt offers a range of features to help small and medium businesses stay secure.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text3
data.value: 1. Strong Encryption: AxCrypt uses AES-256 encryption, one of the most secure encryption standards available today. This ensures that even if your data falls into the wrong hands, it’s unreadable without the encryption key.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text4
data.value: 2. Centralized Key Management: Managing encryption keys across your organization is simplified with AxCrypt’s centralized key management. You can easily manage permissions, ensuring that only authorized employees have access to certain data.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text5
data.value: 3. Group Key Sharing: Need to share encrypted files with your team? AxCrypt’s group key sharing feature makes this easy and secure, ensuring only the right people have access to sensitive information.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text6
data.value: 4. Master Key Access: Worried about losing access to important files if an employee leaves or forgets their password? With AxCrypt’s Master Key feature, administrators can still access encrypted files, ensuring critical data isn’t lost.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text7
data.value: 5. Cloud Storage Integration: If you use cloud storage services like Dropbox, Google Drive, or OneDrive, AxCrypt integrates seamlessly to automatically encrypt your files, giving you peace of mind that your cloud data is also secure.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text8
data.value: 6. User-Friendly Interface: You don’t need to be a tech expert to use AxCrypt. Its intuitive interface makes encryption as simple as a few clicks, making it accessible to all employees, no matter their tech skills.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_H6_Text9
data.value: 7. Mobile Encryption: Work on the go? AxCrypt offers mobile encryption for iOS and Android devices, so your data is protected even when you’re not in the office.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_Text1
data.value: It is high time to bring attention to one of the most pressing issues businesses face today- cyber threats. Small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) are increasingly targeted by cybercriminals, and the statistics are alarming. Here are a few:

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_Text2
data.value: • Almost 43% of cyberattacks target small and medium businesses—a reminder of just how important tools like endpoint protection and network monitoring are to detect threats early.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_Text3
data.value: • A surprising 96% of SMBs struggle to investigate suspicious alerts, which makes them even more vulnerable. Streamlined alerts and automated responses can make a real difference here.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_Text4
data.value: • Nearly 60% of small businesses close within 6 months of an attack. Having a solid recovery and backup plan is key to staying resilient against both financial and reputational damage.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_Text5
data.value: • Cyberattacks happen over 2,200 times a day—every 39 seconds. This pace highlights why continuous monitoring is essential to staying ahead of potential risks.

data.name: Blog_HSBCPTFGCT_Text6
data.value: With these facts in mind, let’s understand why SMBs are prime targets for cyberattacks and, more importantly, how they can protect themselves.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H1_Text1

With data breaches on the rise, safeguarding your sensitive data should not only be a priority, but a systematic practice that ensures that data is protected on every step of the way.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H1_Text2
data.value: According to IBM's ‘Cost of a data breach 2022’ report, an average data breach costs organizations a whopping $4.35M with 83% of studied organizations experiencing more than one data breach in their lifetime. Prioritizing encryption for your data can not only benefit you in the long run, but it can also instill a sense of security and confidence.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H2_Text1
data.value: Encryption is the process of converting readable information (plain text) into an unreadable format (ciphertext), ensuring it remains secure during transmission or storage. This is achieved through complex algorithms that scramble the data, making it impossible to interpret without the correct decryption key.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H2_Text2
data.value: AxCrypt employs the AES-256 encryption algorithm, a trusted method used by governments and organizations worldwide. With AxCrypt, your files remain secure, whether they’re stored on your device or shared with others, preventing unauthorized access at every level.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H3_Text1
data.value: Encryption methods generally fall into two categories: symmetric and asymmetric encryption. Each serves different purposes, and understanding their distinctions is key to choosing the right solution.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H3_Text2
data.value: • Symmetric encryption uses a single key for both encryption and decryption. While fast and efficient, the challenge lies in securely sharing the key between parties.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H3_Text3
data.value: • Asymmetric encryption involves two keys: a public key to encrypt the data and a private key to decrypt it. This adds an extra layer of security, as only the intended recipient can decrypt the information. Although more secure, this method is slower and more resource-intensive.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H4_Text1
data.value: Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H4_Text2
data.value: AES, widely known as Rijndael, is the go-to symmetric encryption algorithm used across multiple industries. Its key lengths—128, 192, or 256 bits—provide strong security for any data type. AES operates on a sophisticated Substitution-Permutation Network, which makes breaking it computationally infeasible.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H4_Text3
data.value: Triple DES (3DES)

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H4_Text4
data.value: 3DES is an enhancement of the original DES (Data Encryption Standard) algorithm, applying it three times to each data block. While 3DES improved upon its predecessor, it was eventually found vulnerable to modern attacks. The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has deprecated 3DES, and its use in new systems is being phased out.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H4_Text5
data.value: RSA

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H4_Text6
data.value: RSA is an asymmetric encryption algorithm, named after its inventors (Rivest, Shamir, and Adleman). It’s widely used in securing communications, such as SSL/TLS for web security, email encryption, and even cryptocurrencies. RSA works by generating large prime numbers to create a cryptographic key, offering multiple levels of encryption strength.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H5_Text1
data.value: AxCrypt employs symmetric encryption for simple, efficient protection. This method uses a single key for both encryption and decryption, providing strong security while allowing easy access to your files.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H5_Text2
data.value: For secure file sharing, AxCrypt integrates asymmetric encryption, which utilizes two keys: a public key for encrypting files and a private key for decryption. This ensures that only the intended recipient can access the data, adding an extra layer of security when sharing sensitive information.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H5_Text3
data.value: Key Management for Advanced Protection

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H5_Text4
data.value: AxCrypt incorporates a sophisticated key management system to streamline the encryption process and improve security. Each encrypted file gets a unique encryption key, also known as a session key. This session key is securely stored and only accessible to authorized users. When files are shared, the session key is encrypted and distributed to selected recipients, ensuring that unauthorized individuals cannot gain access to the file, even if they obtain a copy.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H6_Text1
data.value: AxCrypt sets itself apart by offering a comprehensive, user-friendly encryption platform designed for modern-day file security needs. Here’s why AxCrypt is the best choice for encrypting your sensitive data:

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H6_Text2
data.value: • AES-256 Encryption: AxCrypt uses the highest level of encryption available, ensuring that your data is protected with military-grade security.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H6_Text3
data.value: • Cross-Device Compatibility: Our software seamlessly encrypts files on desktops, smartphones, and tablets, ensuring your data stays protected no matter which device you use.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H6_Text4
data.value: • Cloud Integration: AxCrypt integrates effortlessly with cloud services like Google Drive, Dropbox, and iCloud, providing encryption without disrupting your workflow.

data.name: Blog_HTCTREFYSD_H6_Text5
data.value: • Key Sharing: AxCrypt allows you to securely share encrypted files with specific individuals using our intuitive key-sharing feature. This way, you control exactly who can access your files.
