data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H1_Text1
data.value: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) is a United State’s federal law that mandates creation of rules to prevent unauthorized disclosure of sensitive healthcare data – without a patient's consent.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H1_Text2
data.value: Enacted in 1996, HIPAA is regulated by the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and enforced by the Office for Civil Rights (OCR). HIPAA’s protection covers protected health information (PHI), which includes any data that can be used to identify an individual within the course of a healthcare journey.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H1_Text3
data.value: PHI encompasses a wide range of data, including medical records, patient histories, laboratory test results, and billing information. Additionally, HIPAA safeguards other identifying information such as names, addresses, social security numbers, and even IP addresses if they are associated with health information.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H2_Text1
data.value: Encryption, particularly in file security, transforms data into an unreadable format using complex algorithms and cryptographic keys. The original data, called plaintext, becomes ciphertext after encryption, and decryption reverses this process.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H2_Text2
data.value: During encryption, the algorithm rearranges and alters the data, guided by cryptographic keys, to create a scrambled version that can be restored to its original state through decryption.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H2_Text3
data.value: This method differs from simple password protection, which only secures data with a password, leaving it vulnerable to unauthorized access. Encryption, however, renders data indecipherable without the decryption key, providing robust protection even if data is leaked or accessed without authorization.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H2_Text4
data.value: In healthcare, where safeguarding sensitive patient information is crucial under HIPAA regulations, encryption serves as a vital tool to ensure data security. It acts like a secret code, scrambling data to prevent unauthorized access, unlike password protection, which can be easily bypassed with the right tools.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH1_Text1
data.value: • Identify ePHI: ☑️ Determine where all your organization's electronic Protected Health Information (ePHI) resides (servers, laptops, mobile devices, etc.).

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH1_Text2
data.value: • Protected Health Information (PHI): Any information that can be used to identify an individual and relates to their past, present or future physical or mental health condition, provision of healthcare services, or payment for the provision of healthcare services.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH1_Text3
data.value: • Threat Assessment: ☑️ Identify potential risks to ePHI, such as unauthorized access, data breaches, and cyberattacks.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH1_Text4
data.value: • Vulnerability Assessment: ☑️ Evaluate the weaknesses in your current security measures that could allow these threats to materialize.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH2_Text1
data.value: • Encryption Selection: ☑️ Choose a strong encryption algorithm, such as Advanced Encryption Standard AES 256-bit, following recommendations from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). We recommend using AxCrypt, a simple and easy-to-use file encryption software that utilizes AES 256-bit encryption to safeguard your data.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH2_Text2
data.value: • Data at Rest: ☑️ Implement encryption for all ePHI stored electronically, including databases, servers, and portable devices. AxCrypt allows you to encrypt individual files within folders automatically on your devices, adding an extra layer of security for sensitive patient information.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH2_Text3
data.value: • Data in Transit: ☑️ Use secure protocols like TLS (Transport Layer Security) or VPNs (Virtual Private Networks) to encrypt ePHI whenever it's transmitted electronically. While AxCrypt encrypts data at rest, ensure you have additional safeguards like TLS enabled for secure transmission during emails or file transfers.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH2_Text4
data.value: • Email Encryption: ☑️ Consider implementing a separate email encryption solution for sensitive communications containing ePHI. AxCrypt allows encrypted sharing of files via email with just a click.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH3_Text1
data.value: • Key Security: ☑️ Develop and document secure procedures for generating, storing, managing, and accessing encryption keys. AxCrypt offers user-friendly key management, ensuring only authorized personnel have access to decrypt files.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH3_Text2
data.value: • Key Rotation: ☑️ Rotate encryption keys regularly to maintain security. AxCrypt allows you to set up automatic key rotation for added protection.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH4_Text1
data.value: • Encryption Policy: ☑️ Develop a written policy that outlines your organization's approach to data encryption for ePHI. This policy should specify the use of encryption tools like AxCrypt and define protocols for key management and access.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH4_Text2
data.value: • Procedures: ☑️ Document procedures for implementing, managing, and maintaining encryption controls.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH4_Text3
data.value: • Employee Training: ☑️ Train all employees who handle ePHI in HIPAA requirements and proper data security practices, including how to utilize file encryption.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH5_Text3
data.value: • Regular Reviews: ☑️ Conduct periodic reviews of your encryption practices to ensure their effectiveness and adapt to evolving security threats.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH5_Text4
data.value: • Security Audits: ☑️ Consider conducting regular security audits to identify vulnerabilities and potential breaches. Include AxCrypt and other encryption solutions in your security audits to ensure their proper implementation.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH6_Text1
data.value: • Business Associate Agreements: ☑️ Ensure your agreements with Business Associates clearly outline their responsibility for safeguarding ePHI. Include specific clauses regarding data encryption practices.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH6_Text2
data.value: • Incident Response: ☑️ Develop a plan for responding to data breaches and other security incidents that may involve ePHI. This plan should outline procedures for addressing potential breaches.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_SH7_Text1
data.value: • Understand HIPAA Requirements: ☑️ Familiarize yourself with the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) Security Rule and its addressable implementation specifications for encryption. Resources like the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) website can be helpful.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H3_Text2
data.value: We recommend that you revisit and utilize this checklist on a regular basis to ensure the continued security of your patients' electronic Protected Health Information (ePHI).

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H5_SH8_Text8

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_H5_SH9_Text9

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_Text1
data.value: In today’s AI era, data privacy and confidentiality become a critical aspect of a user’s data, especially in industries like healthcare where sensitive information is handled everyday. The healthcare industry today generates approximately 30% of the world's data volume, and this number is expected to grow exponentially in the future.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_Text2
data.value: The exponential increase in the healthcare data also makes it highly vulnerable to devastating cyber attacks and data breaches. Healthcare is one of the top 3 targeted industries in terms of cyber attacks, with Electronic Health Records (EHR) containing Personal Identifiable Information (PII) being particularly vulnerable.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_Text3
data.value: To mitigate these risks and safeguard the sensitive healthcare data, HIPAA was created in the US as a federal law. HIPAA mandates hospitals, healthcare providers, insurance providers, and any entity that processes sensitive healthcare data, to ensure comprehensive data security measures, including encryption, to safeguard patient information and maintain privacy and confidentiality.

data.name: Blog_HTCWHER_Text4
data.value: In this blog post, we’ll explore HIPAA, its encryption requirements and a checklist to help your healthcare organization easily comply with HIPAA’s data encryption requirements.

data.name: Blog_HTEDOYAAIPI2_H1_Text1
data.value: Encryption is a process of scrambling data so that it cannot be read by unauthorized users. File encryption works by transforming the contents within a file into an indecipherable and unreadable format. This transformation involves an encryption algorithm and cryptographic keys to rearrange the contents of a file.

data.name: Blog_HTEDOYAAIPI2_H1_Text2
data.value: The algorithm has steps that perform permutation or rearrangement of file’s content, such as substituting, shifting, replacing, and mixing to scrabble the data. The cryptographic keys are used to determine the order or specific operations to be performed so that the entire encryption process can be repeated or reversed to decrypt a file.

data.name: Blog_HTEDOYAAIPI2_H1_Text3
data.value: Similar to a real-life padlock and key combination, only the specific cryptographic keys used during the encryption process can decrypt a file. Let’s better understand file encryption with a simple example: Suppose you have a file on your phone containing important and sensitive data, such as tax statements or financial records. Once encrypted, the file's contents will be transformed and scrambled, appearing something like this: ‘U2FsdGVkX1+Ww/kwN8Bn’ – a completely undecipherable string of characters that can only be decoded with the right key.

data.value: 1. 🔒 Protect Personal Photos,Videos and Files: Encryption adds an additional strong security layer to your files on your Android and iOS devices, providing a secured space for files and reducing the risks associated with keeping the data on phones.

data.name: Blog_HTEDOYAAIPI2_H3_Text2

data.name: Blog_HTEDOYAAIPI2_H3_Text3

data.name: Blog_HTEDOYAAIPI2_H3_Text4
data.value: 4. 🛡️ Data Breach Shield: During the events of a devastating data breaches or a hacking attempts, encrypted files on your devices are unreadable to attackers without the decryption key, saving you from unprecedented time, data, and financial losses.

data.name: Blog_HTEDOYAAIPI2_H3_Text5
data.value: 5. 🪪 Physical Theft Protection: If your Android or iOS device is stolen, encrypted files act as a crucial safeguard. Without the decryption key, stolen files remain useless and cannot be opened or viewed. This ensures a robust theft protection measures for your phones.

data.name: Blog_HTEDOYAAIPI2_H4_Text1
data.value: File encryption for your smartphones acts as a first line of defense against cyber attacks. It is the recommended method of data security by renowned institutions like NIST, IBM, Microsoft etc. to protect valuable data at rest.

data.name: Blog_HTEDOYAAIPI2_H4_Text2

Whether it's personal files, photos, videos, financial documents, or sensitive business data, encryption ensures that even if someone gains unauthorized access to your phone, your data remains unreadable and protected.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H1_Text1
data.value: Encryption, particularly file encryption, involves transforming the contents of a file into an unreadable and indecipherable format using complex algorithms and cryptographic keys. In specific terms, the original file or data that needs to be encrypted is called plaintext, and the transformed content after the encryption process is called ciphertext. The reverse of the encryption process to retrieve the original plaintext from the encrypted ciphertext is called decryption.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H1_Text2
data.value: During the file encryption process, the algorithm reorganizes, shifts, mixes, and alters the contents of the files into a random arrangement of characters. The cryptographic keys dictate the precise sequence or procedures of these alterations, allowing for the reversal of the encryption process to restore the contents of the files to their original state.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H2_Text1
data.value: Encryption is intrinsically different from simply password protecting a file, as encryption completely transforms the contents of a file after it is encrypted. When compared to password protection or any other method, a file might only be shielded by a password, whereas encryption ensures that the file's contents are scrambled and unreadable without the decryption key.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H2_Text2
data.value: This makes encryption a far more robust and secure method of protecting sensitive information, as it renders the data indecipherable to unauthorized parties even if they gain access to the file.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H2_Text3
data.value: Think of encryption like a secret code that jumbles up the contents of a file, making it impossible to understand without the correct key to decipher it. On the other hand, password protection simply puts a lock on the file that can be easily bypassed or cracked with the right tools or techniques.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H3_Text1
data.value: Different encryption tools with different methods are available for Windows. Essentially, you can encrypt your files and data in two main ways: file encryption and disk encryption. File encryption, as the name suggests, encrypts individual files or folders, providing granular control over security measures. On the other hand, disk encryption encrypts the entire disk, including the operating system and related files.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H3_Text2
data.value: In terms of disk encryption, BitLocker is a built-in option on Windows. While powerful, it is limited to Windows Pro users and lacks the simplicity and accessibility desired by many users. This complexity can be frustrating and time-consuming for users looking for straightforward solutions to protect their sensitive files and not an entire disk.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H3_Text3
data.value: On the other hand, AxCrypt is a superior option for automatic file encryption on Windows. Unlike BitLocker and device encryption, AxCrypt prioritizes simplicity and effectiveness, offering a seamless and intuitive experience for users. With AxCrypt, encrypting your files is as easy as a few clicks, ensuring robust protection against unauthorized access without the need for technical expertise.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H3_Text4
data.value: AxCrypt offers additional features such as secure file sharing, allowing you to collaborate with colleagues or share sensitive information securely. Its seamless integration with Windows Explorer makes it effortless to encrypt and decrypt files directly from the file explorer, streamlining your workflow and enhancing productivity.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H4_SH1_Text1
data.value: Follow these steps to encrypt your files using a password as a key on Windows.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H4_SH1_Text10
data.value: Your most recent encrypted files will appear on the main screen on the ‘Recent Files’ tab, and will have a file extension of .axx. You can add new folders and subfolders and AxCrypt will automatically encrypt them as well.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H4_SH1_Text11
data.value: To permanently decrypt a file, click on the ‘Stop Securing’ icon from the main menu strip on top and select the files that you’d like to decrypt.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H4_SH1_Text12
data.value: When you open a file to view or edit, it only creates a temporary decryption process, and any changes made to the file will automatically be re-encrypted.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_H4_SH1_Text13
data.value: AxCrypt can also automatically encrypt and sync files from your Windows to your Google Drive and OneDrive accounts, allowing you to access and edit them on the go on your phone.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_Summary
data.value: We all like to keep our sensitive files private and secure. Be it tax statements, financial documents, health records or our cherished memories in the form of photos and videos. However, protecting your sensitive files and documents on Windows can be a not-so-easy task.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_Text1
data.value: We all like to keep our sensitive files private and secure. Be it tax statements, financial documents, health records or our cherished memories in the form of photos and videos. However, protecting your sensitive files and documents on Windows can be a not-so-easy task, especially if you’re not familiar with data security best practices.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_Text2
data.value: Windows is one of the most ubiquitous operating systems in the world, and with this great popularity comes great responsibility – and vulnerability. Due to Window’s dominant market share, it’s also one of the most vulnerable OS in terms of cybersecurity threats. Hackers and cybercriminals love to target Windows systems due to their widespread use, making them a prime target for malware, phishing, ransomware, and other malicious attacks.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_Text3
data.value: Thankfully though, there is an easier and powerful method of securing your sensitive files on Windows. It’s called encryption. Encryption or more specifically file encryption, adds a protective shield over your sensitive files so that your information cannot be accessed by unauthorized users, even if they somehow have access to your files.

data.name: Blog_HTEFOWAWA_Text4
data.value: In this blog, we’ll take a look at what encryption for Windows is, how it works, and how you can protect your sensitive files all with a step-by-step and super-easy to follow language.

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H1_Text1
data.value: This is a step-by-step instruction on how to provide us with a full error report. We might ask you to do this when you are having problems with AxCrypt. The information we get by this will help us help you!

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H1_Text2
data.value: A full error report consists of an email to support@axcrypt.net with the following attachments:

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H1_Text3
data.value:
1. A screen shot of the situation, error message or similar.
  2. The AxCrypt configuration files and internal error log.
  3. Your Windows Event Log. This is a log of all errors reported by Windows recently.

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H1_Text4
data.value: So, the email should contain a description of the problem and the following attachments:

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H1_Text5
data.value:
1. A screen shot of the situation, i.e. ‘Problem.jpg’ or similar.
  2. FileSystemState.txt, ReportSnapshot.txt, UserAccounts.txt, UserPublicKeys.txt, UserSettings.txt
  3. AxCrypt.zip – the zipped event viewer log.

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H1_Text6
data.value: For detailed instructions, read on!

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H2_Text1
data.value: Please follow the instructions from Microsoft on how to use the Snipping Tool:

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H2_Text2
data.value: Do not crop it too much, please show relevant parts of Windows Explorer and the full AxCrypt window where appropriate.

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H3_Text1
data.value: Start by opening Windows Explorer, and enter the path to the AxCrypt configuration folder: %localappdata%/AxCrypt, then hit ‘Enter’.

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H3_Text2
data.value: You should then see something similar to the following:

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H3_Text3
data.value: Take all files ending with .txt, and attach them to the mail. There is nothing especially sensitive in these files. You can always open them with a text editor to see exactly what is sent if you like. Do not add folders that you may see here.: %localappdata%/AxCrypt, then hit ‘Enter’.

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H4_Text1
data.value: Finally, we need to get a copy of your event log since program crashes are recorded here. Do as follows:

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H4_Text2
data.value: Click on your Start button / Windows button and type:

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H4_Text3
data.value: eventvwr

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H4_Text4
data.value: And then click on the “Event Viewer Desktop App” suggestion to start.

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H4_Text5
data.value: Expand the Windows node, right-click the ‘Application’ node and select ‘Save All Events As…’.

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H4_Text6
data.value: Save to ‘Documents’, and name the file ‘AxCrypt’.

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H4_Text7
data.value: Select to include English (US) message texts:

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H4_Text8
data.value: Go to ‘Documents’, right-click the file ‘AxCrypt.evtx’ and send it to Windows Compression to make a zip-file:

data.name: Blog_HTSCER_H4_Text9
data.value: Attach this file to your email:

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H1_Text1
data.value: Malware Embedding: Cybercriminals often exploit PDF files by embedding malware within them. These malicious files can be disguised as legitimate documents and distributed via email or file-sharing platforms. Once opened, the malware can infect the user's device, leading to data breaches or system compromise.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H1_Text2
data.value: Phishing Attacks: PDF files are commonly used in phishing attacks, where attackers trick users into clicking on malicious links or downloading infected attachments. These phishing PDFs may appear to be legitimate documents from trusted sources, making them difficult to identify as threats.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H1_Text3
data.value: Exploitable Security Flaws: PDF reader software and the PDF format itself may contain security vulnerabilities that can be exploited by attackers. These flaws could allow attackers to bypass security controls, execute arbitrary code, or gain unauthorized access to sensitive information stored within PDF files.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H1_Text4
data.value: Password Weaknesses: Password-protected PDF files are only as secure as the strength of their passwords. Weak or easily guessable passwords can be cracked using brute-force attacks, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access to the contents of the PDF.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H1_Text5
data.value: Metadata Leakage: PDF files can contain hidden metadata that may inadvertently disclose sensitive information about the document or its author. This metadata could include details such as author names, creation dates, or revision history, which could be exploited by attackers for social engineering or targeted attacks.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H2_Text1
data.value: Encryption: One of the most effective ways to secure PDF files is by encrypting them with a password. Encryption scrambles the content of the PDF, making it unreadable without the correct password. This prevents unauthorized users from accessing the document's contents, even if they gain access to the file.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H2_Text2
data.value: Access Controls: PDF files can be protected with access controls that restrict who can view, edit, or print the document. Access control settings can specify user permissions, such as allowing only certain users to view the document while preventing others from viewing or opening it

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H2_Text3
data.value: Redaction: Redaction is the process of permanently removing sensitive or confidential information from a PDF document. This can include text, images, or other content that should not be disclosed to unauthorized parties. Redaction tools allow users to selectively remove or obscure sensitive information before sharing the document. While it can remove sensitive information, it's not a good choice when you actually want to share sensitive information

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H2_Text4
data.value: Secure File Transfer: When sharing PDF files, it's essential to use secure file transfer methods to prevent interception or unauthorized access during transmission. Secure file transfer protocols, such as SFTP or HTTPS, encrypting data at rest before sharing it, ensuring that it remains secure from prying eyes.

data.value: And that’s it! Your files will be encrypted with an .axx file extension, and will appear on the ‘Recent Files’ tab under the menu strip. To open a file, just tap on any of the listed files directly from the main screen, or tap the ‘Open Secured’ button and select a file. To permanently decrypt a file, tap on the ‘Stop Securing’ button and select the file that you’d like to decrypt that has the .axx file extension.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H3_SH2_Text7
data.value: When you open a file to view or edit, it only creates a temporary decryption process, and any changes made to the file will automatically be re-encrypted.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H3_Text1
data.value: Encryption is a powerful method for safeguarding sensitive PDFs, ensuring that they’re protected at all times. Encryption is different from other security methods such as password protection. Encryption transforms the contents of the PDF files into an unreadable and undecipherable format using algorithms and crypto keys, so that they cannot be read and made sense of by unauthorized users.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H3_Text2
data.value: By encrypting your PDFs, you can be rest assured that they are protected at all times, even if someone gets access to them, as they will not be able to decrypt or read the contents of the PDFs without the decryption key. AxCrypt is a comprehensive file encryption software that protects your PDFs with the strongest and practically unbreakable encryption algorithm, the AES-256.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_H4_Text1
data.value: In conclusion, the importance of securing PDFs with encryption and passwords cannot be overstated in today's digital age. Despite their convenience and versatility, PDFs are vulnerable to cyber threats, making robust security measures essential. Encrypting PDFs with strong passwords adds an extra layer of protection, ensuring that sensitive information remains safe from unauthorized access.

data.name: Blog_HTSPWESBSI2_Text3
data.value: One common method is embedding malware into PDF files, which can then be unwittingly downloaded and executed by unsuspecting users. data.name: Blog_HTSRWWE_H1_Text1
data.value: Encryption, specifically file encryption is a process where the contents of a file are transformed into an unreadable and undecipherable format. The process involves an encryption algorithm such as AES and encryption keys. The encryption keys contain the precise pattern for the algorithm to transform the file’s contents, so that the same keys can be used to reverse the encryption process (decryption) to restore the file’s contents to its original state.

data.value: The Covid-19 pandemic has changed remote work forever. While remote work existed before, the pandemic accelerated it, making work-from-home a new norm. This shift has brought undeniable benefits, including flexibility, increased productivity, and improved work-life balance.

data.name: Blog_HTSRWWE_Text1
data.value: The Covid-19 pandemic has changed remote work forever. While remote work existed before, the pandemic accelerated it, making work-from-home a new norm. This shift has brought undeniable benefits, including flexibility, increased productivity, and improved work-life balance.

data.name: Blog_HTSRWWE_Text2
data.value: However, the transition to remote work has also brought with it a new set of security challenges. With employees accessing company data and systems from personal devices and home networks, the risk of cyberattacks and data breaches has significantly increased. Sensitive information is now more vulnerable than ever, and businesses need to take proactive measures to safeguard it.

data.name: Blog_HTSRWWE_Text3
data.value: One of the most effective tools for data security in remote work is encryption. Encryption acts as a digital shield, protecting your sensitive information from unauthorized access, even if it falls into the wrong hands.

data.name: Blog_HTSRWWE_Text4
data.value: This blog post will explore the importance of encryption for remote work, how it can be implemented, and security measures that businesses can adopt to create a secure remote work environment. By prioritizing data protection, businesses and organizations can foster trust and confidence among their remote workforce and ensure a streamlined workflow of their remote work model.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H1_Text1
data.value: Data Breaches: This is usually the main reason why companies think they should apply encryption as part of their security strategy. Data breaches seem destructive to newly started companies, and they are, but it’s just one of many areas where encryption helps a business to secure and expand. Actually, there are many areas, and I will list them below.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H1_Text2
data.value: Malware Infections: Talk about ruining one’s reputation. The fact is, shared files without proper security measures are not only damaging to your company but also to anyone who is a recipient of the file. Encryption erases all possibilities of infected malware and ensures that both your company and your fellow companies stay clean.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H1_Text3
data.value: Loss of Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to files can result in the exposure of confidential business information, personal data, and intellectual property. This is another area that would be devastating for the company. Loss of confidentiality will also result in a decreased reputation and neglected connections.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H1_Text4
data.value: Financial Loss: There is a lot of information that is valuable to cybercriminals. It’s not just the direct attack that is the devastating aspect. The initial data breach is usually only the beginning. With the information they gather from the company, they can expand their attack, increasing the financial loss. They may use the information to commit fraud. Additionally, the company may experience even more financial loss due to the cost of remediation efforts.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H1_Text5
data.value: Reputation Damage: Reputation is key to a successful company. No customers initiate contact with a known unsafe company. Encryption is not only for the customers but also for potential partners and stakeholders, who are just as important to keep the company running. Encryption will encourage customers and partners to get involved with your company.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H1_Text6
data.value: Loss of Competitive Advantage: Exposure of strategic business information can undermine an organization’s competitive advantage.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H1_Text7
data.value: Ensuring secure file-sharing practices is crucial to mitigate these risks and protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and exploitation.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H4_Text1
data.value: Imagine a leading software development company in the process of merging with a prominent tech hardware manufacturer. This merger is expected to create a tech giant capable of offering comprehensive hardware and software solutions. Given the complexity and sensitivity of the merger, secure file sharing is crucial.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H4_Text2
data.value: Consider all the parties involved: CEOs, CFOs, and COOs from both companies. It doesn’t stop there—attorneys handling contractual agreements, HR departments responsible for managing employee data, finance departments handling asset evaluations and financial audits, and IT departments ensuring cybersecurity and data migration.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H4_Text3
data.value: With all this data being shared among the departments, there is a significant risk of data breaches. These breaches can lead to financial loss, reputational damage, and legal repercussions.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H4_Text4
data.value: Another challenge is ensuring compliance with data protection laws such as GDPR, CCPA, and HIPAA. They also have a responsibility to maintain data integrity and completeness during the transfer process.

data.name: Blog_HTSSFWAUA_H4_Text5
data.value: This is why encryption and data security are so important for a leading business. By implementing AxCrypt’s AES-256 encryption system, the two merging companies will have these challenges under control.

data.name: BLOG_HTSSPWYFC_Text1
data.value: Weak, simple, and compromised passwords are the number one cause for data breaches around the world, with approximately 81% of data breaches caused due to poor passwords. As an important part of your everyday work life, sharing passwords with team members is often unavoidable in a collaborative work environment.

data.name: BLOG_HTSSPWYFC_Text2
data.value: However, sharing sensitive passwords via insecure methods like email, text messages, or shared documents poses significant security risks to the organization and employees. Cybercriminals can easily intercept these unsecured channels, potentially compromising company login information and accessing sensitive data.

data.name: BLOG_HTSSPWYFC_Text3
data.value: This is where a dedicated and encrypted password manager comes in as the most secure and reliable solution for password sharing. A dedicated password manager ensures that passwords are generated, stored, and shared securely with top-notch security and encryption methods.

data.name: BLOG_HTSSPWYFC_Title
data.value: How to Securely Share Passwords with Your Friends and Colleagues

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_H1_Text1
data.value: As we adjust to a new work environment that no one may ever have envisioned, the pandemic has disturbed organizations and led human resources managers to rethink how to perform their duties. HR professionals are worried not just about their employees' health and well-being during the epidemic, but also about processing paperwork in a secure manner and providing comfort to the millions of people who have been laid off or working remotely.

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_H2_SH1_Text1
data.value: An organization's risk exposure can be determined by completing a risk assessment regularly. Regular evaluations can assist identify which employee habits are most likely to expose a company to data breaches or other hazards. A risk assessment by HR, for example, can assist a business in identifying an insecure workstation. It can also show whether staff has misplaced their identification cards. Employee errors might provide thieves with valuable information or unrestricted access to a company's network.

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_H2_SH2_Text1
data.value: HR needs to keep rules well-documented and ensure that every recruit is aware of them. This comprises protocols for reporting threats, effectively responding to them, and so on, to protect a company and its data.

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_H2_SH3_Text1
data.value: An attacker can impersonate an employee to obtain access to a system from within, therefore investing time and resources in background checks is a critical security strategy that can help a company protect its systems. Background checks can be costly, and a company may not have the means to conduct them properly. In this instance, it's best to outsource these services to professional security agencies that can run thorough background checks that reveal information that the HR department doesn't have access to.

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_H2_SH4_Text1
data.value: The human resources department can assist a company in setting up and implementing access restrictions. Even before an employee is hired or onboarded, HR can establish the data that they will need. They must also ensure that at the end of their contract, the employee does not have access to this information.

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_H2_SH5_Text1
data.value: If a breach occurs, the IT department is not solely responsible for resolving the issue. It's also a human resources concern, especially if there are employees involved. HR is accountable for its employees' conduct. This leaves organizations open to cybercrime.

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_H2_SH6_Text1
data.value: Security has become too important to ignore in the face of the growing menace of cybercrime. Furthermore, it has made internet security a role for the entire firm, rather than just for information technology security specialists. AxCrypt offers 256-bit encryption and a slew of other capabilities that allow teammates to collaborate while maintaining cyber security. It can assist HR personnel in making a good contribution to a company's cybersecurity.

data.value: Organization's Risk Exposure

data.value: Policy Making

data.value: Need and Responsibilities for Cybersecurity in the HR sector

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_Summary
data.value: HRs are in charge of a lot of confidential business information, including employee personal information, payment details, and other information that, if disclosed, might do significant harm.

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_Text1
data.value: HRs are in charge of a lot of confidential business information, including employee personal information, payment details, and other information that, if disclosed, might do significant harm. As a result, HR professionals are in a great position to protect against cyber threats.

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_Text2
data.value: In this digital age, cybersecurity is becoming a major problem for businesses. When information breaches, data hacks, and identity thefts occur, many people believe that HR professionals, for example, have nothing to worry about. However, for a company to remain secure, every employee must exercise fundamental cyber hygiene.

data.name: Blog_ICSHRS_Title
data.value: Importance of cyber security in the human resources sector

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H1_Text1
data.value: Identity theft is the act of stealing someone's personal and sensitive information, such as their photos and videos, names and addresses, social security numbers, and credit card numbers. The perpetrator then uses this information for their own financial gain or to commit other criminal activities.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H1_Text2
data.value: There are several ways in which identity theft can occur. One common method is through phishing scams, where criminals send out emails or messages that appear to be from legitimate sources, such as banks or credit card companies. These messages often ask the recipient to provide their personal information, such as their login credentials or credit card numbers.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H1_Text3
data.value: Another way that identity theft can occur is through data breaches, where hackers gain access to large databases of personal information. In these cases, the hacker may steal thousands or even millions of people's personal information at once.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H1_Text4
data.value: The implications of identity theft can be devastating. Victims may find that their credit scores have been ruined, that they are unable to obtain loans or credit cards, or that they are being pursued by debt collectors for debts that they did not incur. In some cases, victims may even face criminal charges for activities that were committed in their name.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H1_Text5
data.value: A recent example of identity theft is the SolarWinds hack that occurred in late 2020. In this attack, Russian hackers gained access to the computer systems of numerous U.S. government agencies and major corporations, including Microsoft, Cisco, and Intel. The hackers were able to install malware on the victims' systems, giving them access to sensitive information.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H1_Text6
data.value: The SolarWinds hack was one of the largest and most sophisticated cyberattacks in history, with an estimated 18,000 organizations affected. The implications of the hack were far-reaching, with the potential for sensitive information to be used for espionage, financial gain, or other malicious purposes.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H1_Text7
data.value: The SolarWinds hack highlighted the need for increased cybersecurity measures to protect against identity theft and other types of cybercrime. This includes encrypting your personal data, using strong passwords and multi-factor authentication, and staying vigilant for phishing scams and other fraudulent activities. To protect yourself from identity theft, it is important to take steps to safeguard your personal data.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H2_Text1
data.value: There are various ways personal photos and videos get leaked online. Some due to malware and others due to a human error. Identifying the different ways in which personal media can get leaked is crucial to taking preventative measures and keeping your information secure. Following are some of the most common causes of personal media leaks:

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H2_Text2
data.value: Hacking: One of the most common ways personal media gets leaked is through hacking. Cybercriminals can gain unauthorized access to your device, cloud storage, or social media accounts and steal your personal photos and videos. They can then sell or distribute your private content on the dark web or use it for extortion purposes.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H2_Text3
data.value: Malware: Malware and viruses pose a significant threat to the security of personal media. Malware can infiltrate your device through various means, such as malicious links, downloads, or email attachments, and grant hackers remote access to your device, including your personal files.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H2_Text4
data.value: Once they have access, hackers can exploit your personal media as a bargaining chip, demanding ransom payments or using the content for extortion. This type of attack is not only a breach of privacy but also a serious violation of your personal safety and security.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H2_Text5
data.value: Social Engineering: Personal media can also get leaked through social engineering, which is a common technique used by scammers to obtain personal information or login credentials from unsuspecting victims. Social engineering involves manipulating or deceiving people through various means such as phishing emails, phone calls, or text messages.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H2_Text6
data.value: For instance, a scammer can send you an email that looks like it's from your cloud storage provider or social media account, asking you to log in to your account for some reason. Once you provide your login credentials, the scammer can use it to access and leak your personal media. It is important to always be vigilant and verify the authenticity of the source before providing any personal information or login credentials.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H2_Text7
data.value: Human Error: Sometimes, personal media can be leaked by accident. This can happen when you share your media with someone you trust, such as a partner or close friend, and they accidentally or intentionally share it with others without your permission.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H2_Text8
data.value: Data Breaches: In some cases, personal media can also be leaked due to a data breach. If a company that you have shared your personal media with experiences a data breach, your content can be compromised and leaked online. This highlights the importance of using secure and reputable companies to store your personal media.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H2_Text9
data.value: Physical Theft: Personal media can be leaked through physical theft or loss of devices. If someone steals or finds your phone, laptop, or camera, they may be able to access and leak your personal media. This is why it is important to keep your devices secure with strong passwords and enable features such as Find My Device to help locate and remotely wipe your device if it is lost or stolen.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H3_Text1
data.value: Now that you know the different ways by which personal photos and videos get leaked, it's important to take steps to protect them. Here are some ways you can safeguard your personal media:

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H3_Text2
data.value: Data Encryption: Encryption is one of the most effective methods for safeguarding your personal photos and videos from being leaked. Encryption involves converting your data into an unreadable format that can only be deciphered using a special key. By encrypting your personal media, you ensure that even if it falls into the wrong hands, it will be unreadable and useless without the encryption key.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H3_Text3
data.value: Password Manager: Password management is another essential step in safeguarding your personal photos and videos from being leaked. It is important to use strong, unique passwords for each of your online accounts, including your cloud storage and social media accounts. You can use a password manager tool such as AxCryptâ€™s Password Manger to create and store complex passwords securely.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H3_Text4
data.value: VPN: It is important to be cautious when using public Wi-Fi networks as they can be easily hacked, leading to your personal media being accessed and leaked. When connecting to a public Wi-Fi, always connect to a virtual private network (VPN) to encrypt your data and protect it from prying eyes.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H3_Text5
data.value: Backup: Regularly backing up your personal media is also crucial to safeguarding it from being leaked. By creating multiple copies of your media and storing them in different locations, you ensure that even if one copy gets lost or stolen, you still have access to your media. To add an extra layer of security, you can encrypt your backups.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H3_Text6
data.value: Vigilance: Be wary of phishing scams, which involve tricking you into revealing your personal information or login credentials. These scams often come in the form of emails, texts, or phone calls that appear to be from legitimate sources. Always double-check the sender's email address or phone number and never click on suspicious links or download attachments from unknown sources.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H3_Text7
data.value: Lastly, consider limiting the amount of personal media you share online. Even with privacy settings in place, there is always a risk that your media could be accessed or leaked by hackers or malicious actors. By only sharing media with trusted individuals and avoiding sharing sensitive content altogether, you can reduce the risk of your personal media being leaked.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H4_Conclusion_Text1
data.value: When it comes to securing your personal photos, videos, and sensitive documents, AxCrypt is your best bet. For six years in a row, AxCrypt has consistently been recognized as the “World's Best Encryption Software”.by PC Mag since 2016.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H4_Conclusion_Text2
data.value: AxCrypt uses the unbreakable AES 256-bit algorithm to protect your data. It also offers several useful features such as automatic cloud encryption, secure file sharing, password management and generation, and a master key feature to manage subordinate accounts.

data.name: Blog_IDTRLPVU_H4_Conclusion_Text3
data.value: Try AxCrypt today with a no-nonsense 30-day free trial and take your data security to the next level. Sign up now by clicking here.

In this blog post, we’ll explore the risks of leaving your personal photos and videos unprotected, and the various tips and tricks that you can use to proactively protect your personal media.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_Conclusion_Text1
data.value: Cybercrime is on the rise, and educational institutions are particularly vulnerable. Unfortunately, many educational institutions do not use encryption technology, despite the fact that it is a fundamental security measure mandated by rules and policies.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_SH1_Text1
data.value: In the face of known risks, educational institutions can be reasonably protected with encryption. Encryption is now a requirement in the commercial world. Encryption is used to protect data in almost every business that deals with personal or sensitive information. Because student information contains everything that attackers need to steal a person's identity and/or engage in other illicit actions, educational organizations, and suppliers that do business with them are undoubtedly the most targeted for malicious data breaches. Cybercriminals have practically unrestricted access to stolen education data, allowing them to profit, cause harm, and ruin lives.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_SH1_Text2
data.value: Encryption protects data in the following ways:

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_SH1_Text3
data.value: • Only approved receivers have access to view the messages from the moment they are created, throughout their entire lifecycle, regardless of where they go or with whom they are shared.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_SH1_Text4
data.value: • Even if data falls into the wrong hands due to a breach of user error

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_SH1_Text5
data.value: • On top of the platforms they already use, such as G Suite for Education or Microsoft Outlook, data encryption from a trustworthy source adds an extra layer of data protection, ensuring ease of use, recognizable workflows, and high user uptake.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_SubHeading1
data.value: How to protect data?

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_Text1
data.value: Huge Amounts of Sensitive Data are Protected in Schools. Multiple types of personally identifiable data, such as social security numbers, credit card numbers, driver's license numbers, passport numbers, addresses, phone numbers, bank/debit account numbers, medical information, and other sensitive data, are routinely handled by educational institutions of all sizes. These organizations also have access to confidential government and/or business intelligence data about trade, scientific, or military secrets because of their research focus.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_Text2
data.value: • Intellectual property from campus research is quite valuable.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_Text3
data.value: • Personal information about students and employees

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_H1_Text4
data.value: • The processing power of computers

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_Heading1
data.value: Why are hackers targeting educational institutes?

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_Summary
data.value: Educational institutes have become more exposed to cyberattacks as a result of the greater use of technology for teaching and learning.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_Text1
data.value: Educational institutes have become more exposed to cyberattacks as a result of the greater use of technology for teaching and learning. According to reports( Instead of adding a link to a resource, mention the name here. Eg according to the Oxford study type), the education sector accounted for 62% of the approximately 5.8 million malware cases reported.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_Text2
data.value: Therefore, today's schools require a strong and dependable system to ensure the privacy and security of their students' data, as well as their school's compliance with all regulations, in the face of rapidly expanding stores of student data, a rise in data breach threats, and the growing amount of data privacy legislation. These requirements can be met via data encryption.

data.name: Blog_ITESBETFC_Title
data.value: Is the Educational Sector becoming an easy target for Cyberattacks?

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Summary
data.value: When you use AxCrypt 2, first you have to “sign in” – after the first time, that’s just entering your password. Since AxCrypt is a password based file encryption application, that makes sense.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text1
data.value: When you use AxCrypt 2, first you have to “sign in” – after the first time, that’s just entering your password. Since AxCrypt is a password based file encryption application, that makes sense. Even if the password is really the only thing that’s required to decrypt a file, we decided to use the “sign in” metaphor for a number of reasons, among others to make it harder to make a fatal mistake that sometimes happened with AxCrypt 1, which was to mistype the password twice when encrypting a new file. This would sometimes lead to data loss, and that’s bad.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text10
data.value: It should also be noted that AxCrypt is not really 100% about local device security, there are too many things outside our control for that. For local device security, we recommend using hard disk or device encryption such as BitLocker, FileVault or mobile device encryption as an excellent complement to AxCrypt.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text11
data.value: To summarize, we do not think think that the “what if someone walks up to my computer” argument against having AxCrypt stay signed in is valid.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text12
data.value: We think you should activate your screen saver if you walk away from a device with information on it confidential enough to warrant encryption in the first place.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text13
data.value: Happy AxCrypting!

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text2
data.value: Once you are signed in to AxCrypt 2, it’ll stay signed in until you sign out, or the screen saver goes active, or the device goes to sleep, or you sign out of your user account, or you power down the device.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text3
data.value: This is done by careful design to make AxCrypt 2 as convenient as possible to use, i.e. reduce the number of times the password must be entered. This, we believe, will make it used more and thus protect more files. If it’s inconvenient, you won’t use it as much.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text4
data.value: However, now and then we get feedback from users stating “But what if someone walks up to my computer? Then all my files are unprotected.“.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text5
data.value: Yes, that’s true. But it almost makes no difference if AxCrypt is signed in or not, if you leave your device unprotected so anyone can walk up to it and access it with your user sign in permissions.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text6
data.value: It’s that simple. Security is about a chain of measures, and it’s the weakest one that controls the strength of the system.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text7
data.value: If you let anyone walk up to your device and it’s signed in with your user, you should consider that computer compromised and re-install from original media.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text8
data.value: AxCrypt has always been an opinionated application. This means we have opinions about how it should be used, opinions we base on the fact that encryption is all we do. We eat, drink, think and dream about encryption 24 hours a day. We think our opinions are fairly valid. Of course we’re not infallible, but we’re seldom far off the mark.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Text9
data.value: AxCrypt has always been about real, definable, security. It’s not about making you feel secure. It is about making you actually secure within well defined bounds and limitations. Making you feel more secure by having you pointlessly re-enter a password a zillion times is not our thing.

data.name: Blog_LYCWAR_Title
data.value: Leaving your computer with AxCrypt running

data.name: Blog_MDPNST_Conclusion_Text1
data.value: This year, cybercrime will not slow down. Criminals have limitless options, and their methods are becoming increasingly sophisticated. Businesses can no longer afford to cut corners, and risk monitoring must be prioritized for mobile phones. Now that you understand the need for an encrypted phone, encrypt your mobile devices with AxCrypt to protect your data from unauthorized access.

data.name: Blog_MDPNST_H1_Text1
data.value: Mobile security is an important component of a cybersecurity strategy in today's world. The widespread adoption of Bring-Your-Own-Device (BYOD) policies was a direct result of the transition to remote work. Companies may have increased productivity and employee retention by enabling employees to work from personal devices, but they also lost crucial security visibility and the capacity to respond to infections that jeopardize corporate systems and solutions.

data.name: Blog_MDPNST_H2_SH1_Text1
data.value: According to reports, the number of malware attacks has doubled due to the increased use of banking apps. Malware attacks increased significantly in 2021, with hackers concentrating their efforts on smartphones, employing strategies such as surveillance, credential theft, and malicious adverts.

data.name: Blog_MDPNST_H2_SH2_Text1
data.value: Increased cloud adoption attracts more scrutiny from ethical hackers and cyber threat operators. Many of the attacks target cloud infrastructure vulnerabilities, allowing an attacker to exploit multiple targets with a single vulnerability. With AxCrypt you can protect your data on the drive on your mobile and PC.

data.name: Blog_MDPNST_H2_SH3_Text1
data.value: In the first six months of 2021, mobile smishing increased by over 700%, owing to more online traffic. This year, mobile smishing attacks are predicted to become more complicated and effective, luring people to click on malicious web links, open infected files, and even SMS messages.

data.name: Blog_MDPNST_H2_SH4_Text1
data.value: AxCrypt is a multi-award-winning cyber security company that offers mobile and PC cybersecurity solutions for personal and business security. AxCrypt Mobile encryption is beyond a regular lock screen password. It is a one-stop for safeguarding all of your personal information and data on your mobile phones from third-party interference. It does so by storing your phone's information in an unreadable, jumbled format that can only be read with the correct credentials. With mobile encryption, you can be certain that your data is protected even if your device is lost or stolen. You can even exchange encrypted data/files with your team members through our mobile key sharing feature without providing your passwords with just one click.

data.value: 57% of businesses create more than 6,500 files containing sensitive data daily. That is a lot of information, yet it is also very complicated. data.value: Many people use this as a reason to avoid encrypting their data. But this is just a myth. Encryption can be handled by desktop computers, mobile phones, and tablets without slowing down the device. This is attributed to considerable advancements in processing technology in recent years. AxCrypt is a software utility that lets you easily encrypt, password-protect, and secure any file within a few clicks. It uses the strongest 256-bit Advanced Encryption Standard (AES). It is light on computer resources and runs smoothly without slowing your system.

data.name: Blog_MDSCBF_H2_SH2_Text1
data.value: Many users still feel that implementing encryption on their devices necessitates professional skills. This is merely a myth. AxCrypt delivers AES 256-bit encryption, so you won't have trouble installing it. Even if you have an issue during the installation, our customer support team can assist you. Check out our YouTube videos to get started.

data.name: Blog_MDSCBF_H2_SH3_Text1
data.value: In many circumstances, storing encrypted data in the cloud is safer than keeping it on-premises, where insiders may have greater access. If you want to keep encrypted data safe in the cloud, be sure you have custody of the encryption keys, not your cloud provider. Find another cloud service if your current one demands you to hand over your keys. AxCrypt is designed to simplify advanced encryption on multiple cloud storage services such as Google Drive, Dropbox, etc. Read more about the AxCrypt cloud encryption feature here.

data.name: Blog_MDSCBF_H2_SH4_Text1
data.value: It is one of the most widespread Encryption misconceptions. This could be because we only hear about hackers targeting big businesses, which is also untrue. data.name: Blog_PRAA_H1_Text1
data.value: When a file is encrypted with AxCrypt, a very random 128- or 256-bit key as appropriate is generated by AxCrypt. This key, which is never really seen by anyone, is used to encrypt the file with AES-128 or AES-256. This key we call the master encryption key.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H1_Text2
data.value: The master encryption key in turn, is encrypted with your password, and stored along with the encrypted file data in the resulting AxCrypt-encrypted file.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H1_Text3
data.value: This design, which is standard good practice for encryption, also means we can do exciting things by encrypting that same master encryption key in other ways. Which we do, but that’s not the topic for this article.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H1_Text4
data.value: Thus, as long as you know the password used to originally encrypt a file you can decrypt it with AxCrypt.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H1_Text5
data.value: We also by default use the same password for the online account where we store your subscription status, your online password manager data if used, and your AxCrypt ID which is used primarily for the key sharing feature.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H2_Text1
data.value: If you use the password change feature of the web or the AxCrypt app, what happens is that we change the password for data that we keep online, which includes re-encryption anything you may keep in the password manager, and also your AxCrypt ID which is stored as an AxCrypt encrypted piece of data in our system.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H2_Text2
data.value: To change your password, you must know the old one, since otherwise we cannot decrypt the data we store before encrypting it again with your new password.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H2_Text3
data.value: We do not actually change the password for every encrypted file, since to do that we’d need access to every single one and decrypt them with the old password, and re-encrypt with the new.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H2_Text4
data.value: But since we change the password for your AxCrypt ID, you will actually be able to open old files with the new password. More on how that actually works in a different article.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H3_Text1
data.value: If forget your password, you will lose access to everything ever encrypted with that password. On the server, this means your AxCrypt ID and your data in the online password manager.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H3_Text2
data.value: But, you can still regain access to the web account, by requesting a password reset. This does not require you to know the old password, but it does require you to once again verify that you have access to the email account in question. This we do by sending an activation link once again to that email, and after clicking on that you can set a new password.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H3_Text3
data.value: Remember, a password reset only gets you back so you can sign in and continue using the app and the web site, it does not allow you to regain access to files encrypted with the old password.

data.name: Blog_PRAA_H3_Text4
data.value: Happy AxCrypting!

data.value: The holidays are a great time to spend with your loved ones. But, it's important to remember that the holiday season is one of the busiest times for cybercriminals. Hackers and malware are always lurking around during the holiday season, trying to steal passwords from unsuspecting surfers by installing malicious programs on your computers or smartphones. data.name: Blog_PYDFCG_H2_Text1
data.value: One of the best ways to protect your data is through encryption. Encryption is needed to protect your data from being accessed by others. If your device is lost or stolen, it will be harder for someone else to acquire its contents. Whether you are sending emails, sharing photos, or just browsing the web, encryption helps to keep your information safe from prying eyes. Encryption uses password protection to make data unreadable by third parties and prevent snoopers from accessing your information. This keeps hackers out while still allowing you control over who has access to your data.

data.name: Blog_ROCP_H1_SH1_Text1
data.value: Make sure that only authorised people have access to critical information to protect your data. Verifying and maintaining the integrity of your data, as well as knowing exactly what data you have in your custody, is also very important.

data.name: Blog_ROCP_H1_SH2_Text1
data.value: Avoid selecting the “remember my password” option because hackers may pose a threat by altering or bypassing the browser's security settings to gain access to passwords on newer web browsers. Additionally, it's preferable to refrain from keeping passwords in public or digital documents.

data.name: Blog_ROCP_H1_SH3_Text1
data.value: Passwords must contain upper- and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters (such as @,£, percent, and &), and they must be at least ten characters long. Businesses should establish a password security policy and update it frequently. Additionally, each employee in the organisation needs to have their own password.

data.name: Blog_ROCP_H1_SH4_Text1
data.value: An additional layer of security is added to the password procedure by using a multi-factor authentication system. Because of this, the solution can be used to strengthen your company's security posture and guard against password breaches. In fact, putting this system in place by itself can assist you to eliminate 99% of account breaches.

data.name: Blog_ROCP_H1_SH5_Text1
data.value: A password manager is a safe, digital instrument that centrally stores your internet login information and passwords and is protected by a single, strong master password. Additionally, password managers may create strong, one-of-a-kind passwords for you. By assisting you in creating a password that is specific to each of your accounts, this application improves data security. As a result, if one of your accounts is compromised, the password that was used to access it cannot be used to access any other accounts.

Even if they tried to memorise passwords, help desk staff members frequently forget them due to frequent changes and the volume of accounts they must manage. Password management using a browser is not secure, and saving them in a different spreadsheet is even less secure since they are typically not synced to the cloud. Password changes are recorded and do not save a company with a bad reputation from the vengeance of an angry employee who has left the firm.

data.value: There is nearly 24,000 reported case of a data breach every day. Hacking of hospital records, government records being stolen. Transcripts of education have been made public. The result can be humiliating, costly at best, and financially debilitating, with possible fines, lengthy lawsuits, and a loss of customer trust. data.name: Blog_SCMAE_Title
data.value: Some Common Myths About Encryption

data.name: Blog_SD_H1_Text1
data.value: Do you use Netflix? If you have a Netflix account, you have probably heard of the recently released documentary “The Social Dilemma”, which touches on the significant advantages of social media. Google, Apple, YouTube, Facebook and all these tools have made wonderful things a reality. Reuniting family members, enabling effective communication and enhancing our connectivity are only ones of the meaningful systemic changes that this innovating industry has brought. Nevertheless this increasing polarization does not only have advantages. As highlighted in the documentary people are sometimes a little too naïve about the flip side of that coin.

data.name: Blog_SD_H2_Text1
data.value: Everything you do online is being tracked, measured and analysed. You might feel it is now time for you to take your personal security more seriously. It is time to understand the dangers of having your personal information leaked to those who have an ulterior motive. Hackers can easily take advantage of vulnerable breach to your computer and get access to your emails, documents or files to later use it for malicious purposes. To avoid having a breach in your personal data and have a complete online security and peace of mind; encrypt your files with AxCrypt to keep your private information safe!

data.name: Blog_SD_H3_Text1
data.value: By converting your private information into a secret code that hides the information's true meaning, you make it almost impossible for an intruder to decrypt it to plaintext. When an encrypted message is intercepted by an unauthorized entity, the inflator has to guess the variables that were used to encrypt the message. The time and difficulty of guessing this information is what makes encryption such a valuable security tool; take the data, run it through an encryption algorithm, and it's unreadable to anyone who doesn't possess the right key to reverse the process. Used by the military and governments, encryption is a longstanding way of protecting data in transit and data at rest as well as restricting access when access controls aren't sufficient. Few technologies come as close as encryption to nearly unbreakable data security. The use of encryption is almost as old as the art of communication itself and it provides confidentiality, authentication and integrity.

data.name: Blog_SD_H4_Text1
data.value: File encryption plays a major role in enterprises regardless of industry or size and with the complexity of cyber attacks being on continual growth, companies might consider gaining extra peace of mind and security with an encryption software. Files would not only be organized and easily accessible but also safe from threats that lurk in the virtual realm.

data.name: Blog_SD_Summary
data.value: Do you use Netflix? If you have a Netflix account, you have probably heard of the recently released documentary “The Social Dilemma”, which touches on the significant advantages of social media.

data.name: Blog_SD_Title
data.value: Social Dilemma

data.name: Blog_SSING_H1_SH1_Text1
data.value: Updates for smartphones must be installed frequently. Updates are primarily intended to correct vulnerabilities as they are found because hackers are constantly discovering new ones. Your phone isn't protected from this issue if it isn't being updated. People often use outdated phones voluntarily,however, it may also occur if the maker of the phone is no longer offering security upgrades. Whatever the reason, an outdated phone offers a security risk and shouldn't be used for anything crucial.

data.name: Blog_SSING_H1_SH2_Text1
data.value: If security is important to you, you probably only download apps directly from the Apple App Store or Google Play Store. The majority of fraudulent apps are protected from you by this, yet even these platforms have flaws. Because these platforms are so popular, malicious apps occasionally get approved, and they are frequently heavily used before being taken down. Although it is tough to prevent this issue, you can safeguard your phone by only downloading reputable apps and removing anything you don't require.

data.name: Blog_SSING_H1_SH3_Text1
data.value: A phishing page is a website that has the appearance of being trustworthy but is actually intended to steal personal data. Usually, when you attempt to get into one of your accounts, your password is taken.

data.name: Blog_SSING_H1_SH3_Text2
data.value: Smartphones are made to guard against malware, yet they provide very little defense against phishing. Even though your phone is safe, using it could still lead to a hack, so be aware of this. Always carefully examine the URL before entering personal information to avoid scam pages.

data.name: Blog_SSING_H1_SH4_Text1
data.value: Complete control over what apps are able to perform is provided by permissions. You can install malicious software and it won't be able to do anything, provided permissions are appropriately constrained. Regrettably, permissions aren't always properly utilized. Installing an app entails essentially giving it access to all of your data if you don't limit what it can access. Even with trusted apps, you should allow the fewest permissions possible to avoid this issue.

data.name: Blog_SSING_H1_SH5_Text1
data.value: Nobody can access a smartphone that has been properly locked. However, there are numerous other techniques to lock a smartphone, and the efficiency varies. Your PIN code is only as secure as it is secret if you use one. Many people enter their codes in public, which could be counterproductive.

data.name: Blog_SSING_H1_SH5_Text2
data.value: No matter what you try to stop invasions, facial recognition can also be hacked. The owner's photo may be used to unlock smartphones that are encrypted in this manner. A PIN that no one knows or fingerprint unlocking are the two options for locking a smartphone that are the most secure.
