data.name: Blog_WCACT_Conclusion_Text1
data.value: Take the time to evaluate your data protection needs and investigate the proper and efficient encryption services to take advantage of the benefits of cloud encryption. Encryption in the cloud is a critical approach to information security, according to security experts. AxCrypt also has a variety of features to meet a wide range of data security requirements.

data.name: Blog_WCACT_H1_Text1
data.value: Cloud computing uses the internet to provide a shared pool of data that can be accessed at any time. With the rise of remote work, the cloud provides greater flexibility and efficacy while also lowering expenses. Many individuals and corporations have already improved their operational efficiency while reducing IT expenditures by utilising cloud computing. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the long-awaited widespread adoption of cloud systems, including multi cloud and hybrid installations. While cloud computing brings undeniable advantages, it is nevertheless vulnerable to both inside and outside threats.

data.name: Blog_WCACT_H1_Text2
data.value: 79% of businesses have encountered at least one cloud data breach in the previous 18 months, and 43% have reported 10 or more breaches in that period.

data.name: Blog_WCACT_H2_SH1_Text1
data.value: The most prevalent hazard to cloud computing is data breaches, which result in data leaks or loss. A data breach happens when a company is targeted by hackers who get illegal access to their cloud network.

data.name: Blog_WCACT_H2_SH2_Text1
data.value: A denial of service (DoS) attack is one of the most dangerous risks to cloud services. Cybercriminals can overwhelm your system with a massive volume of web traffic that your servers can't handle. This implies that the servers will not buffer, and your employees and business as a whole will not be able to access anything on the cloud.

data.name: Blog_WCACT_H2_SH3_Text1
data.value: An attacker in a cloud system could be because of a client or employee with wide access, or it might be the result of ignorance or simple human mistake. Thus, administrators should establish high-level security designs with distinct degrees of access to cloud services to avoid malicious behaviour by an insider.

data.name: Blog_WCACT_H2_SH4_Text1
data.value: Overly liberal access controls are another prominent cause of data breaches in cloud systems. Proper implementation of access controls within your cloud environment may considerably minimise risk exposure. To avoid any kind of credential leakage, organisations must implement a proper key management system. AxCrypt has a number of characteristics that make it a good key management solution.Read more about AxCrypt key management

data.name: Blog_WCACT_H3_Text1
data.value: Cloud users must implement security measures to safeguard their sensitive data from cyber-attacks. Encryption is one of the most effective data security methods, scrambling the information of any system, database, or file in such a way that it is difficult to understand by any third party without the key. Companies can guarantee that only authorised users have access to sensitive data by using encryption and proper key management systems. Encrypted data is illegible and practically worthless without its key, even if it is lost, stolen, or accessed without authorisation.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H1_Text1
data.value: Cyberattacks are becoming increasingly frequent and advanced, causing disruptions, reputational harm, and financial losses for businesses across all industries. Regardless of the business size, protecting data and maintaining business continuity is paramount. Without a proactive approach to data security for business, organizations risk not only financial losses but the very trust and loyalty of their customers. By prioritizing cybersecurity in 2025, businesses can encrypt business files, safeguard sensitive data, and prevent cyber threats before they escalate.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H1_Text2
data.value: Here are the reasons why investing in cybersecurity is important:

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text1
data.value: 1. Protecting Sensitive Data

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text10
data.value: Businesses increasingly depend on cloud providers for data storage and system operations, a trend accelerated by remote work and the need for flexible infrastructure. While cloud providers offer basic security, additional safeguards tailored to your organization’s needs are essential. Investments in custom cybersecurity measures ensure that your business remains secure across cloud environments, protecting data stored on third-party platforms.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text2
data.value: Safeguarding confidential data — from customer information to financial records, is crucial today. Breaches can result in the unauthorized exposure of sensitive information, leading to reputational damage and regulatory penalties. Business data protection tools like encryption, intrusion detection, and robust firewall systems are essential to secure data, ensuring your business is shielded from unauthorized access and preventing the risks of a breach.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text3
data.value: 2. Safeguarding Brand Reputation

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text4
data.value: A security breach does more than harm your bottom line; it directly impacts your brand's reputation. Customers value data privacy, and many will avoid brands that have been compromised. By investing in cybersecurity solutions 2025, you demonstrate a commitment to protecting your clients’ information, reinforcing trust in your business and its practices. Data security for businesses isn’t just about compliance — it’s about maintaining trust and safeguarding your most valuable asset: your reputation.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text5
data.value: 3. Ensuring Compliance with Regulations

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text6
data.value: Regulatory bodies, including GDPR, HIPAA, and PCI-DSS, have strict guidelines for handling sensitive data. Cybersecurity measures are not only beneficial but often required by law. Investing in comprehensive data protection ensures your business meets these standards, avoiding costly fines and legal consequences.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text7
data.value: 4. Minimizing Operational Downtime

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text8
data.value: Cyberattacks can bring operations to a halt, affecting business productivity and incurring recovery costs. Investing in cybersecurity solutions like disaster recovery, regular backups, and staff training can mitigate these impacts, helping maintain business continuity even in the face of a cyber incident.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H2_Text9
data.value: 5. Addressing Cloud Vulnerabilities

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H3_Text1
data.value: Businesses, especially small businesses are particularly vulnerable to cyberattacks, as they often lack dedicated cybersecurity teams and resources. According to recent studies, nearly half of cyberattacks target small businesses due to this very vulnerability. Data breaches or ransomware attacks can be devastating for small businesses, with the potential to disrupt operations and drain resources.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H3_Text2
data.value: If you’re a small business owner, investing in cybersecurity solutions can help prevent cyber threats and protect your organization from catastrophic losses. Business data protection measures such as encrypting business files and implementing comprehensive data security for business practices can provide crucial resilience in today’s risk-filled digital landscape.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H3_Text3
data.value: By using tools like AxCrypt encryption software, you can secure sensitive data, ensuring that even in the event of an attack, your critical information remains protected.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H3_Text4
data.value: For more insights on cybersecurity for small businesses, see our related blog post here.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H4_Text1
data.value: Encryption is not a standalone solution for cybersecurity, it is a foundational layer of defense.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H4_Text2
data.value: Imagine a scenario where sensitive customer details, financial records, or proprietary designs fall into the wrong hands. The damage is not just financial—it’s reputational. Encryption is the hero of this story, acting as a powerful shield in the fight against cyberattacks. By transforming data into unreadable code, encryption ensures that even in the face of a breach, your information remains secure.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H4_Text3
data.value: This is where AxCrypt encryption software steps in, redefining what encryption can do. Think of it as more than just a security tool—it’s your partner in safeguarding your business. With the advanced AES 256-bit encryption, AxCrypt protects files, whether stored locally or on platforms like Dropbox, Google Drive, or OneDrive. Picture teams seamlessly collaborate without fear, thanks to AxCrypt’s feature that allows secure file sharing through individual passwords.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H4_Text4
data.value: With data security for businesses becoming more essential in 2025, AxCrypt helps encrypt business files, ensuring that sensitive data remains secure from cyber threats and breaches. Cybersecurity solutions 2025 require more than just basic protection—AxCrypt offers the peace of mind that comes with robust encryption.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H4_Text5
data.value: For businesses, managing who gets access is often a puzzle. AxCrypt simplifies this with group-level key management, ensuring only authorized users can view sensitive files. Add to that the convenience of mobile encryption for securing files on the go and an integrated password manager to keep credentials safe and strong.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_H4_Text6
data.value: AxCrypt doesn’t just provide encryption—it offers peace of mind, enabling businesses to focus on growth while staying ahead of cybersecurity threats.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_Text1
data.value: Cyber threats are no longer rare—they’ve become a constant challenge for data security for businesses across every industry.

data.name: Blog_WCSBYTP_Text2
data.value: A few recent incidents underscore the risks: a February ransomware attack disrupted U.S. healthcare operations for weeks, halting claims processing across numerous hospitals and pharmacies. Later, Ascension Health faced similar challenges, diverting emergency care due to a cyber intrusion. More recently, software provider CDK Global fell victim to a ransomware attack that shut down thousands of car dealerships for nearly two weeks. These events reveal the tactics of cybercriminals. Hence, the need to strengthen data security for businesses is urgent.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_Conclusion_Text
data.value: Decryption, while often overlooked compared to encryption, is essential for maintaining both data security and accessibility. AxCrypt, the most trusted encryption software, offers a reliable and easy-to-use solution for handling both encryption and decryption.Its simple interface and compatibility with multiple operating systems make it a practical tool for both individuals and businesses. By choosing AxCrypt, you’re investing in both security and productivity, ensuring your data is safe, accessible, and compliant with industry standards.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H1_Text1
data.value: The decryption process involves several steps to convert ciphertext back into readable plaintext. Here’s a simplified overview:

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H1_Text2
data.value: 1. Input: The process begins with encrypted data (ciphertext) and a decryption key. The key must match the encryption key used initially to ensure successful decryption.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H1_Text3
data.value: 2. Algorithm: A decryption algorithm is applied to the ciphertext using the decryption key. This algorithm reverses the encryption process, transforming the scrambled data back into its original form.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H1_Text4
data.value: 3. Output: The result is plaintext data that can be read and understood by authorized users. This restored data is now accessible and usable.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H1_Text5
data.value: Decryption algorithms vary depending on whether symmetric or asymmetric encryption was used. The key is crucial for this process, as it ensures that the data can be correctly decoded.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H2_Text1
data.value: 1. Data Accessibility: Decryption ensures that authorized users can access the data they need when they need it. Whether it's a critical business document, a personal file, or sensitive customer information, decryption is the only way to make it usable.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H2_Text2
data.value: 2. Data Recovery: In the event of data loss or corruption, decryption is often the only way to recover lost information. Encrypted backups can be decrypted and restored to their original state, minimizing the impact of data disasters.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H2_Text3
data.value: 3. Compliance with Regulations: Many industries have strict data privacy and security regulations, such as GDPR, HIPAA, and CCPA. These regulations often require organizations to encrypt sensitive data and ensure that only authorized individuals can access it. Decryption plays a crucial role in meeting these compliance requirements.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H2_Text4
data.value: 4. Secure Communication: Decryption is essential for secure communication. When encrypted data is transmitted over a network, it's rendered unintelligible to eavesdroppers. However, decryption ensures that the intended recipient can access the message and understand its contents.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text1
data.value: Decrypt a Folder

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text10
data.value: 1. Select the file you want to decrypt from your phone’s storage or a cloud drive link.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text11
data.value: 2. The file will be decrypted and restored to its original format.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text12
data.value: Note:

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text13
data.value: • You need an AxCrypt account and the AxCrypt app to open or decrypt encrypted files.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text14
data.value: • Even after you delete or uninstall the AxCrypt app, AxCrypt encrypted files will still have the .axx extension.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text15
data.value: • You can decrypt encrypted files on any system using the file password that was used to encrypt them.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text16
data.value: • If you're having trouble decrypting files, you can email AxCrypt support at support@axcrypt.net.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text2
data.value: 1. Open the AxCrypt app and go to the Secured Folders tab.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text3
data.value: 2. Right-click on the folder you wish to decrypt.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text4
data.value: 3. Select Decrypt Permanently to remove encryption from the folder and its contents.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text5
data.value: Decrypt an AXX File

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text6
data.value: 1. Right-click the .axx file you want to decrypt.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text7
data.value: 2. Choose AxCrypt > Decrypt from the context menu.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text8
data.value: 3. Alternatively, to view the file without decrypting, go to File > Open Secured in the AxCrypt app.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SH1_Text9
data.value: Decrypt a File on a Mobile Device

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_SubHeading1
data.value: Here are some simple methods to decrypt files using AxCrypt, whether you're working with individual files, folders, or even mobile devices:

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_Text1
data.value: AxCrypt ensures secure decryption by implementing several layers of protection to safeguard your data and prevent unauthorized access during the decryption process. Here’s how it helps:

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_Text2
data.value: 1. AES-256 Encryption Standard: AxCrypt uses AES-256 encryption to ensure strong protection of files. The same encryption key that encrypted the data is used for decryption, ensuring only authorized users can access the decrypted file.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_Text3
data.value: 2. Key Sharing: When sharing encrypted files, AxCrypt allows you to securely share access via encryption keys, not passwords. Only the recipient with the correct decryption key can access the file, ensuring that only authorized users can decrypt it. No need to share passwords separately.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_Text4
data.value: 3. Access Control: With key sharing, the sender controls who can decrypt the file. The shared encryption key is sent securely, and only the person granted access can decrypt the file, ensuring that unauthorized individuals cannot view it.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_H3_Text5
data.value: 4. Encrypted Local Storage: AxCrypt also ensures secure decryption by storing the encryption keys and other sensitive information in encrypted form on the device, preventing unauthorized access.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_Heading1
data.value: How Decryption Works

data.name: Blog_WDMME_Heading2
data.value: The Importance of Decryption

data.name: Blog_WDMME_Heading3
data.value: How AxCrypt Help in Secure Decryption

data.name: Blog_WDMME_Summary
data.value: Imagine a busy office where confidential documents—like financial reports and client information—are constantly shared. Encryption keeps this data secure by scrambling it to prevent cybersecurity threats. But when the right person needs to access the information, decryption steps in to unlock and restore it to its original form.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_Text1
data.value: Imagine a busy office where confidential documents—like financial reports and client information—are constantly shared. Encryption keeps this data secure by scrambling it to prevent cybersecurity threats. But when the right person needs to access the information, decryption steps in to unlock and restore it to its original form.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_Text2
data.value: While encryption often takes the spotlight, decryption is equally vital. It’s the process that ensures you can access your data when you need it, recover lost files, and stay compliant with regulations like GDPR rights, HIPAA, and CCPA. In short, a solid data security plan needs both encryption and decryption working together.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_Text3
data.value: Decryption is what keeps your sensitive data safe, protects your privacy, and helps you meet all regulations. AxCrypt is ahead of the curve, offering secure file transfers and reliable decryption. Want to learn more? Read on to see how AxCrypt makes decryption easier and keeps your data both safe and accessible.

data.name: Blog_WDMME_Title
data.value: Why Decryption Matters as Much as Encryption

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_Conclusion_Text3
data.value: Applying encryption at the Olympic Games 2024 ensures peace of mind, allowing you to be fully present without the worry of data breaches. Such breaches can significantly impact both spectators and athletes. With AxCrypt, you can capture and securely store your Olympic Games experience. Secure your participation by signing up for AxCrypt today and enjoy a 30-day free trial along with a 20% discount for the Olympics. Start protecting your Olympic experience now!

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text1
data.value: Secure Sensitive Data: Traveling to the Olympic Games 2024 requires sharing sensitive information at various points, such as airports, hotels, and event venues. Encryption protects against data breaches and ensures your data remains secure. If a device is lost, encryption keeps your tickets, reservations, and personal information protected. With AxCrypt, these documents will be accessible on any linked device.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text10
data.value: • Enhanced Security: Generates strong, unique passwords for each account.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text11
data.value: • Multi-device Access: Syncs across devices, allowing access from your smartphone, tablet, and laptop.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text2
data.value: Protection Against Unsecured Public Wi-Fi: When traveling, we constantly need our devices. Encryption protects data when connecting to public Wi-Fi. It ensures all data transmitted over Wi-Fi remains unreadable to cybercriminals. Without encryption, data interception on unsecured Wi-Fi could result in personal data being compromised, such as:

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text3

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text4
data.value: • Personal information: Names, addresses, phone numbers, and other identifying details.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text5
data.value: • Sensitive communications: Emails, messages, and other data.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text6
data.value: Easy Access and Sharing: Sharing documents and confidential information securely is crucial for both spectators and athletes. Whether attending as a family, group of friends, or team of athletes, secure communication is essential. Encryption ensures that sensitive information like tickets, reservations, and locations can be shared only with trusted recipients.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text7
data.value: It also protects memories captured through pictures and videos, ensuring they remain private. Athletes are significant targets for data breaches, making secure communications within teams vital to avoid compromising performance.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text8
data.value: Password Management: Password management is essential during the Olympic Games 2024. Nearly 81% of data breaches occur due to weak passwords. Attending the Olympics involves accessing multiple accounts, each requiring a password. Encryption protects flight tickets, Olympic Games tickets, and reservations. Password management provides:

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H1_Text9
data.value: • Centralized Password Storage: Securely stores all passwords in one place.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H2_Text1
data.value: • Encryption at Rest: AxCrypt's 256-bit AES keeps stored data secure, protecting all private documents needed for the Games.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H2_Text2
data.value: • Secured Folders: Important documents, such as tickets and reservations, can be stored in secured folders accessible only to authorized individuals.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H2_Text3
data.value: • End-to-End Encryption for Data in Transit: Ensures secure communications for both athletes and spectators.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_H2_Text4
data.value: • Password Manager: AxCrypt offers a secure password manager feature, helping travelers keep track of their passwords securely.

data.value: Here’s how encryption can enhance your Olympic Games 2024 experience:

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_Heading2
data.value: Apply AxCrypt’s Security Measures at the Olympic Games 2024:

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_Summary
data.value: Imagine capturing Olympic memories without worrying about data breaches! The Olympic Games of 2024, the most prestigious sporting event of the year, will see 12 million spectators, 10,000 athletes, and 30,000 volunteers converging in Paris. However, with such a massive gathering, the event becomes an attractive target for cybercriminals.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_Text1
data.value: Imagine capturing Olympic memories without worrying about data breaches! The Olympic Games of 2024,The Olympic Games of 2024, the most prestigious sporting event of the year, will see 12 million spectators, 10,000 athletes, and 30,000 volunteers converging in Paris. However, with such a massive gathering, the event becomes an attractive target for cybercriminals.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_Text2
data.value: The sheer volume of personal and sensitive information exchanged during the Olympics creates numerous opportunities for malicious actors to exploit vulnerabilities. Ensuring robust data security is essential to protect against potential threats and allow everyone involved to focus on the excitement and spirit of the Games.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_Text3
data.value: Christophe Thivet, director at Atos of the technological integration of the 2024 Games, commented on the cyber threats faced during previous Olympic Games: “In Tokyo, there were 450 million attacks, eight times more than in Rio in 2016. And 4.4 billion threats, or 800 threats per second.”

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_Text4
data.value: Attending the Olympic Games 2024 in Paris will require carrying sensitive information, such as travel documents, financial information, and personal data. Whether you are attending as a spectator or an athlete, the use of encryption will enhance your experience by alleviating concerns about data breaches, allowing you to focus completely on the games.

data.name: Blog_WDSPOG_Title
data.value: Win Data Security at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games

data.name: Blog_WENTI_Conclusion_Text1
data.value: As the frequency and severity of cyberattacks rise, IT companies must continue to innovate and lead the way in cyber security. Tech companies, as the first line of defense for all organizations, have a responsibility to stay ahead of cyber risk and ensure that their own security is the best available.

data.name: Blog_WENTI_H1_Text1
data.value: Telecommunications providers, software developers, and managed security service providers are all part of the IT and communications sector. According to studies, the IT sector was the most targeted industry internationally in 2021. The most popular means of an attempted break-in was via email, with businesses receiving an average of 600 unique phishing e-mails every month. Since the tech industry is the first to adopt new technologies, making it particularly vulnerable to cyber-attacks. According to reports, security threats against industrial control systems (ICS) and operational technology (OT) more than tripled since 2020.

data.name: Blog_WENTI_H2_Text1
data.value: In 2021, researchers have seen 50% more attacks per week on corporate networks compared to 2020. Companies have discovered encryption as one of the best, most efficient, and practical ways to ensure that their sensitive data is protected from everyone, including tech personnel so that only the owner has access to it. In turn, if hackers gain access to a server and steal a user's data, all they have is an unreadable cache of data. Encryption is critical to personal safety as well as enhancing the company’s overall security.

data.name: Blog_WENTI_H3_Text1
data.value: With an increase in ransomware at IT service providers, IT industries can also utilize Zero-Knowledge Encryption for data security which means that no one, but you (not even the service provider) can access your secured data. Even if files are completely encrypted, if the server has access to the keys, centralized hack attacks can result in an unrecoverable data breach. Zero-Knowledge standards enhance end-to-end encryption as it ensures that no one has access to your files and encryption keys in a readable format. It is one of the most secure ways to protect data privacy online.

data.name: Blog_WENTI_H4_Text1
data.value: AxCrypt is designed to provide advanced encryption in a simplistic manner on multiple cloud storage services such as Google Drive, One Drive, Dropbox, etc. AxCrypt provides AES 256 bit, the strongest encryption, and guarantees that risks are at bay without compromising the company's productivity. AxCrypt also ensures your organization stays compliant with regulations like the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) which concerns the protection of personal data and individual rights. Some of the AxCrypt features make it the best encryption solution for the IT industry.

data.name: Blog_WENTI_H4_Text2
data.value: Password Manager - With the AxCrypt password manager feature you can store all your passwords and codes in our cloud in a secure manner. For more information, watch our tutorial.

data.name: Blog_WENTI_H4_Text3
data.value: Key sharing - It allows secured files to be opened by other AxCrypt users with their own passwords. Users can send an encrypted file via email, which means that the file can only be accessed with a unique key. For more info on the AxCrypt key, sharing check our key sharing tutorial

data.name: Blog_WENTI_H4_Text4
data.value: Mobile Encryption - With the AxCrypt mobile encryption you can secure your data on Google Drive Files and Dropbox with just one click on your iOS and Android devices. Try a one-month free trial: Download for Android or iOS

data.name: Blog_WENTI_H4_Text5
data.value: Cloud Storage - With AxCrypt it is very easy to accomplish data privacy in the cloud. AxCrypt will automatically find what Cloud Storage services are installed on your computer and create an AxCrypt folder there. We make it easy for you to automatically view and keep the files secured on these folders.

data.name: Blog_WENTI_Summary
data.value: Telecommunications providers, software developers, and managed security service providers are all part of the IT and communications sector. According to studies, the IT sector was the most targeted industry internationally in 2021.

data.name: Blog_WENTI_Title
data.value: Why is encryption necessary in the tech industry?

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Heading1
data.value: Why can’t I reset my password to open my files?

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Summary
data.value: Warning – this is a rather technical post ;-) It’s only for those really interested in some of the inner workings of AxCrypt.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text1
data.value: Our support people relatively frequently get questions, demands and sometimes even harsh words about why a forgotten password means loss of information.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text10
data.value: To decrypt a file, you must know the password.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text11
data.value: If you have encrypted a file, and subsequently lose the password, the file contents are lost.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text12
data.value: It’s as simple as that.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text13
data.value: Do not forget or lose your password!

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text14
data.value: If this is not what you’re looking for, you should not be using encryption.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text2
data.value: This is what encryption is about, and what it’s all about!

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text3
data.value: Contrary to for example your email, when you use a password with AxCrypt to encrypt or decrypt files, it’s not used to control your access to the files. Your email provider uses your password to verify that it’s actually you signing in, and if you provide the right password, the software has been programmed to allow the access. If you enter the wrong password, it’ll deny the access. It’s just software making decisions based on the password you provide.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text4
data.value: With encryption it’s different.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text5
data.value: Encryption takes your password, and then uses it as a controlling parameter to a very complex algorithm that transforms your file to something completely different. If it’s good encryption (and AxCrypt is) the result will be such that nothing about the original content can be derived except a little bit about the size. Not even the size can very reliably be determined from an AxCrypt-encrypted file, since it also applies compression before encryption.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text6
data.value: An encrypted file is actually ‘physically’ transformed using encryption. After encryption, the file is completely different from the original. The only way to transform it back to the original content, is to apply the encryption in reverse. In order to do this, the correct password must be supplied.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text7
data.value: There is no software making a decision, comparing the provided password with the correct one. The software just simply tries to apply the decryption algorithm using the provided password. Before encrypting, some special values are added to the data, so when trying the decryption, the software can decide if the result is the correct one or not – but that’s the only ‘decision’ the software makes, and changing that does not change the fact.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text8
data.value: Either the decryption works because the correct password was given, or it does not work because the wrong password was used.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Text9
data.value: With AxCrypt, we don’t know your password.

data.name: Blog_WEROA_Title
data.value: What encryption really is about

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Summary
data.value: Warning – this is a rather technical post ;-) It’s only for those really interested in some of the inner workings of AxCrypt.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text1
data.value: Warning – this is a rather technical post ;-) It’s only for those really interested in some of the inner workings of AxCrypt.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text10
data.value: • The file data is encrypted using AES and the session key.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text11
data.value: • The session key is encrypted with your password, using a special key wrap algorithm, with AES at the core. This encrypted session key is added to the encrypted file.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text12
data.value: • The session key is encrypted with your AxCrypt ID public key, using RSA-4096. This encrypted session key is added to the encrypted file.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text13
data.value: • The session key is encrypted with the AxCrypt ID public key of any other AxCrypt users you’ve chosen to key share the file with. These encrypted session keys are addded to the encrypted file.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text14
data.value: To decrypt a file, AxCrypt in principle does the following:

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text15
data.value: • Take your password, find the session key encrypted with a password above, and try to decrypt it. If successful, the decrypted session key is used to decrypt the file.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text16
data.value: • Take your private AxCrypt ID key, find all session keys encrypted with an AxCrypt ID public key, and try to decrypt each. If anyone is successful, the decrypted session key is used to decrypt the file.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text17
data.value: The key pair is typically generated on our server when an account is created. The private key is temporarily encrypted using our local system key. Once you sign on and set your password, we re-encrypt it using your password.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text18
data.value: The private key, when encrypted, is actually encrypted as an AxCrypt file of course – but only using your password to encrypt the session key as above. We don’t use any public keys for this encryption.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text19
data.value: Normally, then, the process is:

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text2
data.value: Actually, it’s more than that. Technically, an AxCrypt ID is a RSA-4096 key pair.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text20
data.value: • You sign up for an account. We generate and create a key pair on our server, and encrypt the private key temporarily.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text21
data.value: • You set your password. We re-encrypt the private key with your password. At this point no-one can recover your private key without knowing your password. Not we, not anyone else.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text22
data.value: • You sign in with an AxCrypt app. The app contacts our server, and downloads the key pair – both private and public keys from the server. The private key is kept encrypted.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text23
data.value: • Whenever opening a file using your sign in password fails, AxCrypt will decrypt the private key, and attempt to decrypt the session key as described above. This will enable you to open files key shared with you, as well as older files encrypted with an earlier password if you have changed the password since then (note: changed – not reset).

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text24
data.value: Changing your AxCrypt ID password in effect means that we take your private key, decrypt it using the old password and then re-encrypt it using the new password. This is how a password change will enable you to open old AxCrypt-encrypted files. Note that they will still in fact open using the old password as well! This is also why you are never dependent on our servers. If you know the original password, you can always open the file. If you have a synchronized copy of the encrypted private key available, you can open any file as long as you have the current password.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text25
data.value: All of this key management is done automatically and behind the scenes by AxCrypt, entirely transparently as long as you allow AxCrypt to access our servers.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text26
data.value: For advanced users who fully understand the above mechanisms, it is possible to do all of this without our servers. It’s possible to generate AxCrypt ID key pairs, export them, import them etc. We do not recommend anyone to actually do this, since a mistake or misunderstanding easily can lead to data loss or inability to use AxCrypt.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text3
data.value: A key pair is a concept used in public key, or asymmetric, cryptography. In this type of cryptography there are two, related keys with the following properties:

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text4
data.value: • A public key – this key is non-secret and can be used by anyone to encrypt data. But it can’t be used to decrypt anything! We sometimes call this a sharing key.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text5
data.value: • A private key – this key must be secret and is required in order to decrypt any data encrypted using the public key. We sometimes call this a secret key.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text6
data.value: • Knowing the public key, it is computationally infeasible (i.e. impossible in layman terms) to derive the private key.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text7
data.value: When we encrypt any file using AxCrypt, we do so using AES-128/-256. This is a symmetrical strong encrypting algorithm, with a single key used for both encryption and decryption.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text8
data.value: The process in principle when AxCrypt encrypts a file is as follows:

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Text9
data.value: • A random 128- or 256-bit session key is generated for each time a file is encrypted.

data.name: Blog_WIAAI_Title
data.value: What is an AxCrypt ID?

data.name: Blog_WICE_AD_Text1
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\27A3';"> Data is accessible anywhere and anytime, as it is stored on the cloud network.

data.name: Blog_WICE_AD_Text2
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\27A3';"> No compromise in security; data is protected as it moves in and out of cloud-based applications or with the end user.

data.name: Blog_WICE_AD_Text3
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\27A3';"> Meets the encryption requirements of regulatory standards such as HIPAA and GDPR.

data.name: Blog_WICE_AD_Text4
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\27A3';"> Trust and privacy for the organization is increased by the use of powerful cloud security encryption.

data.name: Blog_WICE_AD_Text5
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\27A3';"> Cloud computing has increased flexibility in terms of jobs. Remote work has increased, making it easier for employees to access critical business applications anywhere in the world. Data in the cloud is encrypted and shared with your remote workers only during business hours. Once the office workers have logged out, the information becomes completely useless to anyone.

data.name: Blog_WICE_AD_Text6
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\27A3';"> Data breaches are almost impossible, even if someone steals the data, it is impossible for them to read as it is in encrypted form.

data.name: Blog_WICE_AD_Text7
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\27A3';"> In case of any disaster, data is safe in the cloud storage. Data is easily available to keep running the operation.

data.name: Blog_WICE_Advantages
data.value: Advantages of cloud encryption:

data.name: Blog_WICE_H1_Text1
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\2714';"> Cloud encryption protects data regardless of whether it is stored or transmitted. Round the clock, cloud encryption prevents unauthorized access.

data.name: Blog_WICE_H1_Text2
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\2714';"> It’s not only external access we have to be alert of, but also internal data theft. Business partners or contractors or even employees with malicious intention can either damage or even engage in data breach. Cloud encryption protects and helps prevent employees from harming business.

data.name: Blog_WICE_H1_Text3
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\2714';"> It has been viewed that APIs with weak security protocols introduce cloud-based security risk during data transfer, which in turn provides unauthorized access to cybercriminals looking to steal data. Cloud encryption services help in reducing the risks posed by insecure APIs and prevent sensitive data from falling into the wrong hands, even in the event of a leak.

data.name: Blog_WICE_H1_Text4
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\2714';"> The sudden rise in usage of remote workplaces has increased cybercriminals tremendously as hackers insert malicious packets as local traffic and import them into an organization's cloud database using illegal methods. Nevertheless, when cloud data is encrypted, it becomes almost impossible to steal or modify it.

data.name: Blog_WICE_H1_Text5
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\2714';"> Nowadays, multiple devices are used and transferring data through these devices creates another susceptibility. Using cloud encryption, none of the information will be available without a decryption key

data.name: Blog_WICE_H1_Text6
data.value: <li style="list-style-type: '\2714';"> Cloud encryption is not just a secure solution for sharing and storing data. It is also configured to meet internal organizational constraints and relevant regulatory authorities, such as the Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA), Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS), Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), and Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI/DSS).

data.name: Blog_WICE_H2_SH1_Text1
data.value: According to the Cloud Security Alliance's Cloud Adoption Practices and Priorities Survey report, 34% of organizations are avoiding the cloud, as their IT experts don’t have the knowledge and experience to meet cloud service requirements. Most of the enterprises have three to four clouds, creating complexity and hence technical knowledge and relevant experience is mandatory.

data.name: Blog_WICE_H2_SH2_Text1
data.value: Differences in cloud platforms make data encryption a stumbling block. The cloud platform has three models: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), Platform as a Service (PaaS), and Software as a Service (SaaS). These models perform different tasks to secure huge amounts of data. As these models are different, encryption methods become complicated and makes it burdensome for the cloud service provider of an organization to maintain and perform various encryption processes.

data.name: Blog_WICE_H2_SH3_Text1
data.value: In the IT era, the most dangerous concern facing us is: Data Breach. It is a critical issue which has to be addressed proactively. If data is not handled properly, it opens your business up to huge compliance risks. It is your responsibility to protect your customer and employee data.

data.value: In encryption, key management is the most challenging issue. Key management is the process of protecting encryption keys against loss, unauthorized use, and corruption. Key management requires extreme attention and hence, most of the time, organizations avoid adopting encryption.

data.name: Blog_WICE_Text1
data.value: In the era of multiple platforms cloud services have become the best model in providing storage, computing and networking resources. The survey specifies that more than 2 billion users currently use cloud storage to store various types of information or credential data. Due to the huge usage of cloud services, it is necessary that data stored in the cloud is protected and secure. When data is stored on a cloud, we no longer have complete control over what happens to our data. For example, if we are running an application in a hybrid or public cloud, we are forced to rely on a third party and our data gets exposed. So, it is mandatory that the best cloud service provider should be selected by one who understands their responsibility when it comes to security.

data.name: Blog_WICE_Text2
data.value: Credibility and security are among the most important obstacles cloud administrators face. Multiple cyber-attacks and security breaches also occur in cloud storage. Hence, cloud security is the biggest concern for cloud storage as data privacy risks grow.

data.name: Blog_WICE_Text3
data.value: Cloud encryption is the process of converting customer data into encrypted text using encryption algorithms and stored in the cloud. It is a data security process where plaintext data is encoded into unreadable ciphertext to keep it secure within or between cloud environments. It has been observed that cloud computing is often far more secure than traditional computing. Using cloud encryption management tools, your personal business information is provided with cloud security, protecting you from access of unauthorized parties. AxCrypt is the best encryption software to protect cloud storage data from cyber-attacks while in transit or at rest.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H1_Text1
data.value: The importance of cybersecurity increases rapidly due to the increased number of internet users with both sensitive or confidential data. Cyber threats are increasing immensely, $1 trillion in accordance to the survey (2022 Global Digital Trust Insights Survey and organizations expect risks to grow continually. The issue is made even worse by the increase in the quantity and level of sophistication of cyber threats and attack methodologies. Companies employ cyber security help procedures to safeguard themselves against phishing scams, ransomware attacks, identity theft, data breaches, and monetary losses.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H1_Text2
data.value: This is where encryption plays a major role. Encryption protects private data and sensitive data and improves the security of communication between client applications and servers. If the data is encrypted, hackers or any unauthorized person or entity would not be able to read it. Encryption is a cyber security measure that protects private and personal information by using unique codes that scramble the information and make it impossible for intruders to read. Despite a data breach, encryption ensures the security of an organization's private information, even if attackers bypass the firewall.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H2_SH1_Text1
data.value: • Information Security: protects the integrity and privacy of data both during storage and transmission, unauthorized access, including inspection, modification, storage, disconnection or destruction. The main purpose is in ensuring the security and privacy of critical information, such as customer account information, financial information or intellectual property.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H2_SH1_Text2
data.value: • Application Security: Nowadays applications are accessed through various channels/networks and connected to the cloud. Hence the vulnerability of breaches are at a higher end. Focusing on protecting software and devices against threats, AxCrypt provides applications within applications themselves.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H2_SH1_Text3
data.value: • Network Security: is the practice of protecting a computer network from intruders, whether targeted attackers or opportunistic malware. It ensures in securing customer information and data, securing shared information and reliable usage, as well as protecting against cyber threats. AxCrypt reduces overall costs and protects organizations from costly losses resulting from data breaches or other security breaches.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H2_SH1_Text4
data.value: • Cloud Security: is all about creating secure cloud architectures and applications for businesses using cloud service providers like Amazon Web Services, Google, Azure, Rack space, etc.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H2_SH1_Text5
data.value: • Mobile Security: In this digital world mobile security is a big deal as more and more people rely on mobile devices. Businesses that use mobile devices have to use mobile security measures, so as to protect the data stored on these devices against various threats. This subdomain protects organizational and personal information stored on mobile devices such as tablets, mobile phones and laptops against various threats like unauthorized access, loss or theft of devices, malware, viruses, etc.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H2_SubHeading1
data.value: Major Cyber security purposes are:

data.name: Blog_WICS_H2_SubHeading2
data.value: <strong>Common tools used for Cybersecurity measures are:<strong>

data.name: Blog_WICS_H2_Text1
data.value: To create a sturdy defence against potential cyber-attacks, it is important that the business, people, processes and technology are designed to work together. Cyber ​​security includes techniques, processes and methods to protect computer systems, data and networks from attack. Cybersecurity is designed so as to provide multiple levels of protection across all computers, networks and software that the organization uses. Cybersecurity systems are able to detect, investigate and eliminate potential system weaknesses and vulnerabilities before a hacker or malware exploits them.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H3_SH1_Text1
data.value: • IoT Attacks: Internet of Things is the most vulnerable threat in the present time. Every computing, digital, and mechanical device that is capable of transmitting data over an internet network are IoT like; desktop, laptop, mobile phone, smart security devices, etc. Securing IoT devices is one of the biggest cyber security challenges, as access to these devices can open doors to other malicious purposes.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H3_SH1_Text2
data.value: • Ransomware Attacks: As the name specifies it involves hacking a user's data and ceasing access to it until the ransom is paid. Ransomware attacks are critical for both individual and business users. Business users won’t be able to access data for their daily operations. Most of the time it has been observed, the ransomware attackers do not release information even after the payment is made, but instead try to extort more money.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H3_SH1_Text3
data.value: • Cloud Attack: Cloud services are used drastically for personal and professional needs. Hacking cloud platforms to steal user data is also one of the cyber security challenges for individuals and businesses. We are all aware of the infamous iCloud hack that exposed the private photos of celebrities. If such an attack is made against the company's data, it can pose a huge threat to the organization and even lead to its collapse. Hence it is mandatory to consider many aspects of cloud security and data protection to keep sensitive data protected.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H3_SH1_Text4
data.value: • Phishing Attack: Phishing is a social media attack used to steal user information, login credentials and credit card numbers. Hackers use it for online shopping and illegal money transfers. Google has officially released a statement about how it blocks more than 100 million phishing https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/identity-security/protecting-against-cyber-threats-during-covid-19-and-beyond emails every day.

data.name: Blog_WICS_H3_SH1_Text5
data.value: • Cryptocurrency and Blockchain attacks:Digital currency or wallets have become a prime target for hackers. The growth of this new technology has revolutionized physical currency, but creating many serious security challenges too. According to Fincen's report, 177 unique digital wallet addresses were used for the ransomware attacks. It is important organizations must be aware of the security issues associated with these technologies and ensure that they cannot be attacked and exploited by hackers.

data.value: The above mentioned examples are just some major examples wherein the governments of the countries have openly endorsed the idea of using 256-bit encryption for safeguarding sensitive and personal information. data.name: Blog_WIFBE_H1_Text1
data.value: In technical terms, 256-bit encryption refers to the length of the key used to encrypt (lock) and decrypt (unlock) your data. In the process of encryption, the data you chose to encrypt is firstly converted into a ciphertext from its initial stage of plaintext. Furthermore, when the data is attempted to be converted into a human-readable form.

data.name: Blog_WIFBE_H1_Text4
data.value: The 256-bit encryption tool is the most popular data security encryption tool in today’s time.One of the biggest reasons why most organizations and people prefer to protect their data using 256-bit encryption is the massive number of combinations that this encryption uses to lock your data safe and away from the hacking forces. In fact, even numerous highest-level government organizations all around the world place their faith in 256-bit encryption for securing their data against hackers because it is believed that the key length size of this type of encryption is so long that even the most sophisticated and highest-level hackers will take trillions of years just to decode the key! This makes the case of the usage of 256-bit encryption for the protection of data of the highest-level officials as well as the common people a very strong one, thus earning the title of ‘military grade encryption

data.name: Blog_WIFBE_H2_Text1
data.value: To further tilt the case in favor of 256-bit encryption and establish its supremacy over its counterparts, let us have a look at the list of some of the highest-ranking people and the organizations that have put their faith in 256-bit encryption for safeguarding their data against hacking forces.

data.name: Blog_WIFBE_H2_Text2
data.value: • The United States government was the first government to use 256-bit encryption for protecting and safeguarding their data. They approved its usage on November 26, 2001. They lead the way for others to show their faith in encryption and its capability in safeguarding precious and highly-secretive and sensitive information. Astonishingly, the government there has continued to show its faith in this encryption and the government officials still use the 256-bit encryption for safely storing their data away from the prying eyes of hackers.

data.name: Blog_WIFBE_H2_Text3
data.value: • Canada is another country that has regularly encouraged the usage of 256-bit encryption in securing the personal data of the government and the people of the country. The government of Canada has extensively promoted the usage of 256-bit encryption to safeguard the private information of the people. This has brought the country into the limelight as one of the pioneering nations in the fight against the breach of privacy by openly endorsing the idea of encryption of data using 256-bit encryption.

data.name: Blog_WIFBE_H2_Text4
data.value: • The Information and Broadcasting Ministry of the Indian Government, in its order dated February 18, 2022, has restricted its officials from exchanging top-secret documents and information over the Internet without the usage of encryption with the fear of a breach and possible leakage of sensitive information, thus jeopardizing national security. The officials have been guided to use only 256-bit encryption for the exchange of highly-sensitive and confidential information

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H1_Text1
data.value: NIS2 or the Network and Information Security Directive is an EU wide legislation to significantly strengthen cybersecurity across the member states. It lays down a stringent legal framework and extends the scope of the legislation to a wider range of sectors, including essential services like energy, healthcare, and transportation.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H1_Text2
data.value: NIS2 is the continued expansion of its preceding directive NIS1, which was first enacted in July 2016. While NIS1 laid the groundwork for improving cybersecurity standards in critical sectors, NIS2 goes further by expanding its scope, tightening requirements, and strengthening enforcement mechanisms.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text1
data.value: The following two sectors are covered under the NIS2’s obligations.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text10
data.value: Important Sectors: If an organization operates in a sector classified as ‘important’, then the compliance depends on specific criteria like size, number of users, and impact on the society. Some examples of important sectors include:

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text11
data.value: • Platform operators (online marketplaces, social media)

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text12
data.value: • Manufacturing (chemicals, pharmaceuticals)

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text13
data.value: • Food and beverage

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text14
data.value: • Public administration

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text15
data.value: For a more detailed overview, download our free step-by-step PDF guide on how to assess your organization's NIS2 compliance requirements: https://axcrypt.net/information/regulatory-compliance/nis2/

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text2
data.value: Essential Sectors: If an organization operates in any of the following explicitly listed essential sectors, then it automatically falls under NIS2 and is bound by the mandatory compliance requirements. The essential sectors include:

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text3
data.value: • Energy (electricity, gas, oil)

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text4
data.value: • Transport (airports, railways, maritime)

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text5
data.value: • Healthcare (hospitals, pharmacies)

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text6
data.value: • Finance (banks, investment firms, insurance)

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text7
data.value: • Waste management (water, waste disposal)

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text8
data.value: • Postal Services

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H2_Text9
data.value: • Digital infrastructure (data centers, internet exchanges)

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text1
data.value: Though the NIS2 raises the bar for cybersecurity across Europe, its requirements vary based on an organization's size, societal function, and exposure. Smaller businesses get some flexibility, while larger entities face stricter obligations.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text10
data.value:
• Cybersecurity Training & Hygiene:
    • Provide cybersecurity training and promote basic cyber hygiene practices among employees.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text11
data.value:
• Encryption:
    • Implement policies and procedures for using cryptography and encryption to protect sensitive data. AxCrypt offers secure file encryption and sharing solutions with AES-256.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text12
data.value:
• Employee Security:
    • Establish security procedures for employees with access to sensitive data and maintain an overview of all relevant assets.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text13
data.value:
• Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
    • Use MFA and other advanced authentication solutions whenever possible.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text14
data.value: Note: These are the minimum steps that an organization can take to start complying with the NIS2 guidelines! A consultation with a compliance officer is recommended for a more comprehensive approach specific to your organization.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text2
data.value: Despite the disparities in the requirements however, there are essential minimum measures all relevant businesses must implement, which can ensure compliance, and AxCrypt's encryption software can help you achieve some of them.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text3
data.value: Following are the minimum requirement points for any organization under NIS2.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text4
data.value:
• Risk Assessment & Security Policies:
    • Identify cyber threats and build defenses with regular risk assessments and defined security policies.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text5
data.value:
• Incident Response Plan:
    • Have a plan for handling security incidents quickly and effectively.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text6
data.value:
• Business Continuity Plan:
    • Develop a business continuity plan to ensure smooth operations even after an attack. AxCrypt can help with secure and automatic encrypted backups on clouds.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text7
data.value:
• Secure Supply Chain:
    • Manage risks associated with third-party vendors.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text8
data.value:
• Measure Security Effectiveness:
    • Regularly evaluate the effectiveness of your security measures to identify and address weaknesses.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H3_Text9
data.value:
• Secure System Procurement & Development:
    • Implement policies for handling and reporting vulnerabilities in procured systems and your own development processes.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H4_Text1
data.value: Failing to comply with the NIS2 directive before the deadline can have significant consequences for your organization, impacting finances, reputation, and even legal standing. Here's what you need to know:

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H4_Text2
data.value: Financial Penalties:

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H4_Text3
data.value: • Fines up to €10 million or 2% of your global annual turnover (whichever is higher) – a hefty burden for any organization, especially smaller businesses.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H4_Text4
data.value: • Additional administrative sanctions: These can include temporary bans on operating, limitations on data processing, and even public naming and shaming.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H4_Text5
data.value: Key Dates to Remember:

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H4_Text6
data.value: • 2019: Initiation of NIS2 development.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H4_Text7
data.value: • December 2022: Official adoption of NIS2.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H4_Text8
data.value: • October 17, 2024: Deadline for compliance

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_H4_Text9
data.value: It’s important to remember that a proactive approach can help your organization better comply with the NIS2 guidelines before the deadline, and avoid the hefty fines and sanctions that it imposes.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_Summary
data.value: In today's digital landscape, a robust cybersecurity measure is no longer optional – it's essential. Recognizing this, the European Union has expanded and built upon its previously enacted Network and Information Security Directive (NIS1), to a newer and more comprehensive version called the NIS2.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_Text1
data.value: In today's digital landscape, a robust cybersecurity measure is no longer optional – it's essential. Recognizing this, the European Union has expanded and built upon its previously enacted Network and Information Security Directive (NIS1), to a newer and more comprehensive version called the NIS2.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_Text2
data.value: This blog post will provide a detailed overview of NIS2 and its implications for businesses operating within the EU. We'll explore who falls under the directive's purview, dive into the key requirements it outlines, and offer guidance on how businesses can achieve compliance.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_Text3
data.value: Additionally, we'll discuss the potential consequences of non-compliance, empowering businesses to navigate the new regulatory landscape, and effectively protect their sensitive data.

data.name: Blog_WINAIMCR_Title
data.value: What is NIS2 and Its Minimal Compliance Requirements?

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H1_Text1
data.value: When a new account is created, it is mandatory for us to create long and strong passwords. As we use lots of websites and applications nowadays, 90% chances are that we don’t remember all of the passwords we have created. Fortunately, technology has changed and you don't have to remember all the passwords.

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H1_Text2
data.value: Password management tools are applications that help with creation, storing and quickly filling in the passwords when required. They securely store user credentials in cloud or on-premise storage and help users stay secure online by following best practices for creating and managing passwords. AxCrypt password manager generates complex passwords on demand. The tools then link passwords to specific accounts and store them securely in encrypted form. The basic purpose of a password manager is to help us manage our passwords and keep our login details safe wherever we log in. Password managers minimize the risk of the user forgetting the password and the risk of the password being exposed to malicious parties. AxCrypt password management software combines convenience and security at a competitive price, ensuring your online experience in a fast-paced digital world.

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H2_SubHeading1
data.value: • Password memorizing: The major use of password manager is, you just have to remember the master password instead of hundreds of passwords.

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H2_SubHeading2
data.value: • High security password generation: While using password manager, automatic generated password is created which is random, long, alphanumeric, and nearly impossible to guess. Complex algorithms, encryption and other methods are used to keep your credentials and passwords safe. Strong and unique passwords are generated.

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H2_SubHeading3
data.value: • Time saving: Apart from creating and storing unique passwords, password manager also automatically fills in credentials, speeding up the process and thus saving time.

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H2_SubHeading4
data.value: • Cross platform synchronization: AxCrypt password manager is capable of syncing onto both IOS and Android OS. Regardless of the platform, password access is possible using AxCrypt.

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H2_SubHeading5
data.value: • Adding Information: AxCrypt password manager also has another feature. It helps in not only storing passwords but also additional information like credit/debit card details, secure notes, address fields, contact numbers and more.

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H2_SubHeading6
data.value: • Secured password sharing:It is not recommended in sending passwords through text, instant messages or email because plain text can be intercepted, or easily found in your messages, inbox or sent folder and can be hacked. Passwords shared using a piece of paper are hard to keep track of or easily lost. Sharing using AxCrypt provides peace of mind to you because your strong and unique passwords reach only to your intended recipient(s), and with the access rights that you choose.

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H2_Text1
data.value: It is impossible for a human memory to hold dozens and dozens of passwords. Most people try to use the simplest possible password, such as “12356789” or “password123” etc. Some remember one great random password and use it for everything. Due to this simple usage of passwords, it is most likely that you might be the latest victim of identity theft. Remarkably, as years passed by, technology has immensely advanced, but more and more data is lost every second.

data.name: Blog_WIPM_H2_Text2
data.value: Password management allows individuals and businesses to store and manage all their passwords in one secure place. Individuals no longer have to remember multiple passwords. The only password a user has to remember is the one master password which is used to open the password manager. A password manager can remember all the infinite passwords for you.
