data.name: FaqAccessDenied
data.value: Why do I get ‘Access Denied’ and/or my file names are in green text?

data.name: FaqAccessDeniedAnswer1
data.value: AxCrypt is accessed via the right-click context menu, under the heading ‘AxCrypt’. There is also a built-in encryption in some versions of Windows, which is accessed in a similar way, but under the heading ‘Properties’, then the button ‘Advanced’ and finally the check box ‘Encrypt contents to secure data’. This encryption uses a feature called Encrypting File System, or EFS for short.

data.name: FaqAccessDeniedAnswer2
data.value: There are typically two reasons for getting ‘Access Denied’ messages. Both occur when files are either moved to a new system, or Windows is (re)installed on an existing system. One situation is a problem, the other is not.

data.name: FaqAccessDeniedAnswer3
data.value: If the file names in Windows Explorer are shown in black text, then you’re likely just having an NTFS ownership issue, and this is easily remedied. Please Google for ‘ntfs take ownership’ (without the quotes) to find suggested solutions.

data.name: FaqAccessDeniedAnswer4
data.value: If the file names in Windows Explorer are shown in green text, then you’ve inadvertently encrypted them with EFS. This might mean your files are lost. Please Google for ‘efs access denied’ for explanations and possible remedies.

data.name: FaqAccessDeniedAnswer5
data.value: EFS may in some cases be a useful feature, and can for some scenarios be a better solution than AxCrypt. However... Beware: There be Dragons!

data.name: FaqAccessDeniedAnswer6
data.value: Because of the way EFS is implemented, it is also likely to be the single most common cause of data loss in Windows environments. If you’re a computer security wizard, and have a full understanding of X.509 encryption certificates, and how the Windows Certificate Stores work and interact with user credentials, then you won’t have a problem as long as you’re careful to ensure backups of the appropriate certificates and keys. If, however, the previous sentence confuses you then you should probably not be using EFS because of the mentioned risk of data loss when moving files to a new system, or (re)installing Windows, or resetting passwords, or…

data.name: FaqAntivirusWarning
data.value: I got a warning from my antivirus software. Is AxCrypt infected?

data.name: FaqAntivirusWarningAnswer1
data.value: No, the official distribution does not intentionally contain anything that even remotely can be called malicious. It is very unlikely to be infected by anything unintentionally. Please read a lengthier blog post for details why we can make that statement.

data.name: FaqAnyoneCanDeleteFile
data.value: Anyone can still delete my secured files, why is that?

data.name: FaqAnyoneCanDeleteFileAnswer1
data.value: Securing a file with AxCrypt protects your information from prying eyes and undetected modification or corruption. It does not protect against destruction, willfully or by accident.

data.name: FaqAnyoneCanDeleteFileAnswer2
data.value: It bears repetition: Your protection against data loss is regular backups.

data.name: FaqAnyoneCanDeleteFileAnswer3
data.value: Technically it’s not really possible to reliably protect your data against destruction with software – except backup software. Of course, software can add safeguards that make it harder to do it by mistake, or even maliciously but in the end you can’t protect against vandals that way.

data.name: FaqAnyoneCanDeleteFileAnswer4
data.value: You should be using the NTFS file system and let every user of the computer sign in as a separate, restricted, user. No-one should normally run as administrator. This will protect your files against deletion by other users of the same computer, but it will not protect against yourself – or any agent acting on your behalf. Please remember that viruses and trojan intrusions will be acting as if on the behalf of the compromised user!

data.name: FaqAnyoneCanDeleteFileAnswer5
data.value: If your system is compromised by a virus or a trojan, your secured files will be protected from theft – but not from destruction.

data.name: FaqAnyoneCanDeleteFileAnswer6
data.value: AxCrypt is not intended to protect against destruction, and there is to our knowledge no such serious software available except backup software. Any software claiming to provide such protection should be examined carefully to understand exactly what it is it protects against and how. Always backup your data regardless of other measures taken.

data.name: FaqDamagedFile
data.value: My secured file is damaged, what can I do?

data.name: FaqDamagedFileAnswer1
data.value: If your secured file is corrupt, you will get a message which will refer to the HMAC being incorrect or some similar text.

data.name: FaqDamagedFileAnswer2
data.value: This message implies that the file is recognized by AxCrypt, and that you have entered the correct password and/or key file, and there is hope!

data.name: FaqDamagedFileAnswer3
data.value: Another message that may be seen will refer to the GUID being incorrect. This indicates a severe error in the file to the extent that it’s not even recognized as an AxCrypt file. In most cases this is because the file is simply not a file secured by AxCrypt.

data.name: FaqDamagedFileAnswer4
data.value: AxCrypt has some features for recovery of damaged files, but there are some limitations. You must also be careful, and start by marking the original (damaged) file as read-only, and then make a copy of it – and always only work on the copy!

data.name: FaqDamagedFileAnswer5
data.value: Please contact support for further instructions on how to proceed.

data.name: FaqDamagedFileAnswer6
data.value: Your protection against data loss is regular backups. Please backup all your important files – secured as well as files without security. AxCrypt is not intended to provide any protection against data loss – only against disclosure and undetected manipulation.

data.name: FaqDifference1&2
data.value: What is the difference between AxCrypt 1.x and 2.x?

data.name: FaqDifference1&2Answer1
data.value: AxCrypt 1.x is a legacy version. That means it is outdated and there is no longer any support for it, whereas AxCrypt 2.x is the version that we are continuously working on to keep improving it. It’s absolutely not recommended to use 1.x. We recommend all users, old and new, to always use the most current released version of AxCrypt, which can be downloaded here.

data.name: FaqDifference1&2Answer2
data.value: For users that have a specific need for the legacy downloads (usage at own risk), they can be found here.

data.name: FaqDifferenceStandaloneInstaller
data.value: What are the major differences between the standalone version and installer version of AxCrypt?

data.name: FaqDifferenceStandaloneInstallerAnswer1
data.value: The installer version comes with some additional features (e.g. context menu integration) compared to the lightweight, standalone version.

data.name: FaqDifferenceStandaloneInstallerAnswer2
data.value: The standalone version is directly executable – no installation is required. In this version, you will not get AxCrypt’s right click context in Explorer, nor will you be able to open files by double-clicking.

data.name: FaqEmailUsedFor
data.value: What will my email be used for when I sign up?

data.name: FaqEmailUsedForAnswer1
data.value: Your email will be used to name your AxCrypt ID, and will also be used as the name when authenticating against the server in order to access premium functionality. It may also be used to notify you of critical software updates, new features and other communications from us such as a newsletter. The AxCrypt ID itself will be used to allow others to share files securely with you without the need to share passwords, and for other possible future features such as enabling others to validate digital signatures. Since we offer premium features from a server based infrastructure, we need something to identify you by. Currently this is your email since it is universally available and accepted. In the future it may be some other moniker such as your mobile phone number, your government issued digital identity, your Twitter account etc.

data.name: FaqEmailUsedForAnswer2
data.value: We will not sell or use your email for third party communications without your explicit consent.

data.name: FaqEmailUsedForAnswer3
data.value: Please see the terms of use for more details.

data.name: FaqFileEncryptionNotWorking
data.value: File Encryption for .NET and Mono has stopped working

data.name: FaqFileEncryptionNotWorkingAnswer1
data.value: If you get an error message “File Encryption for .NET and Mono has stopped working. A problem caused the program to stop working correctly. Windows will close the program and notify you if a solution is available.” the most likely cause is a software called “Lavasoft Web Companion”. This is not compatible with modern versions of Windows, and it modifies the way the network is accessed in a way that causes AxCrypt and other programs to crash.

data.name: FaqFileEncryptionNotWorkingAnswer2
data.value: Check if you have Lavasoft Web Companion installed, and uninstall it if this is the case. If you’re still having the same problem or do not have the Lavasoft software installed, please follow the instructions and file a full error report.

data.name: FaqForgotPassword
data.value: I forgot my password. What to do?

data.name: FaqForgotPasswordAnswer1
data.value: The basic rule is: If you lose or forget your password or key-file, your documents are lost. There is no back-door into AxCrypt.

data.name: FaqForgotPasswordAnswer2
data.value: The only way to recover a lost password is to try all likely combinations.

data.name: FaqForgotPasswordAnswer3
data.value: All that being said, there is a special case where we could possibly help you. If you think you know your password, but not quite, or if it’s less than 5 characters long – then we can write and adapt a special program that will try many combinations automatically. This is called a brute force attack.

data.name: FaqForgotPasswordAnswer4
data.value: AxCrypt is specifically engineered to counter brute force attacks, and does it rather well, so this will only work when the number of combinations to try is very small, let’s say less than a million.

data.name: FaqForgotPasswordAnswer5
data.value: If you think you may be in a position where you can narrow down the possible combinations enough for us, then there is a slight chance to recover the password using a utility that will attempt to try many possibilities according to a pattern you provide. Please contact support if would like to try the brute force utility.

data.name: FaqHowLargeFileSupport
data.value: How are large files supported?

data.name: FaqHowLargeFileSupportAnswer1
data.value: AxCrypt is only limited by available hard disk space.

data.name: FaqHowManyPassesWipe
data.value: How many passes does wipe do/Why only one pass wiping?

data.name: FaqHowManyWipeAnswer1
data.value: Wipe and Delete only overwrites once with pseudo random data. We’re currently not planning to implement DoD 5220.22 (NISPOM) sanitization, nor Gutmann 35-pass secure-wipe. The cost of retrieving single-overwritten data is prohibitive as it is. If the attacker has the resources for that (as well as getting physical access to the disk) there are many easier and surer ways of getting at the data.

data.name: FaqHowManyWipeAnswer2
data.value: A PC is such an insecure and uncontrolled environment, that to use DoD-style wiping in a running system is severe overkill and misleading. Such wiping should be used prior to destruction or re-use of hard disks, and then only from a stand-alone diskette and CD so that the entire disk surface may be wiped, regardless of operating system structures. We recommend Boot and Nuke for this purpose.

data.name: FaqHowManyWipeAnswer3
data.value: The purpose of AxCrypt wiping is to protect from use of common undelete tools, not to protect from electron microscopy or special diagnostic hardware and software available to hard disc manufacturers. Wiping 35 times also takes a lot of time...

data.name: FaqHowToRenew
data.value: How do I renew my subscription?

data.name: FaqHowToRenewAnswer1
data.value: New subscribers have a subscription that will automatically renew at the end of the subscription period, using the initial payment method. To check your subscription status, login to the account site, and check it on the My AxCrypt ID page. You will see the date it renews on there.

data.name: FaqHowToRenewAnswer2
data.value: If it mentions that the subscription will expire on a certain date, you either subscribed before June 25th 2020, or you cancelled your automatic payments. In that case, you will have to renew it yourself.

data.name: FaqKeysAndPasswords
data.value: Do you have keys and passwords on your servers?

data.name: FaqKeysAndPasswordsAnswer1
data.value: Yes, but encrypted with your password which we do not store. There is no essential change in the security compared to previous versions. You must still use a strong password, and keep it secret.

data.name: FaqKeysAndPasswordsAnswer2
data.value: The only thing that must be secret with AxCrypt is your password. Nothing else, not the software, not the secured files, not the secured account keys or anything else. As long as your password is both strong and secret, your secured files remain secure. Even if our server would be compromised, the permanently stored sensitive data stored there is encrypted with your password, which we do not store.

data.name: FaqLinkLabel
data.value: FAQ

data.name: FaqPasswordRecoveryCorporate
data.value: Does AxCrypt support password recovery for corporate use?

data.name: FaqPasswordRecoveryCorporateAnswer1
data.value: If you represent a company thinking about using AxCrypt, you may be worried about the case of an employee quitting and not telling the password to his or her files. The question then is if you can set a password recovery policy?

data.name: FaqPasswordRecoveryCorporateAnswer2
data.value: If an employee quits, and refuses to give back company property your response should be to report the person to the police for theft, and/or take other legal action. This applies just as much to his laptop as the intellectual property owned by the company which is stored on the laptop or the company servers.

data.name: FaqPasswordRecoveryCorporateAnswer3
data.value: There are enterprise solutions that do implement functionality like this, but the most common reason to use AxCrypt is because of it’s simplicity to implement. Enterprise solutions demand quite a bit of infrastructure, maintenance and can be quite complex to install. Unfortunately, enterprise solutions do not really protect against disgruntled (ex-) employees anyway, although they do provide protection against accidental password loss.

data.name: FaqPasswordRecoveryCorporateAnswer4
data.value: So, AxCrypt is kept simple to use and deploy, at the cost of no password recovery. Data loss concerns should be addressed via backup procedures of both passwords and data, and issues with employees leaving without divulging passwords should be treated as any other destructive or illegal behavior by such a person.

data.name: FaqSignInWithoutPassword
data.value: How do I sign in when I have an existing account I don’t know the password for?

data.name: FaqSignInWithoutPasswordAnswer1
data.value: If you’ve just downloaded AxCrypt 2, entered your email and gotten a message that you already have an account, but don’t know the password, you need to issue a password reset. Click on the link and follow the instructions. If you’re already using a strong password for your AxCrypt files, you should consider using that as your account password.

data.name: FaqStopFromSecuring
data.value: How can I stop anyone from securing my files?

data.name: FaqStopFromSecuringAnswer1
data.value: Short answer: You can’t. Follow-up question: Why would you want to?

data.name: FaqStopFromSecuringAnswer2
data.value: If you install AxCrypt, anyone with access to your computer can secure your files. This is sometimes seen as a risk with installing AxCrypt. However, this is not the case. The real risk is with ‘…anyone with access to your computer’. Anyone who can access your computer and run an installed copy of AxCrypt, can also install AxCrypt or any other security or deletion software. Anyone who can access your computer can delete your files, and probably format your hard disk. Anyone with physical access can also throw it out the window, steal it, use it for target practice with a shotgun or any other activity that may prove detrimental to the health of your files.

data.name: FaqStopFromSecuringAnswer3
data.value: The point is that it makes no sense to restrict access to AxCrypt – it’s the access to the computer that needs to be restricted! That’s why you should always use a password protected screen saver and always have a password on your account. Because then, if your files are secured with AxCrypt, your information will stay safe even in the face of loss or theft of your computer or media with the files on.

data.name: FaqWhatHappensExpire
data.value: What happens when my subscription expires?

data.name: FaqWhatHappensExpireAnswer1
data.value: If you stop subscribing to Premium or Business, you will fall back to the Viewer or Free plan after the end of your subscription period. You won’t have to worry about your files, because you’ll never get locked out of your data.

data.name: FaqWhatHappensExpireAnswer2
data.value: With the Windows version, your files will be re-encrypted with 128-bit AES encryption, rather than the 256-bit AES algorithm that was used when you were on a subscription. If you are using AxCrypt on macOS, you will be unable to encrypt new files. You can still decrypt and view the encrypted files. The content of encrypted files can’t be updated. That means you have to either decrypt them, or get a paid subscription to keep using AxCrypt like before.

data.name: FaqWhatPlatforms
data.value: What platforms does AxCrypt run on?

data.name: FaqWhatPlatformsAnswer1
data.value: AxCrypt is currently available on most major platforms, including: Windows, MacOS, iOS and Android. For more information about platforms and system requirements, head over to Requirements.

data.name: FaqWhyPasswordSignIn
data.value: Why does AxCrypt only ask for a password during sign-in? Isn’t that insecure?

data.name: FaqWhyPasswordSignInAnswer1
data.value: While you are signed in to AxCrypt, offline or online, AxCrypt will not ask you again for the same password. This feature makes usage of AxCrypt much more convenient, and saves you from the trouble of re-entering the password every time.

data.name: FaqWhyPasswordSignInAnswer2
data.value: Security is a chain only as strong as its weakest link. In your local system, there are so many other ways to get at your data that to sacrifice the convenience of a password cache just to ‘feel’ safer, was not thought to be a good idea.

data.name: FaqWhyPasswordSignInAnswer3
data.value: But what’s then the use of AxCrypt if anyone can walk up to my PC and just double-click?

data.name: FaqWhyPasswordSignInAnswer4
data.value: Under the heading Documentation > Security > Local PC Security you will find a discussion about what is needed to protect your PC locally, and why. The important thing for this discussion is: If anyone can walk up to your PC and it’s not protected by a password-protected screen-saver you have no protection anyway! All that is needed for a would-be attacker is access to a PC with for example a diskette or CD-drive, a USB-port or an Internet connection, and it’s a few seconds work to install a keylogger or a trojan. Do not trust a PC that has been left unattended and unprotected.

data.name: FaqWhyPasswordSignInAnswer5
data.value: The second reason for the password cache is that if you do not need to enter it every time, you may actually find it reasonable to use a longer and stronger password than otherwise, thus increasing security.

data.name: FaqWhyPasswordSignInAnswer6
data.value: If you are concerned about physical access to your own computer there are other measures you should take first. If you want to, you can always sign out from AxCrypt when leaving your computer.

data.name: FaqWhySecure
data.value: Why secure files with strong encryption?

data.name: FaqWhySecureAnswer1
data.value: Why do you need encryption in order to secure your files? In two words: privacy and confidentiality.

data.name: FaqWhySecureAnswer2
data.value: As private persons, we nowadays store lots of information on our computers that is not necessarily secret, but just simply private. Many of us also at times have the need to use employer-owned computers and servers, as well as public servers, to store such information. It might be copies of electronic invoices, private letters, your CV etc.

data.name: FaqWhySecureAnswer3
data.value: In all these situations you might feel a little more comfortable knowing that regardless of physical access to the files by network administrators, service personnel or even other family members in your home network, your private information is still kept private.

data.name: FaqWhySecureAnswer4
data.value: As employees we frequently are responsible for information that is sensitive in various ways. It might be salaries if you’re a manager, or customer data if you’re in sales or support etc. This information is kept in confidence by you, and you have a responsibility to care for it as best you can.

data.name: FaqWhySecureAnswer5
data.value: In many cases it’s not really enough to just store it on the corporate network server and apply appropriate restrictive access permissions. The information and files are still always available to support staff, network administrators etc. Even if you trust your colleagues, as you should, mistakes do happen and sometimes it’s simply human to be curious. Anyone finding a file with his or her name on it will be sorely tempted to sneak a peek…

data.name: FaqWhySecureAnswer6
data.value: Finally, there are an increasing number of cases where legislation and similar rules come into play such as the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, HIPAA, where encryption of confidential data is required under certain circumstances.

data.name: FaqWhySecureAnswer7
data.value: In these and similar situations encryption programs such as AxCrypt provide a secure and convenient method to provide privacy and confidentiality as appropriate.

data.name: FaqWhyTimeStap
data.value: Why is the file time-stamp set to the time of securing the file?

data.name: FaqWhyTimeStapAnswer1
data.value: The default operation of AxCrypt when securing a plain-text file, is to store the original files time-stamps inside the secured file and to set the time-stamps of the resulting secured file to the time when it was most recently secured. The rationale for this behavior is as follows:

data.name: FaqWhyTimeStapAnswer2
data.value: Many backup and file-synchronization software programs depend on the modification time of files to determine if it has been modified since the last run. This test fails, if the secured file retains the original date of the plain-text file and at worst the file does not get copied/backed up etc.

data.name: FaqWhyTimeStapAnswer3
data.value: Good security software will ensure that securing the same file twice produces completely different secured files, to make it harder to determine if the file is the same as another file, or another earlier version of a file. If the time-stamp is retained, an attacker will get a high-precision time-stamp that more or less uniquely identifies each and every file thus leaking what might be important information about the file. (File size will remain the same, since the securing is deterministic, but this is a much weaker assertion).

data.name: FaqWhyTimeStapAnswer4
data.value: Semantically, securing a file is a transformation of the file, and this should be reflected in the time-stamp. Note that the original plain-text time-stamps still will be restored if the security is removed from the file!

data.name: FaqWhyTimeStapAnswer5
data.value: If AxCrypt ever should support multi-file archives, there’s no choice but to use the time of securing it, otherwise it’ll make it very inconsistent – which time-stamp should a multi-file AxCrypt archive which happens to contain exactly one file use (which by the way is the case today, the file format supports multiple files, but AxCrypt has not implemented this functionality yet).

data.name: GdprBenefitsHeading1
data.value: Key Benefits of Using AxCrypt for GDPR Compliance

data.name: GdprBenefitsSubHeading4
data.value: Enhanced Security

data.name: GdprBenefitsSubParagraph1
data.value: Secure your data at rest and in transit with AES-256 encryption.

data.name: GdprBenefitsSubParagraph2
data.value: Securely share encrypted files with anyone using just an email address.

data.name: GdprBenefitsSubParagraph3
data.value: Only you have access to your encryption keys; even AxCrypt cannot access your data.

data.name: GdprBenefitsSubParagraph4
data.value: Protect your data against unauthorized access, breaches, and data leaks.

data.name: GdprBenefitsSubParagraph5
data.value: Easy to use, ensuring compliance without compromising productivity.

data.name: GdprBlock1Heading
data.value: What is the GDPR?

data.name: GdprBlock1Text1
data.value: The EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is a binding legislative act concerning the protection of personal data and individual rights. The GDPR replaces the Data Protection Directive 95/46/EC.

data.name: GdprBlock1Text2
data.value: It was designed to harmonize data privacy laws across Europe, to protect and empower all EU citizens data privacy and to reshape the way organizations approach data privacy. The GDPR requires companies to implement reasonable ways to protect their data, such as encryption, to protect it against data loss or exposure.

data.name: GdprBlock1Text3
data.value: The enforcement date of the GDPR is 25 May 2018.

data.name: GdprBlock2Heading
data.value: Who is affected by it?

data.name: GdprBlock2Text1
data.value: The GDPR applies to all organizations located within the EU, or outside of the EU, processing and holding the personal data of EU citizens, in order to: offer goods or services, or monitor their behaviour within the EU.

data.name: GdprBlock3Heading
data.value: How can file encryption help towards compliance?

data.name: GdprBlock3Text1
data.value: As Recital 83 in the GDPR states:

data.name: GdprBlock3Text2
data.value: ”In order to maintain security and to prevent processing in infringement of this Regulation, the controller or processor should evaluate the risks inherent in the processing and implement measures to mitigate those risks, such as encryption.”

data.name: GdprBlock3Text3
data.value: Organizations have to make sure that their personal data is stored securely, whether on-premise or cloud-based, in order to prevent costly data breaches. Files that have been encrypted will be rendered useless when breached.

data.name: GdprBlock4Heading
data.value: What are the penalties for non-compliance?

data.name: GdprBlock4Text1
data.value: Organizations can be fined up to 4% of annual global turnover for breaching GDPR or €20 Million – whichever is greater. This is the maximum fine that can be imposed for the most serious infringements. It is important to note that these rules apply to both controllers and processors – meaning ‘clouds’ will not be exempt from GDPR enforcement.

data.name: GdprBlock5Heading
data.value: How does the GDPR handle personal data breaches?

data.name: GdprBlock5Text1
data.value: In the case of a personal data breach, the controller shall without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after having become aware of it, notify the personal data breach to the supervisory authority.

data.name: GdprBlock6Heading
data.value: What are my main responsibilities under the GDPR?

data.name: GdprBlock6Text1
data.value: If your organization handles personal data, the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) states that you are expected to put into place comprehensive but proportionate governance measures. These measures should minimize the risk of breaches and uphold the protection of personal data. The exact responsibilities that apply are different for every organization, depending on its size, industry and what kind of data is being stored.

data.name: GdprBlock7Heading
data.value: Is my website GDPR compliant?

data.name: GdprBlock7Text1
data.value: According to vpnMentor as little as 34% of websites in the EU are currently GDPR compliant. “Most of the websites either have old privacy policies, and in some cases no privacy policy at all, and are in no way ready for the stricter privacy guidelines.”

data.name: GdprBlock7Text2
data.value: In order to determine which websites collect data, and therefore need to update their privacy policy, vpnMentor based their research on sites that use MailChimp to collect user Email addresses. They have collected as many 100 websites per country, and looked at their privacy policy, if they had one, to determine if it was GDPR compliant.

data.name: GdprBlock8Heading
data.value: How will Brexit impact the GDPR? Will it apply to businesses in the UK?

data.name: GdprBlock8Text1
data.value: If your business is located in the UK, it will also have to comply with the EU regulation. The UK has stated that it will comply with the GDPR, and that its compliance will not be affected by Brexit.

data.name: GdprBlock9Heading
data.value: Where can I find more reliable information on the GDPR?

data.name: GdprBlock9LinkLabel1
data.value: Read and download the complete Regulations

data.name: GdprBlock9LinkLabel2
data.value: EU’s GDPR dedicated website

data.name: GdprBlock9LinkLabel3
data.value: Summary of the articles

data.name: GdprClauseRowText1
data.value: Art. 32 of GDPR: Security of processing

data.name: GdprClauseRowText2
data.value: GDPR's requirement for appropriate technical measures to protect data at rest.

data.name: GdprClauseRowText3
data.value: AES-256 military-grade encryption ensures your files remain unreadable even in the event of unauthorized access or data breaches.

data.name: GdprClauseRowText4
data.value: Art. 15-21 of GDPR: Data Subject Rights

data.name: GdprClauseRowText5
data.value: Facilitate secure access for data subject requests while minimizing risk.

data.name: GdprClauseRowText6
data.value: With AxCrypt, collaborate securely with colleagues or clients by sharing encrypted files with temporary decryption keys, minimizing data exposure during collaboration.

data.name: GdprClauseRowText7
data.value: Art. 32 of GDPR: Storage Security

data.name: GdprClauseRowText8
data.value: Enhance security of personal data stored in the cloud.

data.name: GdprClauseRowText9
data.value: AxCrypt encrypts files stored on popular cloud storage providers like Google Drive and Dropbox, adding an extra layer of security to your cloud-based data.

data.name: GdprComplyHeading1
data.value: How does AxCrypt Help with GDPR Compliance?

data.name: GdprComplyParagraph
data.value: Here’s how AxCrypt simplifies your GDPR compliance journey:

data.name: GdprDescriptionParagraph1
data.value: AxCrypt makes complying with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) straightforward and effective. Our true Zero-Knowledge architecture empowers your organization to take complete control of its data privacy, ensuring that only authorized users have access to the data – not even AxCrypt can view it.

data.name: GdprDescrptnHeading1
data.value: GDPR Compliance with AxCrypt

data.name: GdprHeading
data.value: EU General Data Protection Regulation

data.name: GdprInfoHeading1
data.value: Take Control of Your Data Security with AxCrypt

data.name: GdprInfoParagraph1
data.value: Ensuring GDPR compliance is crucial for protecting personal data and maintaining the trust of your customers and stakeholders. AxCrypt simplifies this process by providing robust encryption solutions designed to meet GDPR requirements effectively. With AxCrypt, you can focus on your core business activities, confident that your data is secure.

data.name: GetStartedInfoNote1ListItem1

data.name: GetStartedInfoNote1ListItem2
data.value: If you are upgrading from a previous version of AxCrypt, you may need to restart your computer.

data.name: GetStartedInfoNote1ListItem3
data.value: Verify that the download is undamaged and authentic by checking the digital signature. Right-click the downloaded file in Windows Explorer, and select ‘Properties’ and the ‘Digital Signatures’ tab. Then select the digital signature and click ‘Details’. Ensure that the digital signature is shown as ‘OK’ and that the signer is ‘AxCrypt AB’.

data.name: GetStartedInfoNote2Text2
data.value: Please report bugs and comments to us. You’re welcome to request support as well. For other issues, please send us an email.

data.name: Group Title
data.value: Group

data.name: GroupBlockSupportText1
data.value: For any additional support and help, please feel free to reach out to us via email. Contact Support: support@axcrypt.net.

data.name: GroupBlockSupportText2
data.value: You can also request a business demo to get a live overview and learn more about our services and solutions.

data.name: GroupFeatureDescriptionForMoreText1
data.value: For more information about group...

data.name: GroupFeatureDescriptionText
data.value: This feature enables admins to add users to specific groups, with the flexibility for users to belong to multiple groups simultaneously. There are no restrictions on users being part of only one group, providing greater versatility and management efficiency.

data.name: GroupFeatureDescriptionText1
data.value: Furthermore, business admins can designate any member within a group as a group admin and assign specific roles to them. Group admins have the authority to add or remove users from the group, facilitating more streamlined and decentralized group management. This hierarchical approach ensures that key sharing is managed effectively while maintaining the desired level of privacy and control for the business admin.

data.name: GroupFeatureInfoText
data.value: Add users or Groups with whom you want to share this secret. If you don`t know about our Group Feature yet, learn more and create your first one by the link

data.name: GroupFileSharingHeading
data.value: Group File Sharing

data.name: GroupFileSharingParagraph
data.value: Easily share files with entire groups at once with utmost security.

data.name: GroupGuidesDescription
data.value: Welcome to AxCrypt's Group Feature guide. Learn how to create and manage user groups, assign key group roles within your teams and effectively manage file access within the groups using the Group Masterkey.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading1
data.value: What is AxCrypt`s Group Feature?

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading1Paragraph1
data.value: AxCrypt's Group Feature is designed to enhance organizational efficiency by facilitating businesses to manage users via structured departmental groups hence streamlining file access restrictions, and implementing granular key management.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading2
data.value: Why use AxCrypt`s Group Feature?

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading2Paragraph1
data.value: Imagine a company with several departments like Finance, HR, and IT. AxCrypt's Group Feature allows you to create distinct groups for each department, ensuring that only the relevant team members have access to the necessary documents.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading2Paragraph2
data.value: For example, Finance team members would access only financial documents, HR personnel would manage employee records, and IT staff would handle technical data. This structure maintains data confidentiality and significantly reduces the risk of unauthorized access.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading2Paragraph3
data.value: AxCrypt’s Group Feature allows you to assign specific roles within each group, such as Admins or regular members, which helps in managing access and responsibilities effectively. For added security and convenience, the Group Masterkey feature enables Admins to recover encrypted files across all groups without needing individual passwords. This is particularly useful during team transitions, employee departures, or when dealing with password issues, as it simplifies access management without compromising security.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3
data.value: How does AxCrypt`s Group Feature work?

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3Paragraph1
data.value: AxCrypt’s Group Feature includes the following key aspects:

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3SubHead1
data.value: Group Creation

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3SubHead3
data.value: Group Masterkey

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3SubHead4
data.value: Role Assigning

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3SubHead5
data.value: Secure Group Sharing

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3Text1
data.value: Easily create user groups within the organization to manage different departmental access and streamline data security.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3Text2
data.value: Efficiently handle group memberships and permissions, allowing you to restrict file access to specific groups and users.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3Text3
data.value: Enables Masterkey Owners and Group Admins to recover group-specific encrypted files without needing individual passwords, ensuring secure and convenient file access.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3Text4
data.value: Assign different roles to group members for clear hierarchy and responsibility distribution, enhancing team management.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading3Text5
data.value: Simplify the process of sharing encrypted files and passwords with entire teams, promoting holistic collaboration while maintaining data confidentiality.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4
data.value: How to use Group Feature?

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4Paragraph1
data.value: Navigate to Your AxCrypt ID: Login as a Business Admin to your AxCrypt ID here. Click on “Groups” in the left side-menu and click on the large “+” icon.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4Paragraph2
data.value: Create Group: On the “Create group” page, enter the group name and description, and Click the “+” icon to add each member to the list by their email addresses. If you’d like to remove a user, click the “X” button next to the respective email. A user can be a part of multiple groups.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4Paragraph3
data.value: Alternatively: Groups can also be created by going to the “Users” page on the left-side menu. Make sure that no group is selected in the dropdown. Now select one or more users then click on “Actions” and select “Add to group”.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4Paragraph4
data.value: Save Group: Ensure the number of added members does not exceed the available licenses. Click the “SAVE” button to create the group.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4Paragraph5
data.value: View Groups: Click the “Groups” option in the side menu to see all created groups displayed as cards.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4Paragraph6
data.value: Manage Groups: Use the three-dot menu on the group card to modify the group name and description, add users, and delete the group.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4Paragraph7
data.value: Add Members: Click on the group to go to the group’s page, and under the “Manager users” section, click on the “Add Users” button on the right to add more members by their email. You can add users in bulk by importing a spreadsheet with a list of emails on the add users’ dialogue box.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4Paragraph8
data.value: Remove Members: Click on the group to go to the group’s page, and under the “Manager users” section. Under the group name, select the users that you’d like to remove by clicking on the checkbox next to a user’s email, then click on the “Actions” button above to select the “Delete” option and confirm the removal.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4Paragraph9
data.value: Check Licenses: Under the “Users” page in the left-side menu, use the “Manage Users” section to view and manage all licenses.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4SubHead1
data.value: Creating a Group

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading4SubHead2
data.value: Managing Groups

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5
data.value: Group Roles and Group Masterkey

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5Paragraph1
data.value: AxCrypt's Group Feature includes a robust role management system designed to increase efficiency by distributing tasks and privileges in a systematic hierarchy. The roles, in order of authority are:

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5Paragraph2
data.value: This structure allows for clear delegation and management of responsibilities, ensuring that sensitive information is accessed and managed appropriately, facilitating secure collaboration and streamlined operations.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5SubHead1
data.value: Roles

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5SubTitle1Text1
data.value: Owns complete control of AxCrypt Business subscription like managing groups, users and more.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5SubTitle2
data.value:
Business Admin /
Masterkey Owner

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5SubTitle3
data.value: Group Admin

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5SubTitle3Text1
data.value: Assigned by the Business Admins, Group Admins manage group-specific tasks within the assigned groups. Group Admins can be members or admins of multiple groups.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5SubTitle4
data.value: Group Member

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading5SubTitle4Text1
data.value: Group Members also known as the Standard Users, can access and collaborate on files within their assigned groups.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6
data.value: Group Masterkey

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6Paragraph1
data.value: The Group Masterkey is a pivotal feature of AxCrypt's Group functionality, designed to enhance security and streamline key management within an organization.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6SubHead1
data.value: Secure Recovery

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6SubHead2
data.value: Efficient Key Management

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6SubHead3
data.value: Role-Based Access

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6SubHead4
data.value: Enhanced Security

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6Text1
data.value: The Group Masterkey allows Group Admins and Masterkey Owner to recover encrypted files specific to their group without needing the individual passwords of group members. This ensures that important data remains accessible even if a member leaves or forgets their password.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6Text2
data.value: With the Group Masterkey, Business Admins can maintain control over encrypted files while delegating access to Group Admins. This hierarchical key management system increases efficiency and ensures that key sharing is both secure and manageable.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6Text3
data.value: The Group Masterkey functionality integrates seamlessly with AxCrypt's role-based access control. While Group Admins can enable or disable the Group Masterkey, and responsible for managing it within their respective groups. Group Members are required to approve the Masterkey access.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading6Text4
data.value: The use of the Group Masterkey minimizes the risk of data breaches by reducing the dependency on individual passwords. This centralized key management approach ensures that all encrypted data can be accessed only by authorized personnel, enhancing overall security and compliance.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7
data.value: Steps to Manage Group Roles and Group Masterkey

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead1
data.value: Assign Business Admins

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead1Text1
data.value: On your AxCrypt ID page, click on the “Users” page in the left-side menu and scroll down to see the list of all the active users of the subscription. Ensure no group is selected.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead1Text3
data.value: Click on the “Standard User” dropdown under the “Roles” column next to the user’s email and select “Administrator.” This will update the user’s role as Business Admin.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead1Text4
data.value: To remove a user as a Business Admin, click on the “Administrator” dropdown again and select “Standard User.”

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead2
data.value: Assign Group Admins

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead2Text1
data.value: On your AxCrypt ID page, click on the “Users” page in the left-side menu and scroll down to see the list of all users of the subscription.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead2Text2
data.value: Select the desired group from the group selection dropdown.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead2Text3
data.value: Click on the “Standard User” dropdown under the “Roles” column next to the user’s email and select “Administrator.” This will update the user’s role as Group Admin.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead2Text4
data.value: To remove a user as a Group Admin, click on the “Administrator” dropdown again and select “Standard User.”

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead3
data.value: Manage Group Users

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead3Text1
data.value: On your AxCrypt ID page, click on the “Users” page in the left-side menu and scroll down to see the list of all the active users of the subscription.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead3Text2
data.value: Select the desired group user(s) and click on the “Action” button on top to:

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead3Text3
data.value: Delete: Removes the selected user(s) from the group, revoking their access to any shared group files and settings.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead3Text4
data.value: Restore Masterkey: Recovers access to encrypted files without needing individual passwords or keys, allowing Admins to decrypt files as necessary.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead3Text5
data.value: Disable Masterkey Access: Prevents selected user(s) from the group to decrypt files shared within the group

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead3Text6
data.value: Enable Masterkey Access: Allows selected user(s) from the group to decrypt files shared within the Group. Files encrypted before enabling will not be accessible with the Masterkey and require re-encryption during the enablement.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead3Text7
data.value: Disable Access: Restricts the selected user(s) from accessing the group, effectively removing their permissions to view or edit group files and also not be part of any file sharing.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead3Text8
data.value: Enable Access: Restores the selected user(s) permissions to access and interact with files shared within the group, reinstating their previous access levels.

data.name: GroupGuidesHeading7SubHead4
data.value: Check Masterkey Status

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText1
data.value: HIPAA Privacy Rule (45 CFR Part 164 Subparts A and C)

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText10
data.value: HIPAA Security Rule ( 45 CFR § 164.312(a)(1) & (c)(1) )

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText11
data.value: Implement technical safeguards to protect ePHI, including access controls and encryption at rest.

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText12
data.value: Implement technical safeguards to protect ePHI, including access controls and encryption at rest.

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText2
data.value: Requires covered entities to implement safeguards to protect PHI privacy and prevent unauthorized access.

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText3
data.value: AxCrypt encrypts and secures PHI at rest and in transit with military-grade AES-256 encryption, rendering it inaccessible to unauthorized users even if intercepted. Encrypted files can be securely shared with teams and external stakeholders.

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText4
data.value: HIPAA Security Rule ( 45 CFR §164.306 (a) & (b) (1) )

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText5
data.value: Requires entities to implement measures to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all electronic protected health information (ePHIs) that entities create, receive, maintain, or transmit, while also protecting the ePHIs from anticipated threats.

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText6
data.value: With AxCrypt, encrypted files can be securely shared with military-grade AES-256 encryption. This ensures the confidentiality and integrity of ePHI while securing the files. Even if unauthorized individuals gain access to encrypted files, the data will be indecipherable.

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText7
data.value: HIPAA Security Rule ( 45 CFR § 164.308(a)(1) )

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText8
data.value: Implement administrative, physical, and technical safeguards for ePHI.

data.name: HipaaClauseRowText9
data.value: AxCrypt’s Zero-knowledge architecture and automatic encryption ensures encryption keys never leave the user's device, eliminating unauthorized access risks even during incidents.

data.name: HipaaComplyHeading1
data.value: How does AxCrypt Helps Your Organization Comply with HIPAA?

data.name: HipaaComplyParagraph
data.value: Here’s how AxCrypt addresses some of the key HIPAA requirements to secure your healthcare data and help you in your organization in its HIPAA compliance journey:

data.name: HipaaDescriptionParagraph1
data.value: Ensuring the privacy and security of Protected Health Information (PHI) is a fundamental requirement under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). AxCrypt simplifies your compliance journey with advanced encryption solutions, designed to meet and easily comply with HIPAA stringent requirements.

data.name: HipaaDescriptionSubParagraph1
data.value:
AxCrypt’s solutions are designed to seamlessly integrate into your existing workflows, providing robust encryption and data security without compromising usability. Our commitment to data privacy and security aligns with HIPAA’s stringent requirements, ensuring your healthcare organization can confidently manage and protect PHI.

Our true Zero-Knowledge architecture ensures that only authorized users have access to the data, and not even AxCrypt can access it.

data.name: IndustriesBenefitsText0
data.value:
AxCrypt utilizes the strongest encryption standard – the AES 256-Bit algorithm – to encrypt and protect data across devices. With its user-friendly and efficient encryption tools including the password manager, cloud storage integration, and master key; AxCrypt has become a trusted solution for companies across industries including finance, healthcare, legal, and government.

AxCrypt's encryption technology ensures that only authorized individuals can access confidential files, protecting sensitive data from cyber threats and data breaches. Additionally, AxCrypt's flexible deployment options and robust management features allow businesses to scale their encryption needs to meet regulatory compliance requirements and ensure their data is secured, always.

data.name: IndustriesBenefitsTitle
data.value: Benefits of using Axcrypt

data.name: IndustriesBlogLabel
data.value: New to encryption? Check out our blog for the latest news.

data.name: IndustriesEducationContent1
data.value:
Data and file encryption acts as the first line of defence against data breaches and cyber attacks, recommended by renowned institutions and organisations like NIST, IBM, and Microsoft. Data encryption plays a critical role in enhancing data security and privacy in the education industry.

The encryption mechanism, using an encryption algorithm like AES, essentially transforms the contents of any file into an unreadable and indecipherable format, making it inaccessible to unauthorised users. Only authorised individuals with access to the decryption key can reverse the encryption process and gain access to the file's contents.

data.name: IndustriesEducationContent2
data.value:
AxCrypt is an award winning file encryption software that protects sensitive information of your universities, colleges, and schools using the AES-256 algorithm! Educational institutions can use AxCrypt to encrypt and protect student records, financial information, and research documents.

AxCrypt ensures that this information remains encrypted and inaccessible to unauthorized individuals, safeguarding student privacy and protecting from data breaches.

AxCrypt is trusted by renowned universities and academic institutions around the world, and is highly recommended as the preferred choice for robust data encryption.

data.name: IndustriesEducationHeading
data.value: Secure proprietary essays, papers, reports, theses and research.

data.name: IndustriesFinancialBenefitsText
data.value:
The financial service industry today is more digital and data-intensive than ever before. People are increasingly using their phones and computers more than their wallets and books to pay, invest, and manage their finances. Internet banking has also replaced most of the operations that were traditionally performed physically in a bank.

This rapid surge in the volumes of finance data being generated by users everyday, also makes it highly vulnerable to cyber attacks and data breaches. Data breaches in the financial service industry are the second most expensive, costing an average of $5.72 million. Small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) are the worst affected by data breaches, as they account for 42% of all data breaches, and 60% of SMBs shut down within 6 months of a breach. Encryption is a proactive approach to securing your financial data that can shield it at all times.

data.name: IndustriesFinancialContent1
data.value:
Encryption for your financial data acts as the first line of defense against cyber attacks and data breaches, recommended by renowned institutions and organizations like NIST, IBM, and Microsoft. During the encryption process, contents of the files are transformed into an unreadable and undecipherable format using encryption algorithms and cryptographic keys. 

The transformation of the files’ contents ensures that only the authorized users who have access to the cryptographic keys can decrypt and access the encrypted files. Encrypted files are also useless in the hands of cyber attackers during a data breach without the specific decryption keys.

data.name: IndustriesFinancialContent2
data.value:
AxCrypt is an award winning file encryption software that protects sensitive financial data and files using the AES-256 algorithm. Use AxCrypt to encrypt and protect transaction records, customer information, financial documents, and more. AxCrypt ensures that your data remains encrypted and inaccessible to unauthorized individuals at all times, safeguarding your organization's privacy and protecting it from cyber attacks and breaches.

AxCrypt has been awarded as the ‘Best Encryption Software’ by PCMag for six consecutive years. AxCrypt is available for Windows, MacOS, iOS, and Android, and can automatically encrypt and sync files to popular cloud storage services like Google Drive, OneDrive, and Dropbox.

data.name: IndustriesGovernmentBenefitsText
data.value:
In today's AI era, governments worldwide face escalating cybersecurity threats that pose significant risks to sensitive information, public safety, and national security.

Recent incidents, such as the SolarWinds cyberattack in 2020, underscore the imperative need for robust encryption measures to safeguard sensitive government data from unauthorized access and exploitation.

Encryption stands as a critical tool in bolstering government defenses against cyber threats, ensuring the integrity and confidentiality of classified documents, public records, and sensitive communications.

data.name: IndustriesGovernmentContent1
data.value:
Instead of just locking a file, encryption transforms the contents of a file into an unreadable and undecipherable format. Using an encryption algorithm like AES, it rearranges, shifts, replaces, and mixes a file’s contents. The encryption keys used with the algorithm dictate the precise sequence of these transformations, allowing for the reversal of the encryption process (decryption) to restore the contents of a file to its original state.
Unlike alternative security methods like password protection of files, file encryption with the AES-256 provides an unbreakable security measure. With a key length of 256, it becomes practically impossible to break an encrypted file, even with the most powerful supercomputers available today.

This complex process ensures that sensitive files are protected at all times, and only the authorized users with access to keys can decrypt the files.

data.name: IndustriesGovernmentContent2
data.value:
AxCrypt’s award winning and Zero-Knowledge file encryption software protects government data in one click. Secure files such as important government documents, public records, confidential reports, classified files, and more – with AES-256 bit data encryption standard. Create automatic encryption mechanisms to encrypt files within a folder and sync them to popular cloud storage providers.

AxCrypt is the number 1 choice of PCMag as the ‘Best Encryption Software’ of 2024. It has been the number 1 for nine consecutive years from 2016 to 2024. It's available for Windows, Mac, iOS, and Android, and can automatically encrypt and sync files to popular cloud storage services like Google Drive, OneDrive, and Dropbox.

data.name: IndustriesHealthcareBenefitsText
data.value:
The healthcare sector is rapidly seeing an exponential increase in the volume of sensitive data being generated everyday. From patient’s details to Electronic Health Records (EHR), healthcare providers have a lot to protect for. Approximately 30% of the world's data volume is being generated by the healthcare industry, and this number is expected to grow tremendously in the near future.

This exponential increase in the healthcare data also makes it highly vulnerable to devastating cyber attacks and data breaches. Healthcare has the highest cost for a data breach out of all industries costing an average of $11 million, and it was the third most attacked industry in 2022. With these alarming stats, it becomes critically important for healthcare service providers to prioritize their data security, especially with data at rest. Thankfully, there is a powerful and highly effective measure for sensitive healthcare data called encryption. File encryption protects a file by transforming its contents, making it unreadable and undecipherable to unauthorized users.

data.name: IndustriesHealthcareContent1
data.value:
File encryption creates a strong protective shield for your sensitive healthcare data, protecting against cyber attacks and data breaches. It is a recommended measure by renowned institutions and organizations like NIST, IBM, and Microsoft. During the encryption process, contents of healthcare files are transformed into an unreadable and undecipherable format using encryption algorithms and cryptographic keys.

The transformation of the files' contents ensures that only authorized users with access to the cryptographic keys can decrypt and access the encrypted files. Encrypted files are also rendered useless in the hands of cyber attackers during a data breach without the specific decryption keys.

data.name: IndustriesHealthcareContent2
data.value:
AxCrypt is an award winning file encryption software that protects your sensitive healthcare files using the AES-256 algorithm. It protects patient information, Electronic Health Records (EHR), insurance details, and more. AxCrypt ensures that your data remains encrypted and inaccessible to unauthorized individuals at all times even when you share it with others, safeguarding your healthcare organization's privacy and protecting it from cyber attacks and breaches. It also helps you easily comply with HIPAA.

AxCrypt has been awarded as the ‘Best Encryption Software’ by PCMag for nine consecutive years from 2016 to 2024. It's available for Windows, Mac, iOS, and Android, and can automatically encrypt and sync files to popular cloud storage services like Google Drive, OneDrive, and Dropbox.

data.name: IndustriesHealthcareHeading
data.value: Secure Sensitive Health Records, Crucial Medical Documents.

data.name: IndustriesLegalBenefitsText
data.value:
The legal industry thrives on confidentiality and data protection. From contracts and client information to intellectual property and litigation documents, legal professionals handle a constant stream of highly sensitive information that requires superior protection.  Even a minor security breach can have devastating consequences, leading to financial losses and reputational damage.

AxCrypt understands the critical need for robust data security in the legal field. Our award-winning file encryption software empowers legal professionals to protect their confidential information at every stage, ensuring compliance with data privacy regulations and fostering a climate of trust with clients.

Whether you're collaborating on a complex litigation case, managing sensitive client contracts, or exchanging confidential documents, AxCrypt provides a simple yet powerful solution. Our on-the-go encryption capabilities ensure secure file sharing with colleagues and clients, while cloud storage integration allows for convenient access to encrypted data from any device. Additionally, AxCrypt's automatic encryption features streamline workflows, protecting sensitive documents the moment they are created or edited.

data.name: IndustriesLegalContent1
data.value:
Encryption as a process, transforms the contents of any legal file into an unreadable and undecipherable format using an encryption key. With an encryption algorithm like AES, it rearranges, shifts, replaces, and mixes a file’s contents. The encryption keys used with the algorithm dictate the precise sequence of these transformations, allowing for the reversal of the encryption process (decryption) to restore the contents of a file to its original state.

Unlike alternative security methods like password protection, which simply locks the files, file encryption with the AES-256 provides an unbreakable security measure. With a key length of 256, it becomes practically impossible to break an encrypted file, even with the most powerful supercomputers available today.

This complex process ensures that sensitive files such as contracts and client records etc., are protected at all times, and only the authorized users with access to keys can decrypt the files.

data.name: IndustriesLegalContent2
data.value:
AxCrypt’s award winning and Zero-Knowledge file encryption software secures your sensitive legal data in one click. Protect files such as important case files, patent documents, clients records, confidential documents and more – with AES-256 bit data encryption standard. Create automatic encryption mechanisms to encrypt files within a folder and sync them to popular cloud storage providers.

AxCrypt is the number 1 choice of PCMag as the ‘Best Encryption Software’ in 2024. It has been the number 1 for nine consecutive years since 2016. AxCrypt is available for Windows, Mac, iOS, and Android, and can automatically encrypt and sync files to popular cloud storage services like Google Drive, OneDrive, and Dropbox.

data.name: IndustriesTechBenefitsText
data.value:
The tech and IT sectors are some of the most targeted sectors today in terms of data breaches, ransomware attacks, and cyber threats.

Ransomware attacks in the IT sector have surged by 47% in 2023. Additionally, 43% of enterprises failed a compliance audit last year, making them 10x more vulnerable to data breaches.

These alarming trends underscore the significant importance of data encryption in the IT sector. Encryption for data at rest, acts as a protective shield for IT files, securing them all times from unauthorized access. It safeguards sensitive data, helps comply with regulations like GDPR, HIPAA, FIPs, etc., and gives organizations control over their data privacy and security measures.

data.name: IndustriesTechConfidentiality
data.value: Use master key, a feature which enables business administrators to recover files of the business members, eliminating the risk of losing access to critical files due to employees leaving or forgetting their passwords.

data.name: IndustriesTechContent1
data.value:
File encryption with the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES-256) is a recommended security measure by renowned institutions and organizations like NIST, IBM, and Microsoft. File encryption creates a robust protective shield for your organization’s sensitive IT data.

Unlike alternative security methods like password protection of files, the AES-256 bit encryption provides an unbreakable security measure. With a key length of 256, it becomes practically impossible to break an encrypted file, even with the most powerful supercomputers available today.

Instead of just locking it, encryption transforms the contents of a file into an unreadable and scrambled text. Using an encryption algorithm like AES, it rearranges, shifts, replaces, and mixes a file’s contents. The encryption keys used with the algorithm dictate the precise sequence of these transformations, allowing for the reversal of the encryption process to restore the contents of a file to its original state.
This complex process ensures that sensitive files are protected at all times, and only the authorized users with access to keys can decrypt the files.

data.name: IndustriesTechContent2
data.value:
AxCrypt’s award winning and Zero-Knowledge file encryption software protects your IT data in one-click. Secure files such as important source codes and project files, business and financial PDFs, sensitive client communication records, human resource documents and more – with AES-256 bit data encryption standard. Create automatic encryption mechanisms to encrypt files within a folder and sync them to popular cloud storage providers.

AxCrypt has been the number 1 choice of PCMag as the ‘Best Encryption Software’ for nine consecutive years from 2016 to 2024. It's available for Windows, Mac, iOS, and Android, and can automatically encrypt and sync files to popular cloud storage services like Google Drive, OneDrive, and Dropbox.

data.name: Legacy-verify-Download-Answer
data.value: Most installers and executables are digitally signed with Authenticode by ‘Axantum Software AB’ or ‘AxCrypt AB’. Verify the signature after downloading by right-clicking the file and select ‘Properties | Digital Signatures’. Then double-click on the signature and confirm that ‘This digital signature is OK’ is shown.

data.name: Legacy-verify-Download-Question
data.value: How to Verify a Download?

data.name: Legacy-Version-Heading
data.value: AxCrypt Legacy Version

data.name: Legacy-Version-Point1
data.value: AxCrypt Legacy was designed to provide secure file encryption for users, offering reliable and effective protection through a simple passphrase system. It played a major role in making file encryption accessible to both personal and professional users, ensuring that only authorized individuals could access encrypted data. Its user-friendly interface allowed many to easily protect sensitive files, even if they were unfamiliar with encryption technologies.

data.name: Legacy-Version-Point2
data.value: The Legacy version introduced essential AES encryption capabilities that met the needs of its time, allowing users to perform multiple encryption operations efficiently. By setting the stage for future advancements, Axcrypt Legacy showcased our commitment to advanced encryption. Although AxCrypt Legacy is no longer actively supported, files encrypted with it remain secure and can still be decrypted using AxCrypt 2, ensuring continued access to important data. We appreciate the vital role AxCrypt Legacy played in our development and encourage users to transition to AxCrypt 2 to benefit from enhanced AES- 256 file encryption and other latest features.

data.name: Legacy-Version-Point3
data.value: NOTE: These are AxCrypt Legacy downloads. We do not endorse them and urge you not to download and use these, unless you have a specific need for it. New files encrypted with AxCrypt 2 are not compatible with AxCrypt Legacy ! Files encrypted with AxCrypt Legacy are decryptable by AxCrypt 2.

data.name: LegacyConversionVerificationPrompt
data.value:
After files are converted they will only open with the current AxCrypt password. Please verify your password.
Do not forget this password!

data.name: LegacyDownloadsDescription
data.value: These are Legacy AxCrypt 1.x downloads. We do not endorse them and urge you not to download and use these, unless you have a specific need for it. New files encrypted with AxCrypt 2.x are not compatible with legacy AxCrypt 1.x! Files encrypted with legacy AxCrypt 1.x are decryptable by AxCrypt 2.x.

data.name: LegacyDownloadsHowToVerifyHeading
data.value: How to Verify a Download

data.name: LegacyDownloadsHowToVerifyText
data.value: Most installers and executables are digitally signed with Authenticode by ‘Axantum Software AB’ or ‘AxCrypt AB’. Verify the signature after downloading by right-clicking the file and select ‘Properties | Digital Signatures’. Then double-click on the signature and confirm that ‘This digital signature is OK’ is shown.

data.name: LegacyDownloadsLinkLabel
data.value: Legacy Downloads

data.name: LegacyDownloadsWarning
data.value: This version is obsolete and we do not offer support for it. AxCrypt 1.x is not maintained and you should not download it, unless specifically needed. Using it is at your own risk.

data.name: LegacyFaq1
data.value: What’s new in AxCrypt 2 compared to the legacy version?

data.name: LegacyFaq1Ans
data.value: AxCrypt 2 introduces a modern interface, a unified password system, and enhanced encryption features. Unlike the legacy version, it includes a streamlined sign-in process and advanced functionalities for easier file management and sharing.

data.name: LegacyFaq2
data.value: How does AxCrypt 2 handle file decryption?

data.name: LegacyFaq2Ans
data.value: With AxCrypt 2, you use a single password to decrypt all your files. This simplifies file management compared to the legacy version, where different passwords were needed for each file.

data.name: LegacyFaq3
data.value: Can I still use the old AxCrypt 1.x?

data.name: LegacyFaq3Ans
data.value: While AxCrypt Legacy is still available, we strongly recommend upgrading to AxCrypt 2 for enhanced security and user experience. The new version offers advanced AES- 256 encryption unlike the AES- 128 encryption that Axcrypt Legacy provides.

data.name: LegacyFaq4
data.value: In which operating systems is AxCrypt 2 available?

data.name: LegacyFaq4Ans
data.value: AxCrypt 2 is available on multiple platforms, including Windows, macOS, iOS, and Android.

data.name: LegacyFaq5
data.value: How does AxCrypt 2 improve password management?

data.name: LegacyFaq5Ans
data.value: AxCrypt 2 eliminates the need for multiple passwords by allowing you to use a single, strong password for all your encrypted files. This not only makes it easier to manage your files but also enhances overall security by reducing the risk of weak passwords.

data.name: LegacyFaq6
data.value: Is self-decryption supported in AxCrypt 2?

data.name: LegacyFaq6Ans
data.value: No, AxCrypt 2 does not support self-decryption of files. This feature was removed due to significant security risks, such as the potential for self-decrypting files to contain strongly encrypted information, including malicious software, which is impossible for antivirus programs to screen.

data.name: LegacyFaq7
data.value: How does AxCrypt 2 enhance security over AxCrypt 1.x?

data.name: LegacyFaq7Ans
data.value: AxCrypt 2 offers several security enhancements, including stronger AES- 256 encryption algorithms, a unified password system, and improved file sharing features. Additionally, the new version provides better protection against common security risks through its streamlined sign-in process and the latest interface.

data.name: LegacyFaq8
data.value: Will upgrading to AxCrypt 2 affect my existing encrypted files?

data.name: LegacyFaq8Ans
data.value: Upgrading to AxCrypt 2 will not affect your existing encrypted files. The new version is fully compatible with files encrypted using AxCrypt 1.x, and it also offers an auto-conversion feature to quickly adapt your files to the new system.

data.name: LegacyFaq9
data.value: How do I upgrade from AxCrypt Legacy to AxCrypt 2?

data.name: LegacyFaq9Ans
data.value: To upgrade from AxCrypt Legacy to AxCrypt 2, simply install AxCrypt 2 over your existing AxCrypt 1 installation. No need to uninstall first. No harm done either.

data.name: LegacyOpenMessage
data.value:
AxCrypt 2 uses a new file format.
You can open legacy AxCrypt 1.x files but unless they are converted you have to provide the original password even when signed in.
Enable automatic conversion of AxCrypt 1.x files (recommended)?

data.name: LegacyType
data.value: AxCrypt Legacy Vs AxCrypt 2

data.name: LegacyTypeSummary
data.value: AxCrypt 2 redefines file encryption with advanced security features and an intuitive interface. It not only enhances your data protection but also simplifies the encryption process, making it the top choice for efficient and reliable security.

data.name: LegacyWarning
